Preface
Lanthanide-doped luminescent inorganic nanoparticles (NPs) possess superior physicochemical features such as long-lived luminescence (from several to tens of milliseconds), large apparent Stokes and/or anti-Stokes shifts, narrow emission bands, high resistance to photobleaching, and low toxicity and thus are regarded as a new generation of bioprobes as compared to conventional molecular probes like organic dyes and lanthanide chelates. These functional NPs, albeit most of their bulk counterparts were well studied previously, have stimulated the growing interests in the deep insights of their spectroscopic properties coupled with their biomedical applications in diverse fields such as biodetection, disease diagnosis, and therapeutics. This can be well established by the number of the articles published on the lanthanide-doped luminescent NPs over the past 5 years (>6,000, by surveying in the ISI Web of Science using the key words “lanthanide OR rare earth” and “nanoparticles OR nanocrystals”). Over the years, many descriptions of luminescent bioprobes have appeared in academic journals and books, but most of them are restricted to quantum dots or molecular bioprobes like lanthanide chelates. This is in sharp contrast with this book which covers a wide range of luminescent bioapplications based on lanthanide-doped inorganic nanomaterials.
This book is aimed at providing a comprehensive review of the latest advances made in developing lanthanide-doped luminescent inorganic NPs as potential bioprobes, which cover from their chemical and physical fundamentals to bioapplications including the controlled synthesis methodology, surface modification chemistry, optical physics, and their promising applications in diverse fields. Although significant advances have recently been made toward the use of lanthanide-doped luminescent nano-bioprobes for tumor biomarker detection and imaging, there is still a long way to go before its commercialization for clinical use since there still remain many technical difficulties and economic concerns to be finally solved. In this regard, we hope that this book not only provides a useful guide to both the beginners and advanced researchers but also keenly advises the most important emerging trends and future efforts toward this active research field. Such an effort may eventually open up new avenues for the exploration of lanthanide-doped inorganic nanoprobes in versatile luminescent bioapplications.

vi Preface
This book is divided into nine chapters. A general introduction to free lanthanide ions is addressed in Chap. 1, which includes the energy level structures, selection rules of electronic transitions, site symmetry, as well as crystal-field theory for free lanthanide ions. The size effect on the luminescence of lanthanide ions doped in diverse inorganic NPs is briefly discussed in Chap. 2, with an emphasis on the size confinement on luminescence dynamics of lanthanide ions. In Chap. 3, we would like to highlight the most representative synthetic approaches reported in the past decade to prepare high-quality core-only and core–shell NPs. In Chap. 4, we attempt to overview the most typical surface modification strategies along with one-pot syntheses to produce hydrophilic NPs for their versatile applications. Furthermore, the most common strategies for bioconjugation of surface-modified NPs and diverse biological molecules are also given in this chapter. The most recent progress in the optical spectroscopy of lanthanide-doped NPs is fully discussed in Chap. 5. Particularly, we provide an in-depth overview of the optical properties for lanthanide-doped semiconductor and insulator NPs, with an emphasis on the hostsensitized long-lived downshifting luminescence and the multicolor upconversion luminescence of lanthanide ions. Furthermore, the use of lanthanide ions as a sensitive structural probe to detect the local structure of dopants is also provided in this chapter. In Chap. 6, we focus on the most recent advances in the development of lanthanide-doped luminescent nano-bioprobes and their in vitro homogeneous and heterogeneous detection of biomolecules and tumor biomarkers. In Chap. 7, we provide a comprehensive overview of the use of lanthanide-doped luminescent NPs as efficient optical and magnetic resonance imaging contrast agents for in vitro and in vivo imaging, which utilizes the long-lived luminescence of lanthanide ions and deep penetration as a merit of upconversion. A detailed overview of the typical design strategies for optical/magnetic multimodal bioprobes as well as significant applications in multimodal imaging, sensing, and therapy recently reported in the literature is outlined in Chap. 8. Finally, some most important emerging trends and future efforts toward this active research field are proposed based on our understanding and research experience in this field.
This book is particularly written for those readers who are interested in systematically understanding the materials design strategy, optical behavior of lanthanide ions, and practical bioapplications based on inorganic lanthanide-doped luminescent NPs. It primarily focuses on the interdisciplinary frontiers in chemistry, photophysics, and biological aspects of luminescent nanomaterials. We believe that both beginners and advanced researchers in the fields of nanoscience and nanotechnology including nano-chemistry, nano-physics, nanomedicine, and biomaterials, particularly postdoctoral researchers and senior graduate students, will benefit or get inspired from this book.

sections.heading: A General Introduction to Lanthanide Ions
sections.text: Abstract Lanthanide (Ln) ions are long known as the lighting elements. Their intricate optical properties originate primarily from the unique features of their electronic [Xe]4f N configurations (ND 0–14), which have very localized states and can be conventionally described within the framework of crystal-field theory. On placing an Ln ion in a dielectric crystal, the energy levels split under the influence of the electric field produced by the crystalline environment. In this chapter, a general introduction to free Ln ions is addressed, which includes the energy-level structures, selection rules of electronic transitions, site symmetry, as well as crystal-field theory for free Ln ions.

sections.heading: 1.1 Free Lanthanide Ions
sections.text:
In general, the term lanthanides (Ln) refers to a series of consecutive chemical elements in the periodic table from lanthanum to lutetium (atomic numbers ZD 57– 71), while the rare earths (RE) are commonly used for the lanthanides coupled with the elements scandium (ZD 21) and yttrium (ZD 39). Except scandium and yttrium, they have very similar electronic configurations for trivalent ions ([Xe]4f N), namely, all the trivalent Ln3C ions have unfilled electron shell structure 4f N (ND 1–14) (Table 1.1). Note that the most commonly studied valence state of the Ln or RE ions is the trivalent one in this book, when the terms Ln and RE are used; henceforth, we shall always mean the trivalent state, that is, Ln3C or RE3C, unless otherwise specified.
As shown in Table 1.1, the partially occupied 4f N electrons for these trivalent Ln3C ions are not in the outer shell and are efficiently shielded by the filled 5s and 5p electron shells, the ligand and/or crystal-field (CF) environment thereby has only a weak influence on the electronic cloud of Ln ions even in solid materials. Although weak, this weak influence can be treated as a perturbation known as the CF interaction, which is mainly responsible for the fine spectral structure of Ln3C ions [1, 2]. For the electronic [Xe]4f N configurations of Ln3C ions, they indeed generate

Due to the shielding of the filled 5s25p6 subshells, the electronic transitions between these 4f N states (levels) are very sharp and have features resembling those of free ion. In particular, they do not vary much with the chemical environments in which the Ln3C ions are inserted. As compared in Table 1.2, the lower energy levels of 4f 11 configuration of Er3C ions in free state [4] and in five kinds of host crystals including LaF3 [4], LaCl3 [5], CsLu2Cl9 [6], Y2O3 [4], and Y3Al5O12 [7], the energy differences for a given level in different materials are generally less than 100 cm 1, only in few cases are about 200 cm 1. sections.heading: 1.2 Energy-Level Structures of Free Lanthanide Ions
sections.text:
A major outcome from the electronic spectra of Ln3C ions is the assignment of the 4f N energy levels, which is of particularly useful for their applications in diverse fields such as lasers and phosphors. For multi-electron free (gaseous) Ln3C ions, the energy levels of each electronic configuration will be split into a series of energy levels, owing to the interaction between the electron orbital magnetic moment and the spin magnetic moment. These states can be described under the Russell–Saunders coupling scheme by the multiplet 2SC1LJ that is composed of (2SC 1)(2LC 1) states, where S and L denote the total electron spin and orbital angular momenta, respectively [3]. The values of LD 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 are used to be designated by the letters S, P, D, F, G, H, I, K, L in spectroscopy. Due to the coupling of the orbital angular momentum and the spin angular momentum in quantum mechanics, these multiplets 2SC1L are usually composed of total 2J C1 possible microstates, where J is the total (i.e., vector sum of S and L) angular momenta.
When it comes to the coupling scheme of the orbital angular momentum and the spin angular momentum, hitherto, there are four models of coupling in the atomic spectroscopy theory, that is, LS coupling (Russell–Saunders coupling), jj coupling, pair coupling (Racah coupling), and intermediate coupling [3]. Among these four coupling schemes, LS coupling is the most commonly used coupling scheme for Ln3C ions, in view of their much stronger electrostatic interaction between different 4f electrons relative to their spin–orbit interaction. In this model, the spin momenta si and orbital momenta li of all the electrons are first coupled by exchange interaction to form a total spin and orbital angular momenta S and L, respectively, and then the total spin angular momentum S couples with the total orbital angular momentum L into the total angular momentum J. According to this coupling scheme, the possible microstates can be designated by 2SC1LJ . For example, for 4f 1 configuration of Ce3C, there are two multiplets, that is, 2F5/2 and 2F7/2, where SD 1/2, LD 3, and JD 5/2 or 7/2. For 4f 3 configuration of Nd3C, there exist a series of states having quantum numbers SD 3/2, LD 6, and JD 9/2, 11/2, 13/2, and 15/2, which correspond to the multiplets of 4I9/2, 4I11/2, 4I13/2, and 4I15/2, respectively. For 4f N configurations of other Ln3C ions, the allowed spectroscopic multiplets or terms were collected and listed in Table 1.3.
In Table 1.3, the 2SC1Ln means that the terms of L appear n times and the J values corresponding to the different possible states (or energy levels) are not shown, which can be easily obtained from L and S as follows: JDL S, L SC 1, : : : , LC S 1, LC S. When the number of 4f electrons is large, it should be noted that three quantum numbers LSJ are inadequate to classify different states completely. The states with the same LSJ number can appear up to ten times as exemplified by 2GJ multiplets of Gd3C (Table 1.3). In order to completely classify the states in a 4f N configuration, an additional quantum number ¤, called the seniority number, is needed for distinguishing the states that have the same L and S quantum numbers. Besides, it is worthy of pointing out that some qualitative rules are very helpful to understand the energy-level structures of Ln3C ions in Fig. 1.1 [3]. One of the wellknown qualitative rules is Hund’s rule, which has the following guidelines: (1) the terms (or states) with the largest S values have the lowest energy values among all the terms of an electron configuration. Among these terms, those with the highest L values have the lowest energy values; (2) for the terms in configuration with a number of electrons equal or exceeding that of the half-filled shell, the larger the J value, the lower the energy. On the other hand, if the number of electrons lower than that of half-filled shell, then the smaller the J values, the lower the energy.
On the basis of the above qualitative rule, one can readily determine which multiplet is the ground state of a 4f N configuration of Ln3C ions. Taking trivalent Nd3C ions, for example, we know that the 4f 3 electron configuration of Nd3C belongs to the case of an electron number lower than that of a half-filled shell. The total spin angular momentum S for these three electrons is 3/2 in maximum, and the maximum orbital angular momentum L is 6. According to second guideline of Hund’s rule, the energy of state with JD 6 3/2D 9/2 will be the lowest one. Therefore, the ground states of Nd3C should be 4I9/2. By contrast, the trivalent Er3C ions have 4f 11 electron configuration and have the same terms and states as those for the 4f 3 configuration. However, its electron number exceeds that of the halffilled shell and so the larger the J, the lower the energy. Then its ground state should be 4I15/2 (JD 6C 3/2). From the 4f N energy-level diagrams of trivalent Ln3C ions (Fig. 1.1), it can be seen that Hund’s rule is really available. If one considers the Gd3C ion as a center, the multiplets of any Ln3C ions in the left positions can be
6 1 A General Introduction to Lanthanide Ions
found in those of Ln3C ions in the corresponding right positions. Nevertheless, for the same term, the lower multiplets in the left will be the higher multiplets in the right. Furthermore, it should also be noted that the energy separations between different terms and different multiples in the same term are larger for Ln3C ions in the right of Gd3C ion. This phenomenon is induced by the fact that the Coulomb interaction between electrons and the spin–orbital interaction are stronger for the right part of rare earth ions due to radius reduction of lanthanide contraction and the fact that the spin–orbital coupling is proportional to Z4.

Fortunately, just like many other problems in quantum mechanics, the problem can be simplified by neglecting some less important interactions in a good enough approximation. Among these, the central field approximation is one of the most important. The atoms can be treated as N electrons, with mass me and charge e, moving around a nucleus with infinite mass and charge of Z. The 4f electrons have very localized states that are conventionally described within the framework of CF theory [1]. sections.heading: 1.4 Radiative Transition: Selection Rules
sections.text:
Selection rules tell us whether a radiative transition such as the well-known electric dipole (ED), induced ED, magnetic dipole (MD), and electric quadrupole (EQ) transitions is potentially allowed or forbidden. In principle, a transition between a CF level i of the initial state and a CF level f of the final state is allowed if the matrix element h ijOj f i is nonzero. Herein, O stands for the ED, MD, and EQ operators, and h ijOj f i is identical to the integral of R i O f d . According to this principle, the selection rules for the most commonly ED, MD, and EQ transitions will be introduced in this section according to the group theory.
12 1 A General Introduction to Lanthanide Ions

sections.heading: 1.4.1 Selection Rules for Radiative Transitions of Free
sections.text:
Based on the group theory, the transition matrix elements should not be changed in a symmetry transformation, and they must belong to the identity representation. The total angular momentum quantum number J is a good quantum number for free Ln3C ions. As we all know, the initial state i belongs to a representation DJi and the final state f belongs to a representation DJf of the full rotational group [3]. As for the ED transition of Ln3C ions, the ED operator OED transforms like x, y, z and thus is an operator belonging to D1. The matrix element h ijOj f i will not vanish if the direct product DJi ˝DJ contains the representation DJf . It is easy to obtain that DJi ˝ D1 D DJiC1 ˚ DJi ˚ DJi 1. Therefore, the selection rule for ED transitions is JD 0,˙1. It should be pointed out that when JiD 0, Jf can only be 1, and the JiD 0! Jf D 0 transition is forbidden. On the other hand, the parity of final state should be different from that of the initial state, because the parity of electric dipole is odd. In the case of weak spin–orbit coupling, Russell–Saunders approximation is good enough, and so L and S are good quantum numbers. In this case, the ED moment operator belongs to representation D1 (LD 1, SD 0), and the initial state belongs toDLi˝DS , but the final state belongs toDLf˝DS . Obviously, we have the following selection rules: SD 0, LD 0, ˙1, and JD 0, ˙1; the parity should be changed in the transition, but JiD 0! Jf D 0, LiD 0!Lf D 0 is forbidden (Table 1.6).
As for the MD transitions, the MD operator OMD transforms like Rx, Ry, and Rz, which belongs to D1g representation (having even parity). One can thus obtain their selection rules by using the same method: JD 0, ˙1; the parity should not be changed in the transition, but JiD 0! Jf D 0 is forbidden. When Russell– Saunders approximation is reasonable, we have the following selection rules:
1.4 Radiative Transition: Selection Rules 13
SD 0, LD 0, and JD 0,˙1; the parity should not be changed in the transition, but LiD 0!Lf D 0 is forbidden (Table 1.6).
For the EQ transition, the EQ moment is a second-order tensor belonging to representation D2g. According to tables of representation product, one thereby has the selection rules as follows: JD 0, ˙1, ˙2; the parity should not be changed in the transition, but JiD 0! Jf D 0 and JiD 1! Jf D 0 are forbidden. When taking Russell–Saunders coupling scheme into account, the selection rules for an EQ transition should be changed to SD 0, LD 0, ˙1, ˙2; the parity should not be changed in the transition, but LiD 0!Lf D 0 and LiD 1!Lf D 0 are forbidden (Table 1.6).

sections.heading: 1.4.2 Selection Rules for Radiative Transitions of Lanthanide Ions Doped in Solid Materials
sections.text:
For Ln3C ions embedded in solid materials, J, L, and S of the Ln3C ions are not really good quantum numbers due to the CF effect. The actual good quantum numbers are the symmetry irreducible representations (irreps) of Ln3C ion. Therefore, the transition selection rules should be those involving their irreps. Assume that i, f , and O have the respective irreps i, f , and o. The matrix element h ijOj f i will not vanish if the direct product i˝ o˝ f contains the totally symmetric irrep 1; in other words, the representation o has to be contained in the direct product i˝ f . Since the irreps ED and MD transform as Cartesian vectors (x,y,z) and rotations (Rx,Ry,Rz) in the relevant point group and 1 is the totally symmetric irrep, the radiative transition selection rules can be introduced easily by applying the tables of the irrep product as has been well tabulated by Luo et al. [3].
Strictly speaking, the ED transitions between 4f N configurations (4f N!4f N) with the same parity are forbidden for free Ln3C ions; nevertheless, this forbidden rule can be partly broken by the odd parity CF perturbation after the embedding of Ln3C ions into the lattice of solid materials, which is mainly induced by the odd parity CF terms or odd lattice vibrations that can mix 4f N configurations of opposite parity into the initial and/or final state wave functions. As a result, the ED transition between 4f N configurations with the same parity can be observed in solid materials if the point group of Ln3C site contains no inversion center, including C6v, C6, D6, D3h, D3, C3v, C3h, C3, D4, C4v, C4, S4, D2d, D2, C2v, C2, Cs, C1, O, Td, and T symmetry point groups [11]. This type of ED transition of Ln3C ions was termed as induced ED transition by Judd and Ofelt et al. The best-known induced ED transition is the 5D0–7F2 transition of Eu3C. Even though the CF interaction of Ln3C ions in solid materials is weak relative to their spin–orbit coupling, the quantum numbers J, L, and S can still be used to describe their energy levels, and the odd parity CF interaction plays an important role in the ED transition. Therefore, in this case, the selection rules for free ions will be invalid except that of SD 0. However, it can be shown that the following selection rules of induced ED transition
14 1 A General Introduction to Lanthanide Ions
are applicable, that is, lD˙1, SD 0, L 2l, J 2l (lD 3); the forbidden rule of JiD 0! Jf D 0 transition is generally valid except the special cases in which Judd–Ofelt parameter 0¤ 0 (Table 1.6). Furthermore, it should be noted that an ED transition allowed by SLJ selection rules will not be observed if it is forbidden by the site symmetry selection rules as discussed in the following. By contrast, without this kind of perturbation, the transitions between 4f N configurations with the same parity can only be of MD or EQ nature. This is the situation when Ln3C ions occupy a position possessing inversion center for the following symmetry point groups: Ci, S6, C2h, C4h, C6h, D3d, D2h, D4h, D6h, Oh, and Th [11].
When spin–orbit coupling is strong, the above selection rules on L and S cannot be used, but the selection rules related to the irreps of the site symmetry of the active ions are strictly applicable. The irrep D1 of the ED moment of the full rotational group can be reduced to irreps of site symmetry of active ions as D1DP i…i. If the final state is denoted by jJS f i and the initial state by jJS ii, then one can find the following selection rule: i˝P j…j f ; that is, the product of the irrep of the initial state with the irrep of the dipole moment operator contains the complex conjugate of the final state irrep. Based on this principle, the selection rules from Judd–Ofelt theory for crystallographic point groups are summarized by GorllerWalrand and Binnemans [11] and given in Appendix 1. From these tables, one can easily determine whether an ED and/or MD transition between two CF levels is allowed or forbidden and in which polarization directions (i.e., ˛, , and ) of a transition will be observed particularly for Ln3C ion-doped bulk crystal.

sections.heading: 2.1 Electronic Energy-Level Fitting of Lanthanide Ions
sections.text:
In principle, theoretical model for the energy levels of Ln3C in bulk materials is also applicable to Ln3C doped in nanomaterials. On placing a Ln3C ion in a dielectric nanoparticle, the electrostatic field produced by the crystalline environment will split the 2SC1LJ multiplet (or energy level) of a Ln3C ion up to several hundreds wave number (cm 1). The calculation of energy levels of Ln3C is usually made by fitting the observed energy levels to the parametrized and semiempirical Hamiltonian in Eq. 1.1 by least-squares fitting diagonalization. Once a set of experimental crystalfield (CF) energy levels of Ln3C occupying a single dopant site in given host are identified from the high-resolution photoluminescence (PL) and/or absorption spectra, the energy-level calculation and/or fitting can be performed using f - shell empirical program suite, which enables a complete diagonalization without truncation of the 4f N wave functions.

Such a large volume of data at single site is essential for reliable parameterization of the effective operator Hamiltonian for the 4f 6 configuration, since any incorrect assignment of the observed energy levels can result in discrepancies between the calculated energy levels and the observed ones. Subsequently, the obtained energy levels were analyzed by means of the parameterization of an effective operator Hamiltonian including 20 freely varied free-ion (FI) and CF parameters for Eu3C ion at the C2 site, as shown in Eq. 2.1:

The FI parameters of LaF3:Eu3C [2] and CF parameters of Y2O3:Eu3C [3] were used as starting values. Theoretically, the 4f 6 configuration of Eu3C comprises 295 multiplets and 3,003 electronic states. So it is necessary to truncate the wave functions of the levels below 50,000 cm 1 for a fast fit. sections.heading: 2.2.1 Radiative and Nonradiative Relaxation

sections.heading: 2.2.2 Modification of Radiative and Nonradiative Lifetime
sections.text:
In nanoscale systems, there are many factors that may affect the radiative and nonradiative relaxation rates and thus luminescence lifetimes of emitters. It was reported that, in some nanocrystalline systems such as cubic Y2O3:Eu3C [12], and Gd2O3:Eu3C [13] prepared by combustion synthesis, the luminescence lifetimes of the doped lanthanide ions were observed to decrease with decreasing particle size, which was mainly attributed to the increase of the nonradiative relaxation rate. The increase in surface-to-volume ratio in tripositive lanthanide-doped nanomaterials will produce a large number of surface defect states, which may act as nonradiative relaxation channels (traps or killer). However, unusually longer radiative lifetimes of Ln3C ions in nanomaterials can also be observed in comparison with their bulk
26 2 Size Effect on the Luminescence of Lanthanide Ions in Nanoparticles
counterparts [14–17]. For example, we found that the lifetime of 5D0 state of Eu3C (2.01 ms) in Gd2O3:Eu3C nanotubes was unusually longer than that of bulk counterparts (0.9 ms) [1, 15].
There exist three factors that may result in a longer radiative lifetime of 5D0 of Eu3C in NPs as follows [18]: (1) the nonsolid medium surrounding the NPs that changes the effective index of refraction; (2) size-dependent spontaneous emission rate increases with a factor up to three times; and (3) increased lattice constant which reduces the odd CF component. To investigate the influence of the surrounding environment on the luminescence dynamics of lanthanides in NPs, Schmechel and co-workers [19] characterized and compared the Eu3C (5D0) luminescence lifetime in NPs with different size dispersed in air or aqueous solution and inside different caging hosts such as porous MCM-41, porous silica, and porous alumina (Fig. 2.1). As shown in Fig. 2.1, the lifetime of Eu3C doped in all NPs was found to be much larger when compared to the reference bulk powder (1.1 ms). A general trend can be also gathered from Fig. 2.1, namely, the smaller nanocrystals or pores, the longer lifetime observed. Specifically, for the 5-nm NPs in air, the lifetime is found to be up to three times longer than the bulk counterpart, reaching a value of 3.8 ms. Note that the strong drop of lifetime in aqueous solution compared to NPs in air is due to the increased nonradiative decay processes involving the vibrational modes of the water molecules at the surface. Combined with their structural characterization, Schmechel et al. assumed that increased radiative lifetime may be due to the increased lattice constant in the nanocrystalline samples which thus reduces the odd
crystal-field components. However, it is worthy of pointing out that Schmechel et al. ignored another very important contribution to lifetime lengthening; that is, they did not take into account the correction of effective refractive index as Meltzer et al. did [16]. In fact, the above lifetime behavior can be well elucidated by using the Meltzer’s method of “filling factor.”
As indicated in Eq. 2.2, spontaneous emission and radiative lifetime of lanthanide excited state in condensed phases is determined by the electromagnetic field and the index of refraction of the surrounding medium. Since the NPs occupy only a small fraction of the total volume, in order to compare the experimental results with Eq. 2.2, it is necessary to introduce an effective index of refraction for the medium (neff), which consists of the nanoparticles surrounded by the media with refractive index nmed. As for the lifetime behavior for Ln3C-doped NPs, however, one interesting question needed to be addressed is whether the lifetime for all excited states of Ln3C ions will be lengthened or not, as compared with their bulk counterparts. The answer is obviously “no” since the observed lifetime depends on both the radiative and nonradiative relaxation rates. Although the correction of effective refractive index in Eq. 2.6 may be applicable to all excited states of Ln3C ions, we would like to emphasize that it only affects the radiative lifetime. For example, in 2005, Chen et al. measured the luminescence lifetime of Eu3C ions in Y2O3–Al2O3 core–shell NPs ( 7-nm-thick nanolayer of cubic Y2O3 coating on Al2O3, with an average size of 60–70 nm) at 3.5, 77 K, and room temperature, respectively [27]. As expected, the lifetime of 5D0 of Eu3C, which is independent of temperature due to the very large energy gap between 5D0 and 7F6, was found to be unusually longer than that of the bulk counterparts (0.86 ms), owing to the nonsolid medium surrounding the NPs that changes the effective index of refraction, thus modifying the radiative lifetime. The filling factor, showing which fraction of space is occupied by Y2O3:Eu3C nanocoating particles, was estimated to be approximately 72 % by utilizing Eq. 2.6. By contrast, the 5D1 lifetime was observed to be very sensitive to temperature in view of the much smaller energy gap between 5D1 and 5D0. When the temperature varied from 3.5 to 295 K, the 5D1 lifetime for NPs was significantly shortened from 68 to 13 s. More importantly, as shown in Fig. 2.4, the 5D1 lifetime at a specific temperature was much shorter for the NPs than observed in the bulk counterparts, which differs markedly from that of the case of 5D0 state of Eu3C due to the surface effects or cross relaxation. The surface defects of the nanocoating particles act as the nonradiative transition channels, leading to the increase of nonradiative relaxation rates for 5D1! 5D0 and thus the shortened lifetime of 5D1 state. Such shortening of the 5D1 lifetime was also observed in YAlO3:Eu3C NPs. The lifetime of 5D0 at 3.5 K (1.64 ms) was longer than the value for the bulk counterpart (1.5 ms), which corresponded to a filling factor of 94 %, but the 5D1 lifetime (45 s) was much shorter than the value for the bulk (65 s) in spite of the lower measurement temperature.
For other Ln3C ions doped in inorganic NPs, the lifetime behavior may be more complicated. For instance, it was found for Er3C doped in 50-nm Lu2O3 NPs that the decay times of the 4S3/2 and 4F9/2 levels are longer with respect to the bulk sample following upconversion excitation at 980 nm, but shorter with respect to the bulk following direct excitation at 488 nm [28]. This complicated luminescence
dynamics may result from the competition between two processes: one is the multiphonon relaxation in nanocrystals owing to the presence of contaminants (such as CO2 and H2O) on their surface which increases the nonradiative decay rate; the other is aforementioned change in the effective refractive index in NPs plus the feeding from longer-lived states under upconversion excitation which reduces the radiative rate. For direct pumping, the former prevails over the latter, while the latter is obviously predominant for upconversion pumping.

sections.heading: 2.2.3 Modification of Phonon Density of States
sections.text:
Even though no quantum confinement should occur in the electronic energy-level structure of lanthanide ions because of the localized 4f electronic states, the optical spectrum and luminescence dynamics for lanthanide ion in dielectric NPs can be significantly modified through electron–phonon interaction. Confinement effects on electron–phonon interaction are primarily due to the effect that the phonon density of states (PDOS) in an NP is discrete, and, therefore, the low-energy acoustic phonon modes are cut off. As a consequence of the PDOS modification, the luminescence dynamics for lanthanides doped in NPs, particularly, the nonradiative relaxation of ions from the electronically excited states, are expected to differ markedly from that observed in their bulk counterparts.
The most essential property of acoustic vibrations in an NP is the existence of minimum size-quantized frequencies corresponding to acoustic resonances of the particle. In dielectric NPs, the Debye model is not valid for evaluation of the PDOS if the radius of the NP is less than 10 nm. The vibrational modes of a finite sphere were analyzed previously by Tamura et al. [29]. A stress-free boundary condition at the surface and a finiteness condition on both elastic displacements and stresses at
the center are assumed. These boundary conditions yield the spheroidal modes and torsional modes, determined by the following eigenvalue equations:

sections.heading: 2.2.4 Line Broadening and Shifts
sections.text:
One of the direct consequences of ion–phonon interaction is the broadening of the line widths of electronic transitions. This temperature-dependent process is called homogeneous line broadening, whereas the structure defect and crystalline straininduced static variation in electronic energy levels and line broadening is named inhomogeneous broadening. In time domain, homogenous line broadening is a measurement of dephasing of coherence in the excited states, which is characterized by a dephasing time 2 given as 2D ( ) 1, where is the homogeneous line width. Along with line broadening, the lattice dynamics characterized by electron– phonon interaction leads to temperature-dependent line shift of the electronic transitions. The contributions to homogeneous line broadening and shift generally come from direct one-phonon and multiphonon processes including Raman phonon scattering. Theoretically, the temperature-dependent line width and line shifts (ıE) associated with the two levels of an electronic transition can be, respectively, expressed by the McCumber–Sturge equations as follows [31]:

In crystals for which the defect-induced inhomogeneous line broadening is dominant, the homogeneous broadening caused by electron–phonon interaction

may be determined by nonlinear spectroscopic methods such as hole burning in frequency domain and photon echoes in time domain experiments. A very narrow excitation source (e.g., from a laser) is used in hole burning to excite a selected site causing saturation or photobleaching, so that this site does not absorb anymore. Consequently, a hole appears in the inhomogeneously broadened line shape of the transition. The hole width is limited by the homogeneous broadening. Because of the pumping and probing processes, the hole width is twice the homogeneous line width [32].
So far the principles and theoretical models that we have discussed for the excited state dynamics including line shifts and broadening were developed originally for ions in bulk solids. Although the 4f electronic states are localized and exhibit little quantum confinement, the dynamics of electronic transitions may be subjected to quantum confinement arising from electron–phonon interactions. Modification of the existing theoretical models is required for their applications to lanthanides in nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 2.2.5 Anomalous Thermalization
sections.text:
As discussed above, the optical spectrum and luminescence dynamics of a Ln3C ion in dielectric NPs can be significantly modified via electron–phonon interaction. As a result of confinement on PDOS, the luminescence dynamics of optical centers in NPs, particularly, the nonradiative relaxation of Ln3C ions from the electronically excited states, are expected to behave differently from that in bulk materials. For example, we recently observed anomalous thermalization phenomena in 20-nm Er3C-doped Y2O2S NPs at low temperature [33]. It is well known that the population of the Ln3C ions doped in the host materials among the energy levels should obey the Boltzmann distribution characterized by the Boltzmann factor. For the ith level, the population of bi can be written as:
bi D gi exp . Ei=kBT /X j gj exp Ej=kBT (2.14)
where kB is the Boltzmann constant, gi is the degeneracy of the ith level, and Ei is its energy. Thereby, at low temperature (T < 4.2 K), one should only observe the emission or absorption lines from the lowest sublevel of the initial multiplet on which most ions populate, providing that the energy difference between the lowest level and the nearest upper level is much larger than kBT. Nevertheless, we found an “anomaly” during the investigation of optical properties of Er3C-doped Y2O2S NPs [33]. As shown in the low-temperature excitation spectra of Er3C in bulk Y2O2S crystals and NPs in Fig. 2.6, hot bands originating from the upper Stark levels of 4I15/2 with an energy gap up to 224 cm 1 are observed in the excitation spectrum at 2.6 K. Moreover, it was observed that the intensity of the hot bands centered
34 2 Size Effect on the Luminescence of Lanthanide Ions in Nanoparticles
at 492.3 and 492.9 nm reached a minimum and the intensity of the normal line reached a maximum at 7.6 K (Fig. 2.6). The intensity of the hot band sharply increased and saturated as the sample temperatures decrease from 7.6 to 2.2 K. These anomalous phenomena obviously rule out the possibility that the sample is at an elevated temperature, since the above unusual thermalization was not observed in the bulk counterparts (400-nm Y2O2S:Er3C crystal) under otherwise identical experimental conditions.
Particularly, such unusual thermalization phenomena took place not only in the excitation spectrum of 4I15/2! 4F7/2 transition of Er3C but also in the emission spectrum from 4S3/2 state at low temperature (3 K). As compared in Fig. 2.7, upon 491.8-nm laser excitation, three normal emission lines arising from the lowest sublevel of 4S3/2 (a) to the three sublevels of 4I15/2 (1,2,3) were detected for the bulk Y2O2S:Er3C sample, since the Boltzmann factor of the upper Stark level (15 cm 1 above) is calculated to be only 0.08 %. By contrast, three new peaks marked as b! 1,2,3 were also observed in Y2O2S:Er3C NPs, which can be readily assigned to the hot bands from the upper sublevel of 4S3/2 (b) to the three sublevels of 4I15/2 (1,2,3) [34]. Additional evidence of such anomalous thermalization phenomena can be also found in the luminescence dynamic behavior of Er3C in bulk Y2O2S crystals and NPs. The luminescence decay from the upper level of 4S3/2 (b) was measured to
be as long as 3.29 s at 4 K, which was nearly identical to that of the lower level, 4S3/2 (a). However, the decay from 4S3/2 (b) cannot be observed in bulk samples due to the rapid direct phonon relaxation process. The unusual long lifetime of 4S3/2 (b) in NPs indicates that the ions excited by the pump laser can be efficiently maintained in the upper level 4S3/2 (b) even at low temperature, which matches well the appearance of hot bands in the emission spectrum.
To better understand the mechanism of anomalous thermalization in Y2O2S:Er3C NPs, the temperature and power dependence of the excitation intensity in the excitation spectra was also quantitatively studied. Integrated intensities of excitation spectra at 491.8 and 492.9 nm versus temperature (from 2.2 to 66 K) are shown in Fig. 2.8, where each experimental point represents the integrated intensity of each main peak. The intensity of saturated hot bands in NPs decreases rapidly to zero as temperature increases from 6 to 8 K and then increases with temperature reflecting Boltzmann thermalization behavior. The NPs and the bulk crystals exhibit the same thermodynamics above 12 K. The anomaly was still observable at very low pump intensity (5 kW/cm2), indicating that the Er3C population in the ground state can be remarkably depleted by the laser pulse at a peak intensity less than 5 kW/cm2. The power dependences of the integrated intensity of the three excitation peaks 4F7/2 (a) 4I15/2 (1,2,3) (491.8, 492.3, and 492.9 nm) in Y2O2S:Er3C NPs at 3 and 20 K were measured. As expected, the integrated intensity of each excitation peak is proportional to the pump intensity at 20 K, by contrast, the hot bands at 492.3 and 492.9 nm exhibit a nonlinear dependence on the pump intensity at 3 K. At pump intensity lower than 11 kW/cm2, the pump power exponent can be approximately fitted to 1.4 for excitation at 492.9 nm and 1.2 for excitation at 492.3 nm, respectively. The luminescence intensity upon laser excitation at 491.8 nm showed tendency to saturate with increasing pump power, and the exponent was fitted to 0.88.

One question concerning the effect of surface defects still needs to be addressed, that is, how the initially empty upper crystal-field levels of 4I15/2 can be populated at thermal energy far below the energy gaps of the electronic states (up to 200 cm 1). In NPs, the influence of lattice defects and contamination of hydrous species in the considerably large area of the surface layer is not negligible. It will somewhat induce inhomogeneous broadening like the case in glasses. In the absence of selective excitation and luminescence line narrowing, the 4f spectra of NPs should correspond to a sum of optical emissions contributed from emitters at the surface and in the interior of the particles. The latter should have unperturbed crystalline lattice environment. As shown in Fig. 2.6, the spectrum indicates that the hot bands originating from the upper crystal-field levels overlap “accidentally” with the excitation bands of some defect sites from the lowest level in the ground state. Therefore, when the laser was tuned to induce a resonant transition apparently from an upper level of the ground state which was initially empty at liquid helium temperature, it actually pumped the Er3C ions at defect sites from the ground level.
2.2 Confinement on Luminescence Dynamics 37
Through energy transfer and cascade emission of phonons, which occur efficiently in less than 5 ns after the laser pulse, the relaxation of an excited Er3C ion at a defect site may result in populating more than one Er3C ions in the upper levels of the ground state. This describes how an empty level can be populated at low temperature. Then, the Er3C ions in these upper levels can be excited by the same laser pulses, and depending on the rate of nonradiative phonon relaxation of ions in the upper levels, observation of hot bands is possible. This effect is similar to a photon avalanche except that a threshold is not observed.
A possible thermalization mechanism was proposed, and a simple model based on the rate-equation approach was established to interpret the above phenomena. The equilibrium population in the upper levels of the 4I15/2 ground state results from the competition mainly between the laser-induced thermalization through nonradiative relaxation in the excited states (populating) and two-phonon Raman process (depopulating). Calculated results are in agreement with the observations. In brief, the anomalous thermalization effect in NPs, which is not observed in the bulk counterparts, can be interpreted within the existing theory by taking into account the facts that the low-frequency phonons are scarce and electronic levels of hot bands can be efficiently populated via laser-induced multiphonon relaxation from the excited states.
Such anomalous thermalization effect due to absence of low-frequency phonon modes in NPs discussed above can also occur in other systems. Observation of this effect depends on the energy-level structure of the luminescent centers as well as on the sample temperature and crystal size. According to the temperature-dependent multiphonon relaxation rate and the relationship between the cutoff frequency and crystal size, anomalous hot bands from the excited states with higher energies will occur in crystals with smaller size. More recently, we observed the similar anomalous thermalization phenomenon in Gd2O3:Eu3C nanotubes at 10 K (Fig. 2.9) [15]. According to the Boltzmann distribution of Eu3C population, Eu3C ions should populate only the lowest-level 7F0 at 10 K in Gd2O3:Eu3C nanotubes, and no population should be accumulated at 7F1 due to the very fast phonon relaxation to the ground state and their small energy gap (217 cm 1). Hence, under normal conditions, the excitation spectra are expected to be exactly like that of the bulk sample without excitation peaks arising from the level 7F1 at 10 K, wherein only three excitation peaks assigned to the 7F0! 5D1 transition of Eu3C were detected. However, as clearly depicted in Fig. 2.9, two abnormal hot bands assigned to the transitions from the lowest level of F1 to the two sublevels of 5D1 (18,944 and 18,962 cm 1) were observed in the excitation spectrum of Eu3C at C2 site symmetry, which is mainly due to the restricted phonon relaxation in nanotubes, as had been well elucidated in Y2O2S:Er3C NPs [33].
Moreover, it should be noted that the temperature-dependent intensity of hot bands in Gd2O3:Eu3C nanotubes behaved very differently from that in Y2O2S:Er3C NPs, where the hot bands almost disappeared at 8 K but increased rapidly until saturation was reached as temperature decreased below 8 K. By contrast, the integrated intensity of hot bands for Gd2O3:Eu3C nanotubes hardly changed below

sections.heading: 2.2.6 Energy Transfer and Migration
sections.text:
As a result of ion–ion interactions, electronic excitation of Ln3C ions in host materials may undergo migration through resonant energy transfer and phononassisted energy transfer processes [9, 36, 37]. In a classical resonant energy transfer process, the donor (ion A) deactivates from its excited state E0A to its ground state GA and thereby excites the acceptor (ion B) from its ground state to GB to its excited state E0B. That is to say, in this process the transition of E0A!GA should have the exactly same energy with the transition of GB!E0B. By contrast, considerable mismatch in energy between the acceptor and the donor is allowable due to the phonon emission or absorption in the phonon-assisted energy transfer processes. Based on the above analysis, the latter energy transfer process is more favorable because Ln3C ions embedded in the lattice of diverse host materials do not have exactly the same energy level in an excited state due to lattice stress and defects. As a result, the line widths of electronic transitions are inhomogeneously broadened, and resonant energy transfer becomes improbable. For excitation migration among the ions with different energy levels due to defect-induced inhomogeneous broadening, the energy mismatch between a donor and an acceptor can be made up by lattice phonons. The energy-level variation or inhomogeneous broadening is generally more significant in nanostructures than that in bulk crystals. As discussed above, the density of phonon states becomes discrete and low-frequency phonon modes are absent below a cutoff energy, Ecut. Energy transfer does not occur when the energy difference between a donor and an acceptor is below Ecut. Because of the restrictions of PDOS in NPs, one expects that both luminescence lifetime and the efficiency of energy transfer will be modified when compared with their bulk counterparts [30].
Based on the classical Förster–Dexter model of interionic interaction-induced energy transfer, the excitation probability of ion i can be expressed as [9, 38, 39]:

sections.heading: 3.1 Synthesis of Lanthanide-Doped Core-Only Nanoparticles
sections.text: The development of facile synthetic strategies toward high-quality trivalent lanthanide (Ln3C)-doped luminescent NPs with controlled crystalline phases, shapes, and sizes is crucial to tuning their physicochemical properties and exploring their potential bioapplications in diverse fields. Hitherto, a large variety of chemical synthetic approaches such as thermal decomposition, high-temperature coprecipitation, hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis, sol–gel procedure, cation exchange, and ionic liquid-based synthesis have been proposed to synthesize high-quality lanthanidedoped luminescent NPs. As summarized in Table 3.1, thermal decomposition, high-temperature coprecipitation, and hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis are nowadays the three most representative routes to the synthesis of high-quality Ln3C-doped luminescent core-only and core–shell NPs of various compositions among those methods ever reported.

organic solvent such as oleic acid (OA), oleylamine (OM), tri-n-octylphosphine oxide (TOPO), and 1-octadecene (ODE). By carefully tailoring the experimental variables like nature of solvents, concentration of metal precursors, reaction temperature and time, high-quality NPs with narrow size distribution, good crystallinity, and exceptional optical properties can be readily obtained from the thermal decomposition process. One of the earliest examples of this approach was demonstrated by Yan and co-workers, who synthesized highly monodisperse LaF3 triangular nanoplates via the thermal decomposition of the metal trifluoroacetate (La(CF3COO)3) in the presence of OA and ODE mixture solution [36]. OA, possessing good coordinating abilities, was used as capping surfactant to stabilize NPs against agglomeration, while ODE with a high boiling point (315 ıC) served as non-coordinating solvent to provide a high-temperature reaction environment. This method was later refined and extended as the most commonly used route to yield high-quality Ln3C-doped luminescent NPs of various compositions. To date, a series of monodisperse Ln3C-doped luminescent NPs based on diverse host materials such as LiYF4 [1, 2, 4, 37], NaYF4 [5, 6, 38–43], NaGdF4 [17, 44, 45], NaLuF4 [25], BaYF5 [32, 46], KY3F10 [47], BaGdF5 [29], CaF2 [48, 49], SrF2 [48, 49], BaF2 [49], YOF [50], LuOF [51], LaOF [52], and GdOF [51, 52] have been achieved through this method. For example, Capobianco and co-workers reported the synthesis of monodisperse Yb/Er or Yb/Tm co-doped NaYF4 NPs with a remarkably narrow size distribution [38, 39]. Subsequently, they extended this synthetic route for the synthesis of monodisperse Ln3C-doped LiYF4 [1, 2], NaGdF4 [17, 53], KY3F10 [47], and BaYF5 [32] NPs. Another outstanding demonstration was reported by Murray and co-workers, who prepared highly uniform hexagonal NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs with controlled sizes and morphologies by using the same synthetic strategy [54]. By manipulating the reaction time and the ratio of sodium to lanthanide trifluoroacetates dissolved in the mixture solution of OA and ODE, the as-prepared NaYF4 NPs can be rationally tuned in morphologies from spherical NPs to nanorods, hexagonal nanoprisms, and nanoplates (Fig. 3.1 a–i). More importantly, these as-prepared NPs can be easily assembled into large-area superlattices under appropriate conditions (Fig. 3.1 j and k). Alternatively, Chow et al. synthesized monodisperse hexagonalphase NaYF4:Yb/Er (or Tm) NPs through thermal decomposition of sodium and lanthanide trifluoroacetates by using single solvent of OM, which served as reaction medium and capping ligand [5]. Although the thermal decomposition approach enables the preparation of high-quality Ln3C-doped luminescent NPs, one should keep in mind that its requirements of expensive, air-sensitive, and highly toxic Ln3C trifluoroacetate precursors along with the generation of some deleterious by-products like HF will raise some safety concerns and thus somewhat limit its large-scale use in biotechnology and biomedical fields.

sections.heading: 3.1.2 High-Temperature Coprecipitation
sections.text:
High-temperature coprecipitation method is another well-developed synthetic strategy to fabricate uniform Ln3C-doped luminescent NPs. As compared to thermal
3.1 Synthesis of Lanthanide-Doped Core-Only Nanoparticles 47
decomposition method, this approach is expected to be more convenient and favorable in view of its relatively mild reaction conditions, low cost for required equipment, simple protocols, and short reaction time [55]. In one of their pioneering works, van Veggel and co-workers adopted the coprecipitation method to prepare luminescent LaF3 NPs doped with emitters of Ln3C (LnDEu, Er, Nd, and Ho) using ammonium di-n-octadecyldithiophosphate as surfactant in mild experimental conditions [10]. Yi et al. reported the synthesis of cubic-phase NaYF4:Yb3C/Er3C NPs by the coprecipitation method with the aid of ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) [8]. By adjusting the molar ratio of EDTA to total Ln3C ions, nearly spherical NaYF4 NPs with diameters ranging from 37 to 166 nm were obtained. In another interesting report, Haase and co-workers also synthesized 5–30-nm cubicphase NaYF4:Yb3C/Er3C (or Tm3C) NPs in the presence of high-boiling solvent N-(2-hydroxyethyl)ethylenediamine (HEEDA). Although Ln3C-doped luminescent
48 3 Controlled Synthesis of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
NPs were successfully synthesized in the above pioneering work, unfortunately, most of NPs obtained above often suffer from several drawbacks such as broad size distribution, ill-defined shapes, and low luminescent efficiency. By contrast, Zhang and co-workers recently developed a user-friendly method termed hightemperature coprecipitation for the synthesis of highly uniform hexagonal-phase NaYF4:Yb/Er/Tm NPs with controllable shapes, sizes, and intense UC luminescence (UCL), by using OA as capping ligand and ODE as solvent (Fig. 3.2a–c) [56]. This synthetic strategy was based on the formation of small amorphous NaYF4 coprecipitates at room temperature (RT) followed by the growth of NPs at elevated temperatures (300 ıC). Since then, this method has been extensively adopted by other research groups to prepare monodisperse Ln3C-doped LiYF4, NaYF4 [12, 57, 58], NaGdF4 [16, 59, 60], NaTbF4 [61], NaLuF4 [23], KGdF4 [27], NaScF4 [13], and CaF2 [34] NPs, to name a few. Specifically, monodisperse and uniform Ln3Cdoped luminescent NPs with ultrasmall size (<10 nm) can also be obtained through this method, as exemplified by Ln3C-doped CaF2 and NaGdF4 NPs synthesized in our group (Fig. 3.2d–f).

sections.heading: 3.1.3 Hydro(solvo)thermal Synthesis
sections.text:
Different from thermal decomposition and coprecipitation methods, the hydro(solvo) thermal synthesis is usually carried out within specialized reaction vessels defined as autoclaves that are used to provide a high-pressure and sealed environment and thus to promote reactions between solid precursors. As a result, this approach enables the synthesis of high crystalline nanomaterials under relatively mild conditions when compared to other synthetic routes. In a typical hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis procedure, some organic additives and/or surfactants with specific functional groups like OA [62], polyethylenimine (PEI) [63, 64], EDTA [31], and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) are generally added along with the reaction precursors to achieve simultaneous control over the crystalline phases, sizes, and morphologies as well as the surface functional groups for the resulting NPs. The most successful example for hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis was demonstrated by Li and co-workers, who proposed a general multiphase and the interface-controlled strategy to synthesize monodisperse NPs on the basis of liquid–solid–solution (LSS) phase transfer and separation mechanism occurring at the interfaces of the liquid, solid, and solution [65]. Using this method with slight modification, a variety of Ln3C-doped NPs featuring high crystallinity, dispersity, and well-controlled crystal phases, sizes, and shapes have been synthesized, such as NaYF4 [66–68], NaLuF4 [24, 26], BaGdF5 [30], YF3 [69], LaF3 [70, 71], LaOF [35, 72], GdF3 [73], CaF2 [74], SrF2 [75], BaF2 [76], and KMnF4 [77]. For example, Zhao and co-workers utilized a facile OA-mediated hydrothermal approach to prepare uniform Ln3C-doped NaYF4 with controlled nanorods, hexagonal nanotubes, and flower-patterned nanodisks [66]. Very recently, a more shining example of hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis was reported by Liu et al., who
3.1 Synthesis of Lanthanide-Doped Core-Only Nanoparticles 49
developed a novel Gd3C-doping approach to give simultaneous control over the crystal phase, size, and optical properties for the resulting NaYF4 NPs (Fig. 3.3a) [9]. It was discovered that the Gd3C doping at precisely defined concentrations can not only result in a rapid cubic-to-hexagonal-phase transformation within 2 h but also lead to a substantial decrease in a reaction temperature as low as 230 ıC for the formation of ultrasmall hexagonal NaYF4 NPs, which is inaccessible by other methods where high reaction temperatures (>300 ıC) as well as prolonged heating treatment procedure up to several days are often required. Such phase transformation and size and morphology optimization induced by impurity doping were further verified later by some other groups. Hao and co-workers reported the synthesis of NaLuF4:Gd/Yb/Tm NPs with controllable size and phase by doping different contents of Gd3C ions. The addition of Gd3C ions promoted the
50 3 Controlled Synthesis of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
phase transformation from cubic to hexagonal and reduced the particle size from large micro-tubes to small cubes. Wang and co-workers extended such impuritydoping strategy for the controlled synthesis of MF2 (MDCa, Sr, and Ba) and LnF3 (LnDLa, Ce, and Pr) NPs (Fig. 3.3b) [71, 75]. In addition to fluoride NPs aforementioned, by using the hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis, monodisperse Ln3C-doped inorganic oxide NPs can also be readily obtained as exemplified by ZrO2:Ln3C [78–80], ZnO:Ln3C [81, 82], Y2O3:Ln3C [83], Gd2O3:Ln3C [84–86], and TiO2:Ln3C NPs [87, 88].

sections.heading: 3.1.4 Other Approaches
sections.text:
While the thermal decomposition, high-temperature coprecipitation, and hydro (solvo)thermal syntheses are currently well established for the fabrication of
3.2 Synthesis of Lanthanide-Doped Core–Shell Nanoparticles 51
monodisperse NPs, quite a few groups have also attempted to develop other synthetic strategies like cation exchange, microwave-assisted synthesis, and ionic liquid (IL)-based synthesis to yield Ln3C-doped luminescent NPs with different compositions, shapes, and sizes. For instance, Cui and co-workers developed a general strategy that combines the advantages of thermal decomposition method [18, 19, 90], IL-based synthesis, and the liquid–liquid two-phase approach to synthesize highly uniform and monodisperse Ln3C-doped fluoride NPs through a novel OA/IL two-phase system. Oil-dispersible cubic-phase NaGdF4 NPs with ultrasmall size ( 5 nm) were obtained in OA phase via an IL-based reaction. Notably, water-soluble hexagonal-phase NaGdF4 NPs can also be obtained in the same system by adopting an extremely facile method to complete the dual phase transition (crystal-phase transition and OA-phase to IL-phase transition) simultaneously. By contrast, Mudring and co-workers reported another approach defined as microwave-assisted method for the fast and efficient synthesis of small, uniform, and oxygen-free GdF3:Eu3C NPs in the IL of [C4mim][BF4] (C4mimD 1- butyl-3-methylimidazolium) [21]. Van Veggel and co-workers developed a facile cation exchange reaction to prepare ultrasmall and monodisperse LaF3 NPs in mild experimental conditions [91].

sections.heading: 3.2 Synthesis of Lanthanide-Doped Core–Shell Nanoparticles
sections.text:
In addition to Ln3C-doped core-only NPs, much progress has also been made in the synthesis of composite NPs with core–shell structures in the past decade. Such composite core–shell NPs not only provide an excellent platform to combine different functional units into one single NP but also offer an effective solution to problems associated with the core-only NPs such as low PL efficiency. As schematically illustrated in Fig. 3.4, one of the most frequently used methods to fabricate core–shell NPs is the seed-mediated shell growth, namely, making core-only NPs as seed first followed by epitaxially growing a homogeneous or heterogeneous shell on the surface of these core NPs, thereby resulting in the formation of core–shell structured NPs. By adopting this strategy, Yi and Chow first prepared monodisperse “-NaYF4:Yb/Tm@NaYF4 core–shell NPs with an average diameter of 11.1 nm via the thermal decomposition of the corresponding metal trifluoroacetate precursors dissolved in hot OM solution (340 ıC) [92]. Zhang and co-workers synthesized uniform “-NaYF4:Yb/Tm@NaYF4:Yb/Er core–shell NPs with tunable UC emissions through high-temperature coprecipitation method [93]. Subsequently, this approach was refined and extended as a common route by the groups of van Veggel, Capobianco, and Prasad et al. to produce diverse core–shell NPs with various material combinations like NaYF4@CaF2 [43], NaYF4@NaGdF4 [94, 95], NaGdF4:Yb/Tm@NaGdF4:Tb [96], NaGdF4:Yb/Er@NaGdF4:Yb [17], NaGdF4:Nd@NaGdF4 [59], and KGdF4:Yb/Tm@KGdF4 [27] core–shell NPs. By virtue of the techniques including X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS),
52 3 Controlled Synthesis of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
high-angle annular dark field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM), and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) by electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) in line scan mode or in 2D elemental mapping mode, such core–shell structures can be well characterized along with the observation of a size increase from the TEM analysis. For example, with the aid of XPS, van Veggel and co-workers provided direct proof for the formation of NaYF4@NaGdF4 core–shell structure [94]. Recently, they offered more convincing evidence based on the HAADF-STEM technique coupled with EELS and X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) to analyze NaYF4@NaGdF4 core– shell structure [97]. Meanwhile, Zhang and co-workers proposed a reproducible successive ion layer adsorption and reaction method to grow hexagonal NaGdF4 shell on NaYF4:Yb/Er core NPs with monolayer control thickness and without introducing detrimental structural defects [95]. Furthermore, in combination with the cryo-transmission electron microscopy, rigorous EELS, and HAADF-STEM investigations under the low temperature, they acquired the first direct imaging of NaYF4:Yb/Er@NaGdF4 NPs with clear core–shell feature. A linear correlation between the NaGdF4 shell thickness and the optical properties of monodisperse hexagonal NaYF4:Yb/Er@NaGdF4 core–shell NPs was revealed, which is of great importance for researchers in an effort to achieve highly luminescent and stable core–shell NPs.
Even though monodisperse core–shell NPs with diverse compositions can be easily obtained by using the seed-mediated shell growth approach aforementioned,
References 53
the approach often suffers from some limitations like independent nucleation, anisotropic shell growth, and complicated separation and washing steps associated with multiple reactions. To circumvent these limitations, van Veggel and coworkers recently developed a more versatile epitaxial shell growth strategy based on a common physical phenomenon of Ostwald ripening (i.e., self-focusing by Ostwald ripening) to perform layer-by-layer shell growth directly onto a larger core NP (Fig. 3.4b) [98]. In their study, small ’-NaYF4 sacrificial NPs (SNPs) were synthesized at first and then used as shell precursors. The subsequent injection of SNPs into a hot solution of NaYF4 core NPs (defocusing) will induce the rapid dissolution of SNPs and their deposition onto the larger core NPs (self-focusing), thereby resulting in the formation of genuine core–shell-structured NPs with welldefined shape, narrow size distribution, and tunable shell growth. More importantly, the shell thickness and multiple layers of such core–shell NPs can be precisely controlled by manipulating the number of SNPs injected and/or repeating the above defocusing and self-focusing cycle. Furthermore, this method is flexible and can be easily extended to prepare other high-quality core–shell NPs with different compositions. For example, by using the sample synthetic strategy, recently we have also prepared monodisperse and uniform CaF2@CaF2 and NaGdF4@NaGdF4 core– shell NPs as shown in Fig. 3.2g–i.
Besides the self-focusing by Ostwald ripening strategy, another facile way to prepare monodisperse Ln3C-doped core–shell NPs is cation exchange reaction (Fig. 3.4c). One of the earliest examples of this technique was demonstrated by van Veggel and co-workers [91], who prepared GdF3@LnF3 core–shell NPs by exposing GdF3 core NPs to an aqueous solution containing excess Ln3C ions, where the Gd3C ions in GdF3 NPs were partially replaced by Ln3C in the solution. By refining this synthetic route, they synthesized multifunctional NaYF4:Yb/Tm@NaGdF4 core–shell NPs with tunable shell thickness and enhanced UCL and outstanding paramagnetic performance via cation exchange of NaYF4:Yb/Tm NPs with Gd3C ions, making these NPs promising for bimodal imaging, namely, optical bioimaging and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) [14]. Similarly, Liu and co-workers developed a novel approach based on rare-earth cation-assisted ligand assembly to synthesize Gd3C-modified NaYF4:Yb/Er core–shell NPs [99]. In their study, NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs were first synthesized via a modified cothermolysis process in oleylamine, then Gd3C ions were introduced on the surface of NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs by cation-assisted ligand assembly, which thereby greatly increased the positive charge onto the surface of NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs so that the functional molecules (i.e., folic acid and aminocaproic acid) can be attached.

sections.heading: 4.1 Surface Modification of Hydrophobic Nanoparticles
sections.text:
Because of the hydrophobic nature of capping ligands used such as OA and OM, most of synthetic approaches predominantly produce Ln3C-doped luminescent NPs with hydrophobic surfaces, which thereby make them dispersible in nonpolar organic solvents while insoluble in aqueous solution or biological buffers. The resulting insolubility of these NPs in water will greatly limit their biomedical applications in diverse fields such as drug delivery, biodetection, and bioimaging where the hydrophilicity is a prerequisite. As a consequence, one crucial issue facing the use of these hydrophobic Ln3C-doped luminescent NPs for bioapplications is the modification and functionalization of their surface, in an effort to render them water-soluble and provide reactive groups for subsequent bioconjugation to various biomolecules. To this end, a variety of surface modification strategies like ligand exchange, ligand oxidation, ligand-free synthesis, ligand attraction, electrostatic layer-by-layer assembly, and surface silanization have been designed to transfer NPs with hydrophobic surface into water over the past decade (Fig. 4.1) [1], as will be briefly overviewed in the following.
