59
60 4 Surface Modification Chemistry of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles

sections.heading: 4.1.1 Ligand Exchange
sections.text:
Ligand exchange is currently the most popular method to modify the surface of hydrophobic NPs without obviously affecting their shapes, compositions, and morphologies. In a typical ligand exchange procedure, the original capping hydrophobic ligand such as OA and OM anchored on the NP surface can be replaced with a new bifunctional organic molecules or polymers (Fig. 4.1). Such bifunctional organic molecules or polymers should have one functional group capable of binding to the NP surface tightly and another hydrophilic functional group at the other end so that the NPs can be well dispersed in water or can be further functionalized. Hitherto, a variety of organic molecules or polymers meeting this structural requirement have been investigated for the decoration of the NP surface with hydrophilic moieties, including poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) diacid [2], poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG)–phosphate [3–5], polyacrylic acid (PAA) [6–10], 3-mercaptopropionic acid [11], hexanedioic acid [12], 6-aminohexanoic acid (AA) [13], and 2-aminoethyl dihydrogen phosphate (AEP) [14, 15]. In their pioneering work, Yin and coworkers first demonstrated a robust and general ligand exchange procedure to transfer hydrophobic OA-capped inorganic NPs into water by using PAA as new capping ligand at an elevated temperature ( 240 ıC) [6]. Very recently, a more universal and versatile ligand exchange strategy that enables sequential surface functionalization of NPs was proposed by Dong and co-workers [16]. In their study, nitrosonium tetrafluoroborate (NOBF4) was used to replace the original organic ligands such as OA and OM attached to the NP surface at RT, thereby stabilizing the NPs in various polar media without aggregation or precipitation for years. More importantly, the hydrophilic NPs obtained above can be further
4.1 Surface Modification of Hydrophobic Nanoparticles 61
functionalized by employing different capping organic molecules to impart desired surface functionalization to NPs. Furthermore, this approach proves feasible to the synthesis of various types of NPs such as metal oxides, metals, semiconductors, and dielectrics regardless of their composition and morphology, as exemplified by amine-functionalized tetragonal ZrO2:Ln3C NPs recently prepared in our group [17]. However, it should be noted that such ligand exchange approach often yield water-soluble NPs at an expense of reduced PL efficiency of Ln3C, due to the quenching effect from the high-frequency vibrational groups such as -OH and -NH2 introduced in the ligand exchange procedure. For instance, we observed that the integrated UC luminescence intensity of AEP-capped KLaF4:Yb,Er NPs decreased to about one fifth of that observed in OA-capped counterparts after ligand exchange with AEP [14].

sections.heading: 4.1.2 Ligand Oxidation
sections.text: Ligand oxidation is primarily based on the oxidation of the unsaturated carbon– carbon double bonds of capping ligands such as OA into carboxylic acid groups to generate water-soluble Ln3C-doped luminescent NPs (Fig. 4.1). Using this technique, Li and co-workers first demonstrated the conversion of OA-capped NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs into water-soluble ones with preserved morphology, dispersity, and luminescence intensity via the Lemieux–von Rudloff reagent [18]. The resulting carboxylic groups on the NP surface not only imparted high solubility for these NPs in water but also allowed further conjugation with various biomolecules. This can be well validated by a recent work reported by Lin and co-workers [19], in which water-soluble and carboxyl-functionalized NaYF4:Yb/Tm NPs were initially oxidized by the Lemieux–von Rudloff oxidation method and then conjugated with hydrazine and doxorubicin (DOX) to fabricate an anticancer drug delivery system based on DOX-conjugated NaYF4:Yb/Tm NPs. By contrast, Yan and co-workers reported the oxidation of OA on the surface of NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs into the azelaic aldehyde or azelaic acid through ozonolysis [20]. Although the ligand oxidation approach turns out to be very simple and easily handled for surface modification of hydrophobic NPs, it is only applicable to a limited number of capping ligands containing unsaturated carbon–carbon double bonds.

sections.heading: 4.1.3 Ligand-Free Synthesis
sections.text:
Ligand-free synthesis was developed with the endeavor to completely remove the oleate ligand from the surface of OA-capped Ln3C-doped NPs by using a simple acid treatment process and/or excess ethanol treatment under ultrasonication to yield water-soluble NPs with naked surface Ln3C (Fig. 4.1). As a result of the strong coordination capability of naked surface Ln3C, the obtained ligand-free NPs are
62 4 Surface Modification Chemistry of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
capable of direct conjugation of hydrophilic and biocompatible molecules with electronegative groups such as –COOH, –NH2, and –OH in water solution for further bioapplications. For example, Xu and co-workers demonstrated that the surface OA ligand of NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs can be thoroughly released by washing with excess ethanol under vigorous ultrasonic treatment [21]. Recently, Capobianco and co-workers developed a facile approach based on acid–base reaction to modify OA-capped NaYF4:Yb/Er and NaGdF4:Yb/Er NPs, in which OA-capped NPs were treated with a HCl solution at pH 4 and then the oleate ligands were protonated. This would result in the release of OA from the NP surface, thereby yielding a positive charged ligand-free NPs for further bioconjugation with electronegative groups of biological molecules like heparin and basic fibroblast growth factor in an aqueous medium [22, 23]. Similarly, Liu and co-workers adopted this acid washing method for the synthesis of PEG-coated NaYF4:Yb/Er@NaGdF4 core–shell NPs for simultaneous nuclear imaging and intranuclear drug delivery after bioconjugation with TAT peptide [24].

sections.heading: 4.1.4 Ligand Attraction
sections.text:
The approach of ligand attraction mainly makes use of hydrophobic–hydrophobic van der Waals interactions between the well-chosen amphiphilic polymers and original hydrophobic ligand to realize the successful conversion of hydrophobic Ln3C-doped NPs into water-soluble ones. In this process, the hydrophobic portion of amphiphilic polymers interacts with the organic capping layer of the NPs via hydrophobic attraction, while the hydrophilic portion faces outward, interacting with the aqueous solvent and rendering the particle water soluble (Fig. 4.1). Note that the coating amphiphilic molecules do not directly interact with the NP surface. This method is expected to produce exceptionally stable watersoluble NPs with preserved optical properties. Presently, the most commonly used amphiphilic polymers in this approach include OA–PAA–PEG [25], poly(maleic anhydride-alt-1-octadecene) [26], poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(carprolactone) [27], poly((ethylene glycol)-block-lactic acid) [27], 6-aminohexanoic acid [28], PAA [29], and poly(L-lysine) [30]. For example, by using the octylamine- and isoprolylamine-modified PAA as coating polymers, Chow and co-workers successfully modified the surface of NaYF4:Yb/Er@NaYF4 core–shell NPs with desirable carboxylic functional group via the ligand attraction method [29]. Cheng and coworkers utilized an amphiphilic polymer of OA–PAA–PEG to render OA-capped NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs water soluble, as a result of the hydrophobic–hydrophobic interaction between OA and hydrocarbon chains of the polymer [25]. In particular, Jiang and co-workers proposed a simple and effective cross-linking methodology to achieve stable dispersion of NaYF4 core–shell UCNPs in water, physiological saline buffers, and biological growth media in a wide range of pH values [26].
4.1 Surface Modification of Hydrophobic Nanoparticles 63

sections.heading: 4.1.5 Layer-by-Layer Assembly
sections.text: Unlike the ligand attraction strategy via hydrophobic–hydrophobic interactions, the layer-by-layer assembly mainly takes advantage of the electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged species to achieve the successful surface modification of NPs (Fig. 4.1) [31–33]. In one of the earliest reports, Li and co-workers functionalized the NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs by sequential deposition of oppositely charged poly(allylamine hydrochloride) (PAH), poly(styrene sulfonate) (PSS), and PAH to generate hydrophilic PAH/PSS/PAH-coated NPs with stable amino-rich shells [34]. Albeit this simple method permits the preparation of water-soluble NPs with uniform layers of diverse compositions and controllable thickness, the timeconsuming posttreatment procedure along with the significant increase in the hydrodynamic size of NPs is somewhat unfavorable for their further bioapplications.

sections.heading: 4.1.6 Surface Silanization
sections.text:
Surface silanization or silica coating is the only one inorganic surface treatment strategy to fabricate a hybrid nanocomposite composed of a luminescent core NP and an amorphous silica shell (Fig. 4.1). Such amorphous silica shell not only is water soluble, photostable, and biocompatible but also allows easy surface carboxyl-functionalization (or amine-functionalization) for further bioconjugation with diverse biomolecules. According to the type of capping ligands on core NPs, the presently established silica coating methods can be classified into two major categories, namely, reverse microemulsion and Stöber methods. NPs with hydrophobic capping ligands can be coated with silica through the reverse microemulsion method [35–49], while NPs with hydrophilic ligands can be coated via the Stöber method [50–57]. For example, Zhang and co-workers employed the reverse microemulsion method to coat thin and uniform silica shells on OA-capped NaYF4 NPs with excellent water solubility and biocompatibility [36]. Using a modified water-inoil reverse microemulsion technique, Chen and co-workers recently succeeded in developing one kind of magnetic/UC bimodal imaging and PDT agent based on NaYF4:Yb/Er/Gd@SiO2(MB) core–shell NPs that are capable of generating singlet oxygen upon a 980-nm laser excitation [58]. On the other hand, Zhang and co-workers demonstrated the coating of a uniform silica shell onto polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP)-stabilized NaYF4 NPs to form a core–shell structure, with the shell thickness adjustable down to 1–3 nm [51].
Particularly, mesoporous silica (mSiO2) as a drug delivery vehicle has attracted considerable attention owing to their unique properties such as high surface area, large pore volume, tunable pore size with a narrow distribution, and good chemical and thermal stability [59]. It is highly anticipated that the integration of mSiO2 with Ln3C-doped luminescent NPs to form uniform core–shell nanocomposites may find potentials in multimodal bioimaging (e.g., MRI and UC imaging), targeted anticancer drug delivery, and PDT. For example, Liu et al. synthesized
64 4 Surface Modification Chemistry of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
uniform NaYF4:Yb/Tm/Gd@mSiO2 core–shell NPs smaller than 50 nm in order to combine diagnostic and therapeutic functions within single NP for simultaneous in vivo MRI and UC imaging [60]. Zhang and co-workers reported the use of NaYF4:Yb/Er@SiO2@mSiO2 NPs with photosensitizers doped into the mesoporous silica shell for both UC cellular imaging and PDT [45]. Lin and coworkers also reported the fabrication of a series of multifunctional mesoporous core–shell-structured nanocomposites like Fe3O4@SiO2@mSiO2@NaYF4:Yb/Er [61], Gd2O3:Er@SiO2@mSiO2 [62], and NaYF4:Yb/Er@SiO2@mSiO2 [63] as efficient drug carriers for drug delivery and cell imaging. Detailed discussion on these functionalized mesoporous silica-coated nanomaterials for controlled drug delivery can be referred to a recent critical review by Yang and co-workers [59].

sections.heading: 4.2 One-Step Synthesis of Hydrophilic Nanoparticles
sections.text:
Although the above two-step surface modification approaches enable us to transfer the hydrophobic NPs into hydrophilic ones which bear appropriate surface functional groups such as carboxyl and amino for further bioconjugation, they still suffer from some intrinsic limitations associated with the complicated synthesis processes and tedious posttreatment procedures. To overcome such undesirable limitations, considerable effort has been devoted to the development of more convenient onestep or one-pot synthetic methods for a wide range of monodisperse, water-soluble, surface-functionalized, and biocompatible Ln3C-doped luminescent NPs, such as hydrothermal microemulsion synthesis [64, 65], IL-based method [66–68], OA/IL two-phase method [69, 70], one-pot hydrothermal synthesis assisted by hydrophilic and/or binary cooperative ligands [71–80], and polyol-based process [81, 82]. For example, Li and co-workers developed a general procedure for one-pot synthesis of amine-functionalized and carboxyl-functionalized NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs by a modified polyol route assisted by bifunctional ligands containing one carboxyl group, such as 11-aminoundecanoic acid (ADA), poly(ethylene glycol)bis(carboxymethyl)ether (PEGBA), and folic acid (FA) [82]. More recently, they developed another facile one-step method termed hydrothermal microemulsion to prepare multifunctional NaLuF4-based UCNPs for multimodal lymphatic imaging (Fig. 4.2) [64]. By contrast, Zhang and co-workers synthesized shape-controlled, water-dispersible, and carboxyl-functionalized NaYF4 UC phosphors by using small-molecule binary acids such as malonic acid, oxalic acid, succinic acid, or tartaric acid as capping agents in one-step hydrothermal synthesis [83]. Yang and co-workers demonstrated the synthesis of hollow mesoporous structured NaYF4:Yb/Er nanospheres via onestep hydrothermal process by using Y(OH)CO3:Yb/Er NPs as sacrificial templates and PEI as capping ligand for cell imaging and targeted anticancer drug delivery [84]. Likewise, we succeeded in direct synthesis of water-soluble carboxylic group-capped GdF3:Ln3C [71], and BaFCl:Ln3C [72], and amine-functionalized KGdF4:Ln3C NPs [79] by selecting different polymers like PAA and PEI as surfactants and capping ligands through modified one-step solvothermal route. Because
4.3 Bioconjugation Chemistry for Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles 65
of the carboxyl or amino groups capping on the surface, these NPs can withstand various biological conditions and can be easily dispersed in aqueous solutions under different experimental conditions in terms of pH (from 3 to 12), temperature (from 0 to 45 ıC), and salt concentration ( 300 mM) [79]. However, despite of their simplified reaction and posttreatment procedures, it is worthy of emphasizing that these facile one-step syntheses generally result in Ln3C-doped NPs with poor shapes, uniformity, and monodispersity as well as low luminescence efficiency for most cases, and, thus, it still remains a great challenge to obtain monodisperse and uniform NPs with small size by using one-step methods up to now (Fig. 4.2).

sections.heading: 4.3 Bioconjugation Chemistry for Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
sections.text:
For bioapplication, the as-prepared hydrophobic or hydrophilic NPs should be further conjugated with biomolecules. There are generally two major purposes for the bioconjugated NPs: (1) to provide biocompatibility or (2) to impart desired
66 4 Surface Modification Chemistry of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
properties such as specific recognition. Nowadays, the inorganic NPs can be modified with biomolecules by taking advantages of many bioconjugation chemistry approaches, which can be categorized as covalent and non-covalent methods.

sections.heading: 4.3.1 Covalent Bonding
sections.text:
Surface modification of NPs with hydrophilic ligands can tune their colloidal properties to render them water-soluble and stable in physiological environments. After that, these hydrophilic NPs can be conjugated with biomolecules (e.g., peptides, proteins, or DNA) for specific interactions with living systems to participate in biological processes like bioimaging and therapy. To date, the covalent binding of biomolecules with special functional groups like carboxylic acids, amines, and maleimides (MA) on NPs is a common method for bioconjugation (Fig. 4.3).
To render the NPs functioned with carboxylate groups (–COOH), ligands like PAA [6–10, 35], 3-mercaptopropionic acid [11], hexanedioic acid [12], AA [13], poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) diacid [2], or citrate [85] were usually used to cap on the surface of the NPs. Note that the –COOH group should be activated so as to
4.3 Bioconjugation Chemistry for Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles 67
couple with biomolecules containing –NH2, such as streptavidin [18], DNA [7], and antibody [53]. For this purpose, the most used reagents are N-hydroxysuccinimide (NHS) and ethyl(dimethylaminopropyl) carbodiimide (EDC) [34, 79]. For instance, Li and co-workers reported the synthesis of azelaic acids (HOOC(CH2)7COOH)functionalized NaYF4:Yb/Er UCNPs by directly oxidizing oleic acid ligands (Fig. 4.4) [18]. The presence of free carboxylic acid groups allowed further conjugation with streptavidin by EDC/NHS coupling protocol. Such streptavidinfunctionalized UCNPs can be employed as a highly sensitive DNA sensor.
Likewise, the NPs modified with PEI [84], AEP [14, 15], poly(allylamine hydrochloride) (PAH) [86], diamino PEG [87], or poly(allylamine) (PAAm) [88] ligands can provide –NH2 groups on the surface of NPs. These amine-functionalized NPs allow further conjugation with FA [15], biotin [89], antibodies [90], and DNA [91] that contain –COOH groups. The conjugation should also be activated for the covalent bonding. Besides the popular EDC/NHS protocol performed in biological buffers within pH range of 4.5–7.5 [89], we recently successfully bioconjugated amine-functionalized ZrO2:Ln3C [17] and CaF2:Ln3C [92] NPs with biotin in DMF solution by utilizing o-benzotriazole-N,N,N0,N0-tetramethyl-uronium-hexafluorophosphate (HBTU) and N,N-diisopropylethy (DIEA) as cross-linking reagents (Fig. 4.5). Moreover, the NPs capped with –NH2 moieties can also allow conjugation with molecules containing –CHO or SDCDN groups for further conjugation with biomolecules like oligonucleotides [46], streptavidin [52], and mannose [93].
Besides the frequently reported carboxyl- and amine-functionalized NPs, the NPs modified with maleimide (MA) groups on the surface are also suitable for coupling with biomolecules containing active RSH groups [94, 95]. The MAfunctionalized NPs can usually be converted from amine modified ones by reacting with a bifunctional linker for bioconjugation. For example, Li and co-workers reported the synthesis of 6-maleimidohexanoic acid N-hydroxysuccinimide estermodified NaYF4:Yb/Er/Tm-NH2 UCNPs to form MA-functionalized equivalents, which can be linked with the thiolated cyclopeptide (Arg–Gly–Asp–Phe–Lys(mpa)) for targeted bioimaging [96]. Similarly, Zako and co-workers labeled Y2O3@SiO2NH2 NPs with thiolated RGD peptides via bifunctional PEG containing NHS and MA groups at both ends (Fig. 4.6) [97].
68 4 Surface Modification Chemistry of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles

sections.heading: 4.3.2 Non-covalent Bonding
sections.text:
In addition to the covalent bonding, biomolecules can also be linked directly to NPs via non-covalent approaches, which are even simpler and more accessible to biologists. For example, negatively charged nucleic acids can be easily attached to the positively charged surface of NPs via electrostatic interactions as reported by Yan and co-workers [98]. In their work, due to the electrostatic interaction between the positively charged NH3C groups of the PEI-Ca1.86 Mg0.14ZnSi2O7:Eu2C/Dy3C persistent-luminescence NPs ( potentialDC14.25 mV) and the negatively charged antibodies on the surface of the Au NPs ( potentialD 28.95 mV) in PBS buffer at pH 7.4, PEI–NPs/Ab–Au NPs probe was formed as a sensitive and specific persistent photoluminescence probe for the inhibition assay of ’-fetoprotein (AFP) in serum samples and imaging of AFP excreted during cancer cell growth. Similarly, Liu and co-workers synthesized MA–PEG–NaYF4:Yb/Tm@SiO2 NPs functionalized with cationic photocaged linkers [99], which can effectively adsorb anionic siRNA through electrostatic attractions and can be easily internalized by living cells. Upon NIR light irradiation, the photocaged linker on the surface of NPs can be cleaved by the upconverted UV light and thus initiated the intracellular
References 69
release of the siRNA. Recently, Lu and co-workers reported a facile approach to prepare DNA-functionalized NaYF4:Yb/Er UCNPs based on ligand exchange at the liquid–liquid interface (Fig. 4.7) [100]. Note that this approach does not require preparation of functionalizable NPs or chemical modification. It cannot only convert the hydrophobic NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs into water-dispersible and biocompatible ones via a facile one-step approach but also lead to the formation of bioconjugates that retained the advantageous properties of both DNA and NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs.

sections.heading: 5.1 Introduction
sections.text:
The optical properties of the host nanomaterials may differ significantly from their bulk counterparts. In lanthanide-doped nanoparticles (NPs), particle size may affect emission lifetime, luminescence quantum efficiency, and concentration quenching [1]. Many of these observed phenomena result from size-reduction-induced structural distortion and surface defects that affect the local crystal-field (CF) environments surrounding the doped lanthanide ions. As a result, the site symmetry, CF strength, and the index of refraction may be significantly different from that in the bulk materials. Although electronic energy levels shift and excited-state lifetime
X. Chen et al., Lanthanide-Doped Luminescent Nanomaterials: From Fundamentals to Bioapplications, Nanomedicine and Nanotoxicology, DOI 10.1007/978-3-642-40364-4__5, © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2014
75
76 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
varies as a function of particle size, literally, many of these effects are not considered as a result of nano-confinement on electronic states. It is well known that in solid states, electrons in the 4f N orbitals of trivalent lanthanide (Ln3C) ions are localized because of extremely small exciton Bohr radius (less than several angstroms), and therefore do not exhibit quantum confinement even in ultrasmall NPs. In general, quantum confinement effect has little impact on the localized electronic states of Ln3C ions doped in insulating NPs with an average size larger than 2–3 nm. Instead, according to CF theory, the electronic energy levels for lanthanide ions in NPs may vary because of changes in the strength of local electrostatic field and site symmetry.
The Ln3C ions are long known as the lighting elements. Luminescence can occur from a specific energy level of Ln3C if the energy gap to the next low-lying energy level is large enough (usually more than 5 phonons), provided that the luminescent level can be populated and the nonradiative deactivation paths can be minimized [2]. Looking at the partial energy diagrams for 4f N energy levels of Ln3C ions shown in Fig. 5.1, many gaps satisfying the above requirement are observed, particularly for Gd3C ( 32,000 cm 1, 6P7/2! 8S7/2), Eu3C ( 12,000 cm 1, 5D0! 7F6), and Tb3C ( 14,000 cm 1, 5D4! 7F0) ions. As a result, intense luminescence spanning a broad spectral range from UV (Gd3C) to visible (e.g., Eu3C, Tb3C, Sm3C, Dy3C, and Tm3C) and to NIR (e.g., Ho3C, Nd3C, Er3C, and Yb3C) can be achieved after the doping of Ln3C ions into the appropriate host materials [3–5]. In view of their wide energy gaps between the luminescent levels and next low-lying energy levels and the parity-forbidden nature of 4f –4f transitions of Ln3C, such luminescence is
5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles 77
generally characterized by sharp emission peaks with long luminescence lifetime even up to tens of milliseconds. For example, in GdF3:Eu3C [6], KGdF4:Eu3C [7], NaGdF4:Eu3C [8], Gd2O3:Eu3C [9], ZrO2:Eu3C [10], and CaF2:Ce3C/Tb3C/NaC NPs [11], the RT lifetimes of Eu3C or Tb3C were determined to be 10.51, 10.34, 5.7, 2.2, 1.02, and 12.5 ms, respectively. Such long-lived luminescence of Ln3C is highly desirable in that it can allow background-free TR biodetection.

sections.heading: 5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles
5.2.1 Spectroscopic Site of Lanthanide Ions in Nanoparticles
sections.text: It’s well known that the optical properties of Ln3C are very sensitive to their local coordination environment occupied, and the emission intensity of Ln3C-doped NPs is critically dependent on the crystal structure and CF surroundings around Ln3C ions. A slight variation of local structure will give rise to significant change in the optical properties of Ln3C ions doped in NPs. In nanoscale, structure disordering and surface defects are inevitable after the introduction of Ln3C ions into the lattices of diverse inorganic NPs. Consequently, multiple sites of Ln3C with different CF surroundings come into being [12–17]. In view of their different CF surroundings, Ln3C ions possessing multiple sites in NPs will present distinct photoluminescence (PL) and luminescence decays for each single site. These optical behaviors may facilitate the determination of local structures and/or site symmetries of Ln3C ions embedded in NPs by means of high-resolution site-selective or time-resolved PL spectroscopy. Therefore, Ln3C ions are often used as a sensitive structural probe for the determination of the number of dopant sites in NPs and their real site symmetry.

sections.heading: 5.2.1.1 Determination of Site Symmetry
sections.text:
Among all the Ln3C ions, Eu3C ion is considered to be the most useful spectroscopic probe in view of its non-degenerate emissive state of 5D0 and the ground state of 7F0 [18–21]. By comparing the CF splitting number of the 5D0–7FJ transitions with the theoretical predictions, multiple luminescent sites of Eu3C with different CF surroundings coupled with their site symmetries can be easily identified in Ln3Cdoped NPs. For example, by using Eu3C as a sensitive structural probe, we recently provided solid spectroscopic evidence for the multiple sites of Eu3C in Ln3C-doped ZnO [13, 22], TiO2 [12, 23], BaFCl [16], NaScF4 [24], and KYF4 NPs [17] that were prepared via the modified sol–gel, sol–gel solvothermal, and thermal decomposition methods.
As a typical example of this method, we measured the site-selective PL spectra of tetragonal BaFCl:Eu3C NPs at 10 K to probe the practical local structure around
78 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
Eu3C ions [16]. Figure 5.2 shows two totally different luminescence patterns of Eu3C ions under the excitations at 392.5 and 464.8 nm, which correspond to intra 4f –4f transitions of 7F0! 5L6 and 7F0! 5D2, respectively. When excited at 392.5 nm, only five relatively broad emission peaks due to 5D0! 7FJ (JD 0, 1, 2, 3, 4) of Eu3C were observed in the visible region. These peaks with moderately resolved CF splitting suggest that Eu3C ions are very likely located at a distorted lattice site close to the surface (marked as site A). Unlike site A, when site selectively excited at 464.8 nm, much sharper 4f –4f emission lines peaked centered at 578.7, 591.9, 617.4, 660.1, and 692.2 nm were observed (Fig. 5.2). Particularly, it was observed that their line widths characterized by the value of full width at half maximum height (FWHM) were much smaller than that of site A, namely, decreasing from 4 nm (the 612-nm peaks of site A) to 1.1 nm (the 617-nm peak), indicating that Eu3C ions occupy an inner lattice site with an ordered crystalline environment (marked as site B). The different FWHM and line positions reveal a very different CF environment for Eu3C ions at site B, which should reside in a much better crystalline lattice than site A. In addition to the characteristic transition lines from 5D0, intense emission lines from higher excited states of 5D2 and 5D1 to 7FJ were also observed in the visible region, which thereby provide another solid evidence for the much better crystalline surroundings of site B. This can be further confirmed by the much sharper and better resolved excitation lines of Eu3C at site B relative to those of site A (Fig. 5.3).
5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles 79
As we all know that the 5D0! 7F2 transition of Eu3C is of electric dipole (ED) nature and very sensitive to its site symmetry, and the 5D0! 7F1 transition is of magnetic dipole (MD) nature and insensitive to site symmetry. The intensity ratio of the 5D0! 7F2 transition to the 5D0! 7F1 transition of Eu3C thereby can provide site symmetry information according to the JO theory [25, 26]. Moreover, according to the ED selection rule, the 5D0! 7F0 transition of Eu3C induced by CF J-mixing is present in the emission spectrum, which is only allowed for the following 10 site symmetries, Cs, C1, Cn, and Cnv (nD 2, 3, 4, 6) [18, 27]. Based on the above analyses coupled with the JO theory and the selection rules for ED and MD transitions in Chap. 1 [28–30], the allowed transition lines of 5D0! 7FJ (JD 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6) for Eu3C ions at 32 crystallographic point groups are summarized and tabulated in Table 5.1. This table is particularly useful in the assignment of the possible Eu3C site symmetry from the observed spectra for researchers in this field.
As clearly shown in Fig. 5.2, the intensity of the 5D0! 7F2 transition of Eu3C at site B is much stronger than that of the 5D0! 7F1 transition, indicating that Eu3C ions locate at a low-symmetry site without inversion center. In tetragonal BaFCl structure, Ba2C ions occupy a site of C4v symmetry. However, the substitution of Ba2C with Eu3C ions might induce significant lattice distortion. Theoretically, the distortion might descend the original C4v site symmetry to C4, C2v, C2, Cs, and C1, according to the branching rules of the 32 point groups (Fig. 5.4) [31]. As demonstrated in Table 5.1, if Eu3C ions at site B situate at C4v or C4 site, only
80 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
two lines for JD 0! JD 1 transition and two lines for JD 0! JD 2 transition are allowed. If Eu3C ions are situated at C2v, there should be three lines for JD 0! JD 1 transition and four lines for JD 0! JD 2 transition. As a matter of fact, three lines for 5D0! 7F1 transition and five lines for 5D0! 7F2 transition of Eu3C at site B were resolved. It infers that the actual site symmetry of Eu3C at site B is very likely reduced to a lower symmetry than C2v (that is, C2, Cs or C1), due to the difference of ionic radius and charge imbalance between Eu3C (rD 0.095 nm) and Ba2C(rD 0.135 nm) [18]. As for Eu3C ions at site A, the transition of 5D0! 7F0 was also present in the emission spectrum (Fig. 5.2), which
5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles 81
to some extent indicates a low-symmetry site without an inversion center for site A. Besides, three lines of the 5D0! 7F1 transition of site A can be well resolved in the emission spectrum, evidencing that it may occupy C2v, C2, Cs, or C1, according to the selection rules in Table 5.1. Generally speaking, the smaller the intensity ratio of 5D0! 7F2/5D0! 7F1, the higher symmetry the local structure [32]. As shown in the emission spectrum of site A (Fig. 5.2), the intensity of 5D0! 7F1 (MD) is obviously stronger than that of 5D0! 7F2 (ED), implying that it possibly occupies the highest site symmetry of C2v. To determine the actual symmetry of site A, nevertheless, it may need additional evidence such as extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) to characterize the local structure of Eu3C.
More recently, based on the high-resolution site-selective PL spectroscopy of Eu3C coupled with the single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD), we have also determined the multiple sites of Sc3C with crystallographic site symmetry of C1 in NaScF4 crystals [24]. To the best of our knowledge, precise structural determination of NaScF4 crystals had never been reported before this work. To this regard, we first synthesized NaScF4 microcrystals and then collected the single-crystal XRD data for NaScF4 with a Rigaku mercury CCD diffractometer by using !–2 scan method at room temperature. The single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that NaScF4 crystal is trigonal with space group of P31. As shown in Fig. 5.5a, the unit cell is composed of three asymmetric units, and the cations (Sc3C and NaC) are distributed on three
82 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
layers along c axis. The asymmetric unit contains six crystallographically unique Sc atoms with site symmetry of C1. Each Sc atom coordinates to seven F atoms (Fig. 5.5b). In each layer, the Sc atom and its surrounding F atoms form two types of ScF7 pentagonal bipyramid polyhedra. These two polyhedra share one of their equatorial edges to form Sc2F12 groups which extend to form chains parallel to the Na cation chains (Fig. 5.5c).

(b) 10 K PL excitation spectra of Eu3C at sites A and B in NaScF4 microcrystals by monitoring the emissions at 619.2 (red line) and 614.7 (black line) nm, respectively. In (a) and (b), the insets show the enlargement in the spectral regions of 5D0 ! 7F0 and 7F0 ! 5L6 of Eu3C at both sites, respectively (Reprinted with permission from Ref. [24]. Copyright 2013, Royal Society of Chemistry)
In view of their similar ionic radii and the same charge, after the introduction of Eu3C ions into NaScF4 crystals, they are expected to take the place of Sc3C ions. To demonstrate the multisite structures of Sc3C in NaScF4 crystals, highresolution site-selective PL spectra of Eu3C in NaScF4 microcrystals were measured at 10 K. As compared in Fig. 5.6a, upon excitation to 5L6 at 394.2 nm, the whole PL emission spectrum of NaScF4:Eu3C microcrystals is dominated by the typical emission peaks of Eu3C (marked as pound symbols, hereafter referred to as site A). When site selectively excited at 392.2 nm, the emission spectrum of Eu3C differs markedly from that of site A (marked as star symbols, hereafter referred to as site B). The emission peaks of 5D0! 7F0 transition at site A and B were observed at 578.2 and 579.2 nm, respectively (inset of Fig. 5.6a). Such multisite structures of Eu3C can be further confirmed by the distinct PL excitation spectra of Eu3C in NaScF4 crystals. As shown in Fig. 5.6b, different PL excitation spectra can be obtained by monitoring the “fingerprint” emissions of Eu3C at 619.2 and 614.7 nm, which correspond to the 5D0! 7F2 transitions of Eu3C at site A and B, respectively. Furthermore, we also monitored the emissions of 588.6 and 594.2, 614.7 and 622.4, and 701.4 and 706.8 nm, which are originated from the 5D0! 7F1, 5D0! 7F2, and 5D0! 7F4 transitions of Eu3C at site B, respectively. All of these excitation spectra are in line with each other, thereby indicating that
the luminescence originated from Eu3C occupying the same kind of spectroscopic site. The luminescence decays of 5D0 for Eu3C at sites A and B in NaScF4 crystal were also measured at 10 K by monitoring site-selective emissions of the 5D0! 7F2 transitions at 619.2 and 614.7 nm, respectively. The PL decay of Eu3C at site A fits well to single-exponential function (Fig. 5.7), and the 5D0 lifetime was determined to be 6.3 ms. By contrast, the PL decay of site B exhibits a rising edge at the initial stage with a rise time of 1.3 ms, followed by single-exponential decay in the tail with a PL lifetime of 8.0 ms. The markedly different PL decays of Eu3C at sites A and B are mainly caused by their different CF surroundings, thereby providing unambiguous evidence for the multiple Eu3C sites in NaScF4:Eu3C crystals.

sections.heading: 5.2.1.2 Breakdown of Crystallographic Site Symmetry
sections.text:
Nowadays, the disordered crystals with distinct optical properties have been widely used as host materials for lighting and displays, lasers, or bioassays; such spectroscopic revelation of local site symmetry breakdown in this huge family of crystals is crucial to optimizing their optical performance for further applications. Among various host materials with disordered structures, inorganic fluorides in the category of AREF4 (AD alkali metal) such as NaYF4 have been well recognized as one of the excellent hosts for Ln3C doping owing to their low phonon frequencies and high chemical stability [33–38]. Nevertheless, the spectroscopic or crystallographic site of Ln3C in cubic (’) or hexagonal (“) phase NaYF4, particularly in “-NaYF4, has received much debate, and two different symmetries have been proposed from previous optical studies [39–42]. For example, Burns first reported the structure of “-NaLnF4 and found that the space group was P6 for “-NaNdF4 with two kinds of Nd3C sites in the lattice, while it was P63/m for “-NaYF4, which contained only one kind of Y3C with a crystallographic site symmetry of C3h [39]. Since then, this pioneering work has been extensively cited for the description of the “- NaYF4 structure, among which quite a few researchers confused the structure of “-NaNdF4 with “-NaYF4 they synthesized and unintentionally regarded P6 as the
5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles 85
space group of “-NaYF4 [41, 43–46]. On the other hand, Grzechnik et al. argued that the space group for “-NaYF4 was P6 at near ambient pressures and P63/m only at high pressures above 20 GPa through high-pressure crystal structure analysis in 2002 [47]. However, according to their structural parameters of P6 for “-NaYF4, the derived mean bond length of Y1-F was anomalously larger than that of Y2/Na-F thus remains suspicious from the crystallographic point of view, as recently pointed out by Krämer et al., who confirmed the space group of P63/m and only one Y site (C3h) partially occupied by Na in non-stoichiometric “-NaYF4 powders [40]. More recently, by utilizing Eu3C as the structural probe, we provided solid spectroscopic proofs accounting for the universal breakdown of crystallographic site symmetry in Ln3C-doped disordered NaYF4 crystals, and the above controversy over the local site symmetry of emitters in NaYF4 can be resolved from the high-resolution spectra of doped Eu3C ions [48], as will be briefly discussed in the following.
Figure 5.8 schematically illustrates the doping-induced breakdown of crystallographic site symmetry for Eu3C in ’- and “-NaYF4 crystals. The positional parameters of ’-NaYF4 and “-NaYF4 with space groups of Fm-3m and P63/m (or P6) are listed in Table 5.2, respectively. The average structure of ’-NaYF4 from single-crystal XRD data is a derivative CaF2 fluorite type with the Ca2C site (4a) randomly occupied by 1/2 NaC and 1/2 Y3C: the nearest neighboring ions around Y3C on site 4a are 8F , and the second nearest neighboring ions are 6 NaC and 6 Y3C [50]. The crystallographic symmetry for Y3C ions on site 4a is Oh (Fig. 5.8a). When Eu3C ions are doped in the Y lattice of ’-NaYF4, in view of the larger ionic radius of Eu3C relative to that of Y3C, the bond length of Eu–F is supposed to be longer than that of Y–F, which thus perturbs the coordination shell around site 4a originally statistically distributed by Y3C and NaC. Accordingly, the displacement patterns of various Y/Na combinations in the second coordination shell around each subset of Eu could be slightly different. Based on the microscopic model of disorder [41], the local site symmetry of each subset of Eu3C will be reduced from Oh to lower ones such as Cs, C2, or even C1. Particularly, if the second coordination shell with Y/Na on site 4a around one subset of Eu3C is displaced as shown in the right of Fig. 5.8a, the local site symmetry for the Eu3C subset will be exactly Cs. For “-NaYF4, since there is only one Y site observed (as will be revealed by our spectroscopic evidence later), it is reasonable to assume that the space group for “-NaYF4 is P63/m, instead of P6 with two kinds of crystallographic sites for Y3C. According to single-crystal XRD data, there are two types of cationic sites in a unit cell for the space group of P63/m: one ninefold coordinated site occupied randomly by NaC and Y3C (site 2c, symmetry of C3h), which is coordinated by 9 nearest neighboring F ions in the shape of a tricapped trigonal prism and 2 NaC and 6 Y3C in the second nearest neighboring shell [50], and another sixfold coordinated site occupied by NaC and vacancies (site 2b) (Fig. 5.8b). When Eu3C ions are doped, for the same reason above mentioned for ’-NaYF4, the local site symmetry of all Eu3C subsets will descend from C3h to lower ones such as Cs, C3, or C1, depending on the displacement pattern of Y/Na on site 2c in the second coordination shell around each subset of Eu. If Y/Na on site 2c around one subset of Eu3C is displaced as shown in the right of Fig. 5.8b, the local site symmetry for this subset of Eu3C will be exactly Cs.
86 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
To validate our hypothesis, we measured the high-resolution PL spectra of NaYF4:Eu3C samples in both ’ and “ phases at low temperature (10 K), which enables a detailed assignment of the CF transition lines of Eu3C. As shown in Fig. 5.8d, total numbers of 1, 3, and 5 CF transition lines from 5D0 to 7F0, 7F1,
5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles 87
and 7F2 were observed in the emission spectrum of “-NaYF4:Eu3C upon excitation at 393 nm, indicating a complete lifting of degeneracy of 7FJ at a rather low site symmetry. To make sure whether all these lines arose from the same site, site-selective excitation spectra were measured by monitoring the three peaks of 5D0! 7F1 at 594.3, 592.1, and 590.2 nm, respectively. All of these excitation spectra are coincident (Fig. 5.9), which indicates that the luminescence originated from Eu3C occupying the same kind of spectroscopic site and verifies that the
88 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
space group for “-NaYF4 submicron rods could be P63/m. In this structure model, Eu3C ions replacing Y3C should be ideally located at a crystallographic site with symmetry of C3h in theory. If the doped Eu3C ions remained with such a C3h symmetry, the 5D0! 7F0 emissions would be strictly forbidden, and the number of 5D0! 7F1,2 emission lines would be 2 and 1, respectively (Fig. 5.8d, left). However, the appearance of the 5D0! 7F0 transition in Fig. 5.8d infers that the site symmetry of Eu3C in “-NaYF4 should be restricted to Cs, Cn, or Cnv (nD 1, 2, 3, 4, 6). According to the branching rules (Fig. 5.4) and transition selection rules of the 32 point groups (Table 5.1) [16, 31], the highest site symmetry of Eu3C, distorted from C3h, is deduced to be Cs based on the above spectroscopic evidence.
Similarly, for ’-NaYF4, Eu3C ions substituting Y3C ions would ideally possess a crystallographic site with point group symmetry of Oh in theory. In principle, the 5D0! 7F0,2,4 emissions that are of forced ED nature should be strictly forbidden, and only the MD transition of 5D0! 7F1 would be allowed and thus be observed in the PL spectrum of Eu3C (Fig. 5.8c, left). However, the integrated PL intensity of the 5D0! 7F2 transition was found comparable to that of 5D0! 7F1, which unambiguously supports that local Eu3C ions occupy a much lower site symmetry than Oh. As can be seen from Fig. 5.8c (right), the numbers of CF transition lines from 5D0 to 7F0, 7F1, and 7F2 are 1, 3, and 5, respectively. Therefore, the highest site symmetry of Eu3C, distorted from Oh, should be Cs or C2, according to the branching rules and transition selection rules of the 32 point groups. Breakdown of crystallographic site symmetry from Oh to Cs or C2 was also observed in cubic KLaF4 and KGdF4 nanocrystals with the same crystal structure (Fig. 5.10).
5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles 89
Furthermore, the breakdown from crystallographic site symmetry will significantly affect the spectral line width of Ln3C. It should be noted that a typical optical spectrum of Eu3C in ordered crystals (such as In2O3 and Gd2O3) usually exhibits remarkably sharp and well-resolved peaks with an FWHM typically in the range of 0.1–0.5 nm, consistent with the fact that Eu3C ions occupy welldefined locations in the lattice [9, 51]. By contrast, due to the minute structural distortion aforementioned, a locally variable CF surrounding around the dopant will happen in disordered crystals, which imposes a slightly different CF on each subset of Eu3C ions. An average CF environment for whole set of Eu3C ions is often experimentally defined because of the indiscernibility of the Eu subsets even with the aid of state-of-the-art spectroscopic equipments. As a consequence, the line widths of the electronic transitions for Ln3C are usually found to be inhomogeneously broadened relative to that in ordered crystals [41, 52]. As shown in Fig. 5.8c, d, the emission lines are broad for Eu3C in ’- and “-NaYF4 phosphors even at 10 K, with average FWHMs of 3.2 and 1.8 nm, respectively. To exemplify this, we amplified the emission peak of the 5D0! 7F0 transition in ’-NaYF4:Eu3C in Fig. 5.11. The typical FWHM of this 0–0 transition line is in the order of 0.1 nm in ordered crystals [9]; however, it is markedly broadened to 1.3 nm in ’-NaYF4. Such a line broadening can be well illustrated by the energy-level scheme in Fig. 5.11: in ’-NaYF4:Eu3C, the second nearest neighboring ions around Eu3C, 6 NaC, and 6 Y3C are randomly distributed over the same lattice site 4a, which could exert slightly different CF on each subset of Eu3C dopants. Accordingly, the exact energy-level position of 5D0 relative to 7F0 differs slightly for each subset of Eu3C ion with different CF surroundings. Such a level broadening will eventually lead to the closely lying emission lines of 5D0! 7F0 at slightly different transition wavelengths, that is, an overall inhomogeneous line broadening of the 0–0 transition.
90 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
To further verify the spectroscopic site symmetry of Eu3C in ’- and “-NaYF4, energy-level fitting of Eu3C was carried out based on meticulous energy-level assignments from the excitation and emission spectra at 10–300 K. Total 48 and 58 CF levels of Eu3C in ’- and “-NaYF4 were identified, respectively, which span an energy range of 0–36,000 cm 1 and belong to 38 multiplets of the 4f 6 configuration of Eu3C (Appendices 2 and 3). The energy-level fitting was performed by assuming the site symmetry of Cs for both ’- and “-NaYF4, using the f-shell empirical programs from Prof. M. F. Reid [53]. The FI parameters of LaF3:Eu3C [54] and CF parameters of Gd2O3:Eu3C [9] were used as starting values for fitting. All the independent CF parameters except Bk0 are complex with real and imaginary parts denoted by ReBkq and ImB k q, because of the low site symmetry of Eu
3C. By means of the parametrization of an effective operator Hamiltonian including freely varied 16 FI and 14 CF parameters, energy-level fitting yielded root mean square deviations of 13.5 and 13.8 cm 1 for ’- and “-NaYF4, respectively. The optimal FI and CF parameters complete energy levels of Eu3C in ’- and “-NaYF4 crystals, which are extremely important and have been long sought for designing highly luminescent NaYF4-based materials, were also determined and listed in Tables 5.3 and 5.4, and the fitted energy levels were compared with experimental values in Appendices 2 and 3, respectively. Most fitted energy levels of Eu3C in ’- and “-NaYF4 shift within a range from 0 to 30 cm 1. Such small standard deviations show a very satisfying agreement between the calculated and observed levels, which thus verify the rationality of the Cs symmetry assignment of Eu3C and directly support the breakdown of crystallographic site symmetry in ’- and “-NaYF4:Eu3C phosphors.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 Upconversion Luminescence of Lanthanide Ions
sections.text:
The so-called upconversion (UC) refers to nonlinear optical process that converts two or more low-energy pump photons to a higher-energy output photon. With the advent of the inexpensive high-power infrared diode lasers (e.g., 980-nm NIR laser), the UC emission from Ln3C ions, especially from NIR to visible, has been
5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles 91
Table 5.4 FI parameters of Eu3C in both ’- and “-NaYF4 phosphors at 10 K (in units of cm 1)a
Parameter ’-NaYF4 “-NaYF4 Eavg 63,259 (9) 63,398 (18) F2 80,911 (37) 81,622 (71) F4 61,959 (73) 60,420 (139) F6 40,515 (45) 41,493 (80) 1,324 (2) 1,329 (2) ˛ 20 20 ˇ 567 567 1,500 1,500 T2 300 300 T3 40 40 T4 60 60 T6 300 300 T7 370 370 T8 320 320 M0 2 2 P2 360 360 aValues in parentheses are errors in the indicated parameters that were freely varied in the fit
extensively studied for its significant applications in the fields of biosensing [55]. Several different mechanisms have been recognized to be involved in the UC process either alone or in combination, including excited-state absorption (ESA), energy transfer UC (ETU), photon avalanche (PA), and energy migration-mediated UC (EMU) (Fig. 5.12) [56–59].
92 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
In the case of ESA, excitation takes the form of successive absorption of pump photons by a single ion, as clearly depicted in the general energy diagram of the ESA process for a simple three-level system (Fig. 5.12a). Similar to the case of ESA, ETU processes also utilize sequential absorption of two photons to populate the metastable level, but the ETU differs from ESA in that the former is realized through energy transfer between two neighboring ions rather than successive absorption of two photons in single ion (Fig. 5.12b). As a result, the ESA and ETU processes can be readily distinguished from each other by virtue of the PL excitation spectra; PL decay behaves as well as the concentration-related optical properties of luminescent states of UC Ln3C ions. For example, the luminescence decay curve should present a single-exponential nature if UC process is due to the GSA/ESA of single ion, whereas a rising edge in the initial stage may be observed in the luminescence decay curve for ETU process, since the population of the luminescent level requires an energy transfer between two ions [60]. An example of this was recently demonstrated in our recent work, where the room temperature UC decays of 4S3/2 of TiO2:Er3C and TiO2:Yb3C/Er3C NPs were recorded under the excitation of 974.5 nm [61]. As shown in Fig. 5.13b, a rising edge at the initial stage of the decay curve was observed in TiO2:Yb3C/Er3C NPs, which was typical of the ET process from Yb3C to Er3C, and thus established that the UC emissions of Er3C were produced via an ETU process. By contrast, no such rise edge could be detected in Er3C singly doped TiO2 NPs, suggesting that the UC emissions of TiO2:Er3C were achieved mainly through the ESA process.
As for the PA process (Fig. 5.12c), the intermediate reservoir level is initially populated by nonresonant weak GSA, followed by the resonant ESA or ET from another excited ion (i.e., ETU) to populate the luminescent level from which UC luminescence occurs. After this initial stage, an efficient cross relaxation (CR) takes place between the excited ion and another adjacent ground state ion, resulting in the
5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles 93
population of reservoir level of two UC ions. Subsequently, the feedback looping of ESA (or ETU) and CR will exponentially increase the population of the reservoir and luminescence levels, and thus producing strong UC luminescence known as the PA UC. Although the PA UC is considered to be the most efficient due to the feedback looping of ESA (or ETU) and CR in those three UC processes, its disadvantages including weak GSA, high pump threshold, and much longer rise time (even up to seconds) limit its further use in lighting and display applications. For the detailed UC mechanism of EMU, please see the discussion in Sect. 5.2.2.3.
Although most of Ln3C ions in principle can be used to generate UC luminescence (UCL), intense and practically useful UC emissions are mainly produced by those Ln3C ions with metastable and long-lived intermediate levels acting as storage reservoirs for the pump energy. In this sense, Er3C and Tm3C ions, characterized by a wealth of ladderlike energy levels that facilitate the successive photon absorptions and energy transfer involved in the UC processes, are the most commonly used activators to give rise to efficient visible emissions when excited by using an NIR laser (usually 980 nm) [62–65]. In order to enhance UCL efficiency, Yb3C ion, possessing a much larger NIR ( 980 nm) absorption cross section in comparison with other Ln3C ions, is often co-doped as an excellent sensitizer along with Er3C to yield strong green and red UC emissions, or together with Tm3C for blue and NIR UCL. The green and red UC emissions are mainly ascribed to the transitions of 2H11/2, 4S3/2! 4I15/2, and 4F9/2! 4I15/2 of Er3C [66, 67], while the typical emissions in the blue and NIR spectral regions originate from the 1D2! 3F4, 1G4! 3F6, and 3H4! 3H6 transitions of Tm3C [8, 68], respectively (Fig. 5.14). Moreover, multicolor UC emissions spanning a wider spectral region can also be achieved in Ln3C-doped inorganic NPs under single-wavelength excitation at 980 nm, as discussed in the following.

sections.heading: 5.2.2.1 Upconversion Multicolor Fine-Tuning
sections.text:
The ability to fine-tune UC color output for Ln3C-doped NPs is highly desirable for their applications in multiplexed biological labeling, imaging, and therapeutics [58]. Currently, there has been an increasing focus on the preparation of Ln3Cdoped NPs with tunable UC emissions from UV to visible and NIR by means of different strategies. The emission colors of Ln3C-doped UCNPs can be manipulated by control of either emission peaks or their relative emission intensities through tuning the host/dopant combinations, the dopant concentrations, and the NP phase, size, shape, crystallinity, and surface capping ligands [64]. One of the earliest examples for the generation of multicolor UC emissions was reported by Haase and co-workers [63]. By co-doping different dopants (Yb3C/Er3C and Yb3C/Tm3C) in cubic-phase NaYF4 NPs, intense yellow and blue UC emissions were realized upon laser excitation at 974 nm. Likewise, Capobianco et al. demonstrated that colloidal LiYF4:Yb3C/Tm3C NPs produced intense multiple emission peaks spanning deepUV to NIR spectral regions upon a 980-nm laser excitation and observed that the intensity of the emission peaks and their ratios can be controlled by varying the
94 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
Yb3C concentrations [69]. In particular, Liu and co-workers proposed a general approach to fine-tune the UC emission colors, based on a single host source of cubic NaYF4 NPs co-doped with Yb3C, Er3C, and Tm3C ions [67]. By precise control of dopant combinations as well as their concentrations, multicolor UC emissions ranging from visible to NIR regions were obtained under single-wavelength excitation at 980 nm, as shown in Fig. 5.15. What’s more, UC multicolor tuning for Ln3C-doped NPs can be achieved by changing their sizes, crystallinity, and capping ligands. For example, Niu et al. reported UC multicolor outputs due mainly to the effect of NP crystallinity, which can be easily tuned when subjected to different reaction temperatures and times [70]. Schietinger and co-workers reported the sizedependent UC multicolor emissions in single NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs [71].

sections.heading: 5.2.2.2 Single-Band Upconversion Luminescence
sections.text:
In comparison with multicolor UCNPs, NPs featuring a single-band red UCL with high chromatic purity are more preferable to serving as ideal optical biolabels for deep tissue imaging in vivo, since the red emission in the range of 600–700 nm falls within the “optical window” of the biological tissues that can afford the deep tissue
5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles 95
penetration. Therefore, much effort has been devoted to realize single-band UC red emission by rational controlling the multipeak emission profiles of Ln3C [72–74]. For example, Liu and co-workers reported high red-to-green emission ratio with increasing the doping concentration of Yb3C in Yb/Er co-doped NaYF4 NPs [67]. In addition, as a result of the efficient energy transfer between Mn2C and doped Ln3C ions, single-band optical feature can be easily achieved in Yb3C/Er3C and Yb3C/Tm3C co-doped UCNPs that contain Mn2C ions [72, 75, 76]. One of the most
representative examples of this approach was reported by Zhao and co-workers, who developed a facile strategy to manipulate green and red UC emissions in hexagonal NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs by controlling the Mn2C content [75]. The doping of Mn2C ions into the lattice of NaYF4 NPs somewhat disturbed the transition possibilities between green and red emissions of Er3C and thus facilitated the occurrence of red UC emission, resulting in an emission color output from green to red (Fig. 5.16). By contrast, Liu and co-workers described another strategy to generate pure singleband UC emissions in the red and NIR spectral regions, which was mainly based on the use of KMnF3 as host materials with Ln3C (Yb/Er, Yb/Ho, and Yb/Tm) dopants homogeneously incorporated in the host lattice [72]. Furthermore, it was observed that the single-band feature found in KMnF3 NPs was independent of the dopant concentration, pump power, and temperature, which differs markedly from that observed in multicolor UCNPs and makes them particularly attractive as an ideal optical bioprobe for deep tissue imaging without the constraints associated with multipeak UCNPs. More recently, Chen and co-workers also realized intense
5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles 97
intrinsic single-band red (or NIR) UC emissions of Er3C (or Tm3C) ions in Na3Zr(Hf)F7 NPs doped with Yb3C/Er3C (or Tm3C) ions, which originated from the Ln3C clusters formed in Na3Zr(Hf)F7 host materials [74].

sections.heading: 5.2.2.3 Energy Migration Upconversion Luminescence
sections.text:
To date, most of the previous studies in UCNPs were restricted to the utilization of Er3C, Tm3C, and Ho3C ions as activators, thereby generating only a limited number of UC emissions. It is highly desirable that intense UCL can be extended to other downconverting (DC) or downshifting (DS) emitters like Eu3C and Tb3C upon NIR excitation ( 980 nm) so that they could exhibit UC/DC dual-mode luminescence for biosensing. These DC (or DS) emitters with long PL lifetime, however, usually have very large energy gaps between their luminescent and next low-lying energy levels. In view of their large energy mismatch ( 7,000 and 10,000 cm 1) for the energy transfer between the 2F5/2! 2F7/2 transition of Yb3C and the 7F0! 5D0 transition of Eu3C (or the 7F6! 5D4 transition of Tb3C), the generation of efficient UC emissions from Eu3C or Tb3C ions remains a challenge via conventional approaches by simply co-doping Yb3C in NPs [77]. To solve this problem, we recently designed a novel strategy to fabricate uniform “-NaGdF4 NPs that were composed of the NaGdF4:Yb/Tm core and NaGdF4:Eu shell in order to achieve dual-mode (UC and DC) luminescence from identical Eu3C ions [8]. As shown in Fig. 5.17, intense UCL resulting from the transitions of 5D2! 7F3 (510 nm), 5D1! 7F1 (536 nm), 5D1! 7F2 (556 nm), 5D1! 7F3 (584 nm), 5D0! 7F1 (591 nm), 5D0! 7F2 (615 nm), and 5D0! 7F4 (696 nm) of Eu3C was observed in NaGdF4 core–shell NPs upon NIR excitation at 976 nm, by taking advantage of Yb3C and Tm3C ions in the cores as double sensitizers and the merit of core–shell nanostructure. The use of such core–shell structure allowed the elimination of the deleterious cross relaxations between doped Eu3C, Yb3C, and Tm3C ions, which thereby yielded a ten times enhancement in the UC emission of Eu3C when compared with the triply doped core-only counterparts. As an added benefit from this strategy, the integration of intense UC and DC (or DS) luminescence of Eu3C with superior paramagnetic property of Gd3C within one NP system will provide a unique platform to fabricate a new class of multifunctional nanomaterials that can be used as a multiplexed luminescent bioprobe and positive MRI contrast agent.
Subsequently, this strategy was further optimized by Liu and co-workers and extended to the preparation of Yb3C highly doped NaGdF4:Yb/Tm (49/1 mol%)@NaGdF4:Ln3C core–shell NPs [57, 78]. Efficient UC emissions from a series of Ln3C ions (LnDTb, Eu, Dy, and Sm) without intermediary energy levels were successfully realized through Gd sublattice-mediated energy migration, by rational design of a core–shell structure with Ln3C embedded into a NaGdF4 shell layer at precisely controlled concentrations. More importantly, a novel UCL mechanism in fluoride NPs, defined as energy migration-mediated UC (EMU) and never observed before in NPs, was proposed based on spectroscopic evidence, which
98 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
is an important extension of those traditional UC processes including ESA, ETU, and PA (Fig. 5.12). In this novel UC process, Ln3C ions designed for realizing EMU were classified into four types, that is, sensitizers (type I), accumulators (type II), migrators (type III), and activators (type IV) (Fig. 5.12d). A sensitizer ion is used to harvest pump photons and subsequently promote a neighboring accumulator ion to excited states. A migrator ion extracts the excitation energy from high-lying energy states of the accumulator, followed by random energy hopping through the migrator ion sublattice and trapping of the migrating energy by an activator ion (Fig. 5.18). To regulate energy exchange interaction between the accumulator and the activator, the sensitizer/accumulator and the activator are spatially confined in different layers of the core–shell structure, which is essential for eliminating deleterious cross relaxation. To generate an efficient EMU process, arrays of migrator ions through the core–shell interface are needed to bridge the
5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles 99
energy transfer from the accumulator to the activator. A key feature of the EMU design is that the excitation energy collected by the sensitizer can be amassed in the accumulator by successive energy transfer while enabling one-step energy transfer to the activator. Thus, stringent selection rules for activators (type IV ion) can be largely exempted, in parallel with the benefit of inherent high conversion efficiency of ETU for low-energy excitation photons. The core–shell layout also allows a facile modulation in activator composition and concentration while minimizing luminescence quenching. As a result, tunable upconversion emissions are likely to be realized for activators without long-lived intermediary energy states.

sections.heading: 5.2.2.4 Strategies for Upconversion Luminescence Enhancement
sections.text:
UCNPs, despite of their superior features such as long PL lifetime, large anti-Stokes shift, low toxicity, and deep tissue penetration, often suffer from low-to-medium brightness as compared to organic fluorescent dyes or quantum dots (QDs). Thus, it is necessary to optimize and enhance UCL to meet the extremely high sensitivity requirements indispensable for bioassays and bioimaging [79]. Currently, there are several ways to improve UCL, but practically passive and active methods can be distinguished [80]. The passive method is to optimize the UC materials themselves, including optimizing the dopant concentration, modifying local chemical and structural environment, controlling the distribution of the active ions in host material, and varying the composition, structure, or morphology of the UCNPs [58]. These parameters are optimized to diminish the quenching effects, enhance the absorption of NIR radiation, improve the sensitizer-to-activator ET efficiency, or increase the radiative transition rate of the activator.
100 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
Optimizing the Dopant Concentration
The potentially easiest way to improve UC quantum yield is to optimize the concentration of optically active ions within a single NP [55]. Although UC processes take place in singly doped NPs through successive photon absorptions and ET within single activator ions like Er3C and Tm3C, the UCL is often found to be very weak. In order to enhance UC efficiency, Yb3C ion, possessing a much larger NIR ( 980 nm) absorption cross section in comparison with other Ln3C ions, is often co-doped as an excellent sensitizer [55]. Yb3C ions can effectively absorb NIR radiation and then transfer their energy to the activator ions in the so-called ETU process, which usually requires single activator ions surrounded by at least two or three Yb3C ions. Therefore, the doping concentration of the sensitizer Yb3C ions should surpass that of the activator ions.
Concentration quenching, as a representative nonradiative process, should be avoided when optimizing the dopant concentration of UCNPs. The increased concentration quenching is typical for lanthanide ions with rich energy levels, such as Tm3C, Er3C, Nd3C, and Pr3C [81]. This quenching is resulting from a concentrationdependent CR process. Thus, CR is prone to occur as the activator concentration increases, leading to nonradiative depopulation of the excited activator ions. As a result, the PL lifetimes as well as the UC quantum yield decrease, even though the amount of the luminescent center increases. For this reason, the concentration of activator ions should be kept low and precisely adjusted to avoid the quenching effect. Unlike the activator ions, the sensitizer Yb3C ions have a simple energylevel scheme and thus are barely affected by CR. For maximizing the absorption efficiency of the UCNPs, Yb3C ions are often heavily doped. However, quenching induced by energy migration from Yb3C ions to the impurities, defects, or surface ligands increases as increasing the Yb3C concentration. To these regards, there exists a moderate doping concentration for the activator ions and Yb3C. As a representative, the optimized dopant concentration in NaYF4 NPs is fixed to be 2 mol% for Er3C and 20 mol% for Yb3C [63]. It is worth to mention that in the matrices where lanthanides are heterovalently doping, for example, CaF2, ion clusters form, and CR between lanthanides occurs more easily; thus, the optimized dopant concentration in this kind of UCNPs is usually lower than that in NaYF4 [81].
Besides the optimization of the dopant concentration, the enhanced UCL can also be achieved by the proper selection of the host materials or surface passivation. Either crystal structure (e.g., cubic vs. hexagonal in NaYF4), crystal composition (e.g., fluorides vs. oxides), or passive admixtures (e.g., Li co-doping) have been applied to increase the UC quantum yield. On the other hand, surface passivation by coating an inert or active shell around the core NPs is another effective way to enhance the UC quantum yield, which is able to shield the excited activator ions from quenching by the high-frequency vibrational modes or defects on the surface.
5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles 101
Selection of Host Materials
The UC efficiency may be enhanced by a proper selection of host matrix for lanthanide dopants. Generally, desirable host materials should have adequate transparency within the wavelength range of interest, low phonon energy, and high optical damage threshold. In addition, the host materials should have close lattice matches to dopant ions for achieving high doping levels. In these regards, inorganic compounds of rare earth ions, alkaline earth ions, and a number of transition metal ions (e.g., Zr4C, Ti4C, and Mn2C) are suitable host materials for lanthanide doping [58]. Phonon energy of the host matrix is of vital importance for the UC efficiency. Host materials with low phonon energies are appropriate for lanthanide doping to achieve efficient UCL, as the low-energy phonons assure low multiphonon (MP) relaxation rate and low nonradiative losses. Chlorides, bromides, and iodides, with phonon energies of 144, 172, and 260 cm 1, respectively, are theoretically ideal host matrices for UCL. However, these materials often suffer from poor chemical stability and are liable of deliquescence under ambient conditions, which exclude them as practical UC materials. Oxides, despite of their good chemical stability, possess high phonon energies over 600 cm 1 which make the MP relaxation rates of the activator comparable to the radiative emission rates and thus are not either ideal host matrices for UCL [82]. Nevertheless, UC may sometimes require phonon assistance, and, thus, there is a balance between phonon properties and UC efficiency. Fluorides, owning to their high chemical stability and suitably low phonon energies (<350 cm 1), are considered as the most efficient host materials for lanthanide doping to achieve desirable UCL for versatile applications [82]. So far, “-NaYF4 has been well established as the most efficient UC host materials [63]. Actually, almost the whole categories of ABF4 (ADLi, Na, K; BDY, Gd, Lu, Sc) are efficient UC host materials. For example, intense UCL has been observed respectively in Ln3C-doped “-NaGdF4, ’-KYF4, ’-KLaF4, and NaScF4 NPs in our recent work [8, 17, 83]. Recently, Li and co-workers have demonstrated that the UCL of 8-nm “-NaLuF4:Yb/Er (or Yb/Tm) NPs is approximately ten times stronger than that of 20-nm “-NaYF4:Yb/Er (or Yb/Tm) NPs and have realized a quantum yield of 0.47˙ 0.06 % at 800 nm for sub-10-nm “-NaYF4:Yb/Tm NPs, which is only six times lower than that of bulk NaYF4:Yb/Er crystals [84].
In addition to phonon energy, crystal structure of the host matrix also plays a critical role in the UC efficiency enhancement. For example, hexagonal-phase NaYF4:Yb/Er bulk materials exhibit about an order of magnitude enhancement of UC efficiency relative to their cubic-phase counterparts [46]. The phase-dependent optical property can be ascribed directly to the different crystal fields around Ln3C ions in matrices of various symmetries. Low-symmetry hosts typically exert a CF containing more uneven components around the dopant ions as compared to highsymmetry counterparts. The uneven components enhance the electronic coupling between 4f energy levels and higher electronic configuration and subsequently increase f –f transition probabilities of the dopant ions [62]. In addition, the decrease in cation size (or unit–cell volume) of the host can cause an increase in the crystalfield strength around the dopant ions and lead to enhanced UC efficiency.
102 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
Intentional Impurities Incorporation
Co-doping with impurities such as Yb3C ions abovementioned may be an effective way to enhance UC efficiency. The incorporated impurities may generally serve as sensitizers like Yb3C, or modify the local CF environment around activators [85, 86], or dissociate the ion clusters in NPs typically for those with lanthanides heterovalently doping [11], which in consequence leads to the UC enhancement. Besides Yb3C ions, other impurities like Gd3C and Mn2C ions may also participate in ET within the matrix. For example, Liu and co-workers demonstrated simultaneous phase, size, and optical properties control of NaYF4 NPs through Gd3C doping [50]. They also revealed a new UC mechanism (i.e., EMU) based on gadolinium sublattice-mediated energy migration, which facilitates efficient UC emissions from a series of Ln3C ions (LnDTb, Eu, Dy, and Sm) without intermediary energy levels [57]; Zhao and co-workers developed a facile strategy to manipulate green and red UC emissions in hexagonal NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs by controlling the Mn2C content [75]. Recently, we found that the doping of Mn2C ions into the lattice of CaF2 NPs resulted in nearly twofold UC enhancement and drastically different spectral line splitting of Er3C emissions, as well as their obviously shortened effective PL lifetimes from 24.2 to 11.5 s (or from 91.6 to 13.4 s) for 4S3/2 (or 4F9/2) energy level (data unpublished). Such UC enhancement can be ascribed to the different CF around Ln3C ions in the CaF2 lattice.
Unlike the active co-dopants, other impurities, for example, alkali ions, intentionally incorporated into UCNPs do not directly participate in the optical process (e.g., ET) within the hosts, but are capable of enhancing UC efficiency as well. Recently, Cai and co-workers have reported the UC enhancement in Yb/Er co-doped NaGdF4 NPs by introducing LiC ions. In contrast to LiC-free NaGdF4:Yb/Er NPs, the green and red UC emission intensities of the NPs co-doped with 7 mol% LiC ions were enhanced by about 47 and 23 times, respectively [85]. More comprehensive studies on the impact of the alkali ions on the crystal structure, particle size, and the UC properties of NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs have been conducted by Zhang and co-workers [86]. Very recently, we have fabricated monodisperse sub-10-nm CaF2:Ln3C NPs through sodium co-doping, which significantly improves the crystallization and the DS and UC luminescence properties of the NPs. Such improvement could be attributed to (1) enhanced crystallinity of NPs, (2) reduced concentration quenching of activators due to the dissociation of ion clusters in CaF2:Ln3C NPs, and (3) modification of crystal-field environment of the emitters [11].
Surface Passivation
Ln3C-doped NPs normally have a high proportion of superficial dopant ions in incomplete coordination environments (Fig. 5.19a). Luminescence of the superficial dopant ions is readily quenched by high-energy oscillators arising from weakly bound surface impurities, ligands, or solvents due to lack of effective protection by the host lattice. Excitation energy of the interior ions can be also transferred
5.2 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Insulating Nanoparticles 103
to the surface through energy migration and eventually dissipated nonradiatively. In addition, incomplete coordination environments result in a decrease of the CF strength around the superficial dopant ions and consequently lead to low UC efficiency. Therefore, it is generally believed that UC emission of NPs is less efficient than that of their bulk counterparts.
The introduction of an inert crystalline shell of an undoped material around each doped NP provides an effective way to improve the UC efficiency of Ln3Cdoped NPs. The shell usually has the same composition as the NP host. In such structures, all dopant ions are confined in the interior core of the NPs (Fig. 5.19b), effectively suppressing ET to the crystal surface to result in efficient UCL. The first demonstration of UC enhancement in “-NaYF4:Yb/Er(Tm)@NaYF4 core–shell NPs was reported by Chow and co-workers [87]. They showed that with a 1.5-nmthick undoped shell of NaYF4, the UC emission of doped 7.7-nm core NPs can be enhanced by 7.4 and 29.6 times for “-NaYF4:Yb/Er and “-NaYF4:Yb,Tm core NPs, respectively. With lattice matching, core–shell structures of completely different chemical compositions can also be constructed to improve the UC efficiency. For example, amorphous shells have been used to minimize surface quenching effects and improve the luminescence efficiency of UCNPs. Lu and co-workers have reported the preparation of Y2O3:Yb/Tm NPs that were coated with noncrystalline silica or titania shells. The UCL intensities of the NPs can be varied by adjusting the thickness of the amorphous shells [88]. Recently, Yan and co-workers demonstrated a 300-fold enhancement of UCL intensity in 10–13-nm ’-NaYF4:Yb,Er@CaF2 core–shell NPs as compared to the pristine NaYF4:Yb,Er NPs [89]. The heteroshell of CaF2 was chosen as well by Prasad and co-workers to coat ’-NaYbF4:Tm NPs, and a 35-fold enhancement of NIR–NIR UCL was achieved [90].
104 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
An ideal shell coating is that all dopant ions are totally confined in the interior core of the NPs and the shell is homogeneously grown around the core NPs. However, in most cases, the dopant ions are partially passivated by the shells, and, thus, the UC efficiency is closely related to the thickness or number of the shell monolayers (ML) [91]. Linear relation of overall UCL quantum yield and the increase of PL lifetimes in response to rising shell thickness were convincingly demonstrated by Zhang and co-workers (Fig. 5.20a–c) [92]. The ’-NaYF4 core was covered by “-NaGdF4 shell through epitaxial layer-by-layer deposition. With the increasing number of shell monolayers, the surface defects were gradually passivated, and the susceptibility of UCNPs to the high-energy vibrations of water molecules was also substantially reduced, resulting in the overall UC enhancement (Fig. 5.20d, e).
5.3 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Semiconductor Nanoparticles 105
Active Upconversion Luminescence Enhancement
Placing UCNPs in close proximity to plasmonic metal surfaces or random distributions of metal NPs such as gold (Au), silver (Ag), or aluminum (Al) has shown promising enhancements in UC efficiency [93–95], due to the influence of both absorption in the NIR and emission at shorter wavelengths in the visible or violet region. When light impinges on a metal NP, it interacts with the free electrons of the metal, causing charge and current oscillations within the skin depth of the metal surface. At wavelengths resonant with the metal NP plasmon frequency, this interaction results in local electric field strengths that are much higher than that of the incident electromagnetic field. Metal NPs can influence the emission process if their resonant wavelength overlaps with the emission frequency of the UCNPs, similar to the common mechanism of emission enhancement in other fluorophores [96, 97]. However, even at excitation wavelengths off-resonance with the metal NP plasmon frequency, these oscillations create an electromagnetic field near the surface of the metal NP that strengthens the surrounding field acting on UCNPs. Nonresonant absorption enhancement of NIR excitations in UCNPs has been proposed to contribute to the observed UC enhancement in UCNPs [71]. Enhanced fields result in higher emission rates in UCNPs, contributing to considerable enhancement of emission intensity in UCNPs in the vicinity of metal NPs. These metal-induced electromagnetic fields depend strongly on the shape, size, and composition of the metal nanostructures.
The practical applicability of the most efficient known UC materials at moderate light intensities is limited by their extremely weak and narrowband NIR absorption due to the parity-forbidden nature of the 4f transitions. Thus, introducing an antenna to harvest the NIR light may be an effective way to enhance UC efficiency. The concept of an UC material where an organic NIR dye was used as an antenna for the “-NaYF4:Yb,Er NPs was first proposed and realized by Hummelen and coworkers [98]. The overall UC by the dye-sensitized NPs is dramatically enhanced by a factor of 3,300 as a result of increased absorptivity and overall broadening of the absorption spectrum of the upconverter.

sections.heading: 5.3 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Semiconductor Nanoparticles
sections.text:
