Ln3C-doped nanocrystalline semiconductors have been the subject of numerous investigations in the past decades. As compared to the Ln3C-doped nano-insulators aforementioned, one of the advantages of Ln3C ions embedded in a wide bandgap NP lattices is that lanthanide luminescence can be efficiently sensitized by exciton recombination in NPs. For example, Kik and Polman reported that the photoluminescence efficiency of Er3C in Si NPs in SiO2 was increased by more than five orders of magnitude, which thus enabled the fabrication of Er-doped NP
106 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
waveguide amplifiers pumped by white light source [99]. Another advantage of Ln3C ions embedded in a wide bandgap NP lattices is that some novel optical properties for Ln3C ions induced by quantum confinement effects are expected in semiconductor NPs, since the exciton Bohr radius of semiconductors is much larger (e.g., 2.5 nm for CdS) than those of insulators like Y2O3 and Gd2O3. However, to achieve the above purposes, the successful incorporation of Ln3C into the lattices of semiconductor NPs is an important prerequisite, which still remains intractable by using conventional wet-chemical methods.

sections.heading: 5.3.1 Incorporation of Lanthanide Ions into the Lattices of Semiconductor Nanoparticles
sections.text:
The luminescence mechanism of Ln3C ions in doped NPs depends on their location in the host lattice. If Ln3C ions have similar chemical properties such as the same oxidation state and similar ionic radius, it is easy to incorporate Ln3C ions in the host lattice in replacement of the host metallic ions. This is the case for most of the insulating NPs such as oxide (Y2O3 and Gd2O3), phosphate (LaPO4), or fluoride (LaF3, NaYF4). However, an important issue for semiconductor NPs is whether Ln3C ions are really incorporated into the lattice sites or not, since their chemical properties usually differ from those of the semiconductor host cations, for example, II–VI group cations. For example, for Ln3C ions doped in ZnO NPs, the trivalent charge of a Ln3C ion on a divalent Zn2C site has to be compensated somewhere in the host lattice. Furthermore, the ionic radius of the lanthanide ions is much larger than that of Zn2C (e.g., for coordination number 6, r(Eu3C)D 0.95 Å, r(Zn2C)D 0.75 Å), which will not favor the substitution of Zn2C as well [13]. Bol et al. had ever proposed a test to confirm if a Ln3C ions are incorporated in a lattice position in II–VI semiconductor (ZnS) NPs by observing if the host absorption band appears in the excitation spectrum of the Ln3C emission. Based on their experimental results, they concluded that the Ln3C ion was hardly embedded in the lattice of nanocrystalline II–VI semiconductors of ZnS and CdS [100]. Although it was controversial whether Ln3C ions could be incorporated into the semiconductor lattice, as will be discussed in the following, some convincing evidence has been provided to establish that trivalent Ln3C ions could be introduced into the lattice of semiconductor nanomaterials if the synthesis method was well designed and the charge imbalance was intentionally compensated.
One convincing example was reported by Kong and co-workers [101], who demonstrated that the sharp and intense emission bands originating from the 2H11/2, 4S3/2! 4I15/2, 4F9/2! 4I15/2, and 4S3/2! 4I13/2 transitions of Er3C in ZnO NPs can be easily achieved in the green, red, and NIR regions upon direct excitation at 488 nm. These well-resolved and sharp emission lines due to CF splittings made full proof of the incorporation of Er3C ions into ZnO lattice. Otherwise, the emission lines of Er3C in the ZnO NPs would be broadened and unresolved similar to the case of Ln3C ions in a glass-like environment, when Er3C ions occupied the
5.3 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Semiconductor Nanoparticles 107
surface sites. Similarly, Pereira and co-workers also demonstrated that the Tb3C ions could be introduced into nanosized ZnO using colloidal synthetic procedures that emitted the characteristic green PL of intra-4f 8 transitions of Tb3C ions [102]. The host-to-Tb3C ET coupled with the typical emission lines of Tb3C with well CF splittings could be observed above bandgap excitation (325 nm), which suggested the effective incorporation of Tb3C ions into ZnO NPs. Although the above results proved the presence of Tb3C ions in ZnO NPs, it was difficult to assert the exact local environment around Tb3C ions in the nanosized ZnO host. By virtue of the surface modification in the Tb3C ions doped ZnO NPs and the subsequent PL measurements, it turned out that the Tb3C ions are located at a well-crystalline environment inside ZnO NPs.
Recently, we have provided convincing spectroscopic evidences for the possible incorporation of Eu3C ion in the ZnO lattice [13, 22]. By using the modified sol–gel method, Eu3C ions were successfully doped into the lattices of ZnO NPs and thereby resulted in the intense and sharp emission lines of Eu3C ions. Some Eu3C ions exhibited the longer lifetime of 5D0 (Fig. 5.21) and very sharp emission and excitation peaks with resolved CF splittings (Fig. 5.22), which were ascribed to Eu3C ions located at the lattice site with ordered crystalline environment. By contrast, the other part of Eu3C ions adsorbed at the surface of ZnO NPs showed a relatively shorter lifetime of 5D0 and broadened fluorescence lines. More significantly, in addition to the intense 5D0! 7FJ (JD 0, 1, 2, 3 and 4) emission lines, sharp emission lines corresponding to the 5D1! 7FJ (JD 1, 2, 3, 4)
108 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
transitions of Eu3C were also detected. These sharp emission lines (5D0,1! 7FJ transitions) of Eu3C with resolved CF splittings revealed that the Eu3C ions were successfully doped into the ZnO NPs. Moreover, the strong host-to-Eu3C energy transfer was also observed, which provided another strong evidence to suggest that Eu3C ions could be incorporated into the lattice of ZnO NPs using the wet-chemical method. Similarly, Eu3C ions were also incorporated into the ZnO nanosheetbased microspheres via a hydrothermal strategy involving the formation of layered hydroxide zinc carbonate [14, 103]. The characteristic emission lines as well as the host to Eu3C ET could be also detected in these Eu3C-doped ZnO nanostructures.

sections.heading: 5.3.2 Local Structures of Lanthanide Ions in Semiconductor Nanoparticles
sections.text:
A small difference in local structure will lead to significant change in the electronic energy levels as well as the excited-state dynamics of the doped Ln3C ions. In nanoscale, structure disordering and surface defects are inevitable after the introduction of Ln3C ions into the lattices of wide bandgap semiconductor NPs. Consequently, multiple sites of Ln3C with different CF surroundings will come into being [12–15]. In view of the diverse CF surroundings, Ln3C ions occupying multiple sites in semiconductor NPs are expected to exhibit distinct PL and luminescence decays for each single site. These optical features thereby facilitate the probe into the local structures of Ln3C ions in semiconductor NPs using the site-selective and time-resolved spectra.
5.3 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Semiconductor Nanoparticles 109

sections.heading: 5.3.2.1 Multiple Spectroscopic Sites of Lanthanide Ions
sections.text:
One of the typical examples for multiple-site structures of Ln3C ions in semiconductor NPs was demonstrated in anatase TiO2 aggregates assembled from the 10–12-nm TiO2:Eu3C NPs [12]. By means of the site-selective spectroscopy at 10 K, three types of luminescence centers of Eu3C (marked as sites I, II, and III) in TiO2 NPs were identified. As compared in Fig. 5.23, the PL excitation and emission patterns differed obviously from each other in line positions, shapes, and intensities, indicative of a totally different CF environment experienced by Eu3C ions in TiO2:Eu3C NPs. One site (site I) exhibited broadened fluorescence lines with the most intense emission at 613.3 nm similar to that of Eu3C in glass-like phase, which was related to the distorted lattice site near the surface. The other two sites (sites II and III) presented sharp emission and excitation lines with the most intense peaks at 616.7 and 618.1 nm, respectively, which were originated from the lattice sites with ordered crystalline environment in anatase TiO2. These sharp emission lines correspond to the CF transitions within 4f 6 configuration of Eu3C. Based on the well-resolved emission and excitation spectra at 10 K, we have located and assigned the CF levels of Eu3C at three sites in TiO2 NPs (Table 5.5). The CF splittings of 7F1 and 5D1 of Eu3C at sites I, II, and III are in a decreasing order, corresponding to a decreasing order of the scalar rank two CF strength. Unlike the disordered site (site I), the non-degenerate 5D0 level is found significantly red
110 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
Multiplet Site I Site II Site III 7F0 0 0 0 7F1 255 233 278
5.3 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Semiconductor Nanoparticles 111
shifted for Eu3C at two lattice sites. This phenomenon can be well interpreted by the nephelauxetic (or electron cloud-expanding) effect. The stronger covalence of Eu–O bond for Eu3C at lattice sites results in larger nephelauxetic effect, which decreases the interelectronic repulsion of Eu3C as well as the Slater integrals (or Racah parameters).
In addition to the site-selective spectroscopy, time-resolved PL (TRPL) technique is another useful means to identify multiple Ln3C sites in semiconductor NPs. For example, we were unable to pick out the PL from single Nd3C site by the siteselective spectroscopy, owing to the very close CF levels ( 13 cm 1) of 4F3/2 for various Nd3C ions in ZnO NPs [104]. As shown in Fig. 5.24a, upon direct excitation from the ground state 4I9/2 to the 4F5/2 state of Nd3C at 811 nm, three emission bands centered at 898, 1,082, and 1,373 nm can be observed at RT, which are due to the radiative relaxations from 4F3/2 to its low-lying multiplets of 4I9/2, 4I11/2, and 4I13/2, respectively. Meanwhile, much sharper and better resolved emission lines originating from CF levels of 4F3/2 to that of 4I9/2, 4I11/2, and 4I13/2 were also detected at low temperature (4.2 K) (Fig. 5.24b). Owing to the time-reversal (Kramers) degeneracy for the 4f 3 configuration (Nd3C), theoretically, five emission peaks for the transition from 4F3/2 to 4I9/2 are expected for single Nd3C site in ZnO NPs at 4.2 K. However, as depicted in the inset of Fig. 5.24b, ten moderately resolved transition lines assigned to 4F3/2! 4I9/2 are identified upon direct excitation at 811 nm, which thus establish the fact that the emission lines in Fig. 5.24b derive from the PL superimposition of at least two Nd3C sites in ZnO lattices.
As opposed to the high-resolution site-selective spectra in Fig. 5.24b, such multiple Nd3C sites in ZnO NPs were easily distinguishable from each other despite of the low resolution (10 nm) of the TRPL spectra. Figure 5.24c shows the TRPL spectra of ZnO:Nd3C NPs collected at different delay time ranging from 0 to 85 s. The intensity of emission peak centered at 1,066 nm (peak A) was observed to
112 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
increase dramatically with increasing delay time, reaching the maximum at 10 s, and then became undetectable after a delay time of 30 s. Nevertheless, a much slower time evolution process was observed for emission peak at 1,082 nm (peak B). This noticeable difference in the evolution of peaks A and B was mainly caused by the multiple luminescence centers of Nd3C ions in the lattice sites of ZnO NPs that possess various CF surroundings and therefore different decay behaviors [104].

sections.heading: 5.3.2.2 Single Lattice Site of Lanthanide Ions
sections.text:
Different from the cases above mentioned, only one single lattice site of Er3C was observed in TiO2:Er3C NPs, which was unusual in view of the large mismatch of the ionic radius and the charge imbalance between Er3C and Ti4C [105]. To probe the CF surroundings experienced by Er3C ions in TiO2 NPs, the NIR PL spectra of Er3C were first measured upon bandgap excitation at 358 nm and direct excitation at 523.4 nm. As shown in Fig. 5.25a, almost the same NIR PL patterns attributed to the 4I13/2! 4I15/2 transition of Er3C are detected despite the different excitation paths, which thereby reveals the homogenous (i.e., the single lattice site) for the doped Er3C ions in TiO2 NPs. Figure 5.25b exhibits the 10 K excitation spectrum for Er3C-doped TiO2 NPs when monitoring the near-infrared (NIR) 4I13/2! 4I15/2 emission at 1532.6 nm. Abundant sharp excitation lines of Er3C centered at 380.6, 407.6, 489.4, 523.4, 550.5, and 654.0 nm can be detected, which come from the direct excitation from ground state of 4I15/2 to the upper excited states of 4G11/2, 2H9/2, 4F7/2, 2H11/2, 4S3/2, and 4F9/2, respectively. Fine CF splitting of the excited states of Er3C is distinguishable, suggesting that Er3C ions are situated at a lattice site rather than on the surface of TiO2 NPs.
According to the crystal structure of anatase TiO2, Er3C ions occupying the Ti lattice site should possess a D2d site symmetry. Nevertheless, the actual site symmetry of Er3C in TiO2 lattice site may be reduced from D2d to lower symmetries due to the remarkable lattice distortion induced by the significant difference in chemical properties for Ti4C and Er3C ions. Theoretically, the multiplets of Er3C at D2d or lower-symmetry sites should present JC 1/2 lines due to the Kramers degeneracy of 4f 11 configuration for Er3C. As clearly presented in the inset of Fig. 5.25b, only two excitation lines assigned to the excited state of 4S3/2 and no trace of CF splitting due to another site can be detected. The CF splitting of other excited states in Fig. 5.25b is also in good agreement with the theoretical analysis, further verifying the single lattice site of Er3C ions in TiO2 NPs. From the viewpoint of spectroscopy, we speculated that most of Er3C ions were very likely located at the substitutional Ti4C lattice site with a site symmetry descending from D2d to C2v, which can be well established by the energy-level fitting of Er3C performed by means of the parametrization of an effective operator Hamiltonian using the f -shell empirical programs. The CF analysis for Er3C in anatase TiO2 NPs at C2v symmetry yielded a smaller final root mean square deviation of 25.1 cm 1 compared to that at D2d symmetry (31.7 cm 1) and thus verified the rationality of the C2v symmetry assignment of Er3C in TiO2 NPs.
5.3 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Semiconductor Nanoparticles 113
Similarly, such single lattice site of Er3C was also observed in Er3C doped SnO2 NPs [106]. By using a solvothermal approach coupled with subsequent annealing in oxygen atmosphere at 800–1,100 ıC, Er3C ions were successfully incorporated into the lattices of rutile SnO2 NPs and thus gave rise to typical NIR 1.54 m emissions of Er3C upon excitation above the SnO2 bandgap at 300 nm [106]. As shown in Fig. 5.26, the PL excitation spectrum of Er3C in SnO2 NPs was dominated by a strong UV broadband centered at 300 nm that corresponded to the bandgap absorption peak of SnO2 NPs (Fig. 5.26, left), while the emission spectrum displayed the fingerprint of Er3C ions (Fig. 5.26, right) when indirectly excited at 300 nm, verifying the occurrence of ET from SnO2 NPs to emitters (Er3C). These sharp and well-resolved NIR emission lines centered at 1,551 nm are derived from the 4I2/13! 4I15/2 transition of Er3C in the lattices of rutile SnO2 NPs. More importantly, it was found that these emission lines of Er3C kept unchanged in terms of line positions and splittings for the samples annealed at temperatures of 800– 1,100 ıC, indicating the identical site occupation of Er3C in SnO2 NPs. Most likely, Er3C ions are located at a lattice site with D2h centrosymmetric site symmetry after the replacement for Sn4C in SnO2 NCs. This hypothesis can be well proved by the absence of the direct 4f –4f excitation lines of Er3C in the PL excitation spectrum of Fig. 5.26. According to the selection rule for the 4f –4f transitions of Ln3C ions, ED transitions are strictly forbidden for a site with a center of inversion. As a consequence, the direct 4f –4f excitation lines, which correspond to the transitions from the ground multiplet 4I15/2 to the excited states of Er3C in the visible and NIR spectral regions of 380–1,000 nm, are forbidden due to their ED nature.

sections.heading: 5.3.3 Host-Sensitized Luminescence of Lanthanide Ions
sections.text:
Host sensitization via the energy transfer (ET) from the excited semiconductor host to Ln3C is considered to be an effective way to realize highly efficient luminescence of Ln3C for practical applications such as optoelectronic devices and flat panel displays. In ET process, the semiconductor hosts may act as a sensitizer to absorb the excitation light in the ultraviolet and visible regions and subsequently transfer energy to the dopants, which thereby overcomes the low absorptions of parityforbidden f –f transitions of Ln3C doped in semiconductor NPs (Fig. 5.27a, b). In a representative example, Li and co-workers have recently observed strong hostsensitized luminescence of Eu3C in nanocrystalline TiO2 microspheres prepared by ultrasonic spray pyrolysis procedure [107]. When excited above the TiO2 bandgap at 330 nm, typical emission lines entered at 590, 614, 651, and 698 nm that corresponded to the 5D0! 7FJ (JD 1, 2, 3, 4) transitions of Eu3C that were observed (Fig. 5.27c). This result unquestionably suggests that Eu3C emissions are associated with an ET process from the anatase TiO2 NPs to the doped Eu3C ions, as further confirmed by the TiO2 bandgap excitation peak presented in the PL excitation spectra of Eu3C (Fig. 5.27d). Moreover, it should be noticed that the PL intensity of Eu3C increased with the increasing Eu concentration up to 16 mol%. Such a high doping concentration of Eu3C without quenching phenomenon occurred was primarily due to the mesostructure formed in TiO2 microspheres during the spray pyrolysis process.
Another interesting example has been demonstrated by Yin et al., who adopted a nonionic, surfactant-assisted, soft-chemistry method to prepare monodisperse spherical and mesoporous Eu3C-doped TiO2 NPs with an average diameter of 250 nm [108]. Intense red luminescence originating from the 5D0! 7FJ (JD 1, 2, 3, 4) transitions of Eu3C was realized through the host sensitization when excited at 360 nm (Fig. 5.28). Notably, the sample annealed at 400 ıC was found to
Fig. 5.28 RT PL spectra of mesoporous Eu-doped TiO2 NPs for (a) the as-prepared samples and samples annealed at (b) 400 and 500 ıC. The inset shows the emission photographs of the corresponding samples (Reprinted with permission from Ref. [108], Copyright 2007, American Institute of Physics)
possess optimal PL due to the efficient ET from TiO2 nanocrystallite to Eu3C ions dispersed in glassy amorphous titania regions. Its PL intensity of Eu3C was about 4.5 times higher than that of the as-prepared samples without further calcinations and 2.3 times higher than that of the samples annealed at 500 ıC with complete crystallization. The decrease in the PL intensity of Eu3C for samples annealed at 500 ıC was mainly due to the fact that the amorphous TiO2 was completely transformed into anatase TiO2, and, thus, the previously well-dispersed Eu3C ions tended to aggregate. Such unwanted Eu–Eu aggregates may serve as an energy quencher and thereby result in the weaker PL of Eu3C for samples annealed at 500 ıC.
Such host-sensitized luminescence of Eu3C can also be achieved in Eu3Cdoped ZnO nanomaterials such as nanorods [109], nanopyramids [110], and
116 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
nanosheet-based microspheres [14, 103]. For example, Zeng and co-workers reported the optical properties of Eu3C ions embedded in ZnO nanosheet-based microspheres [14, 103]. In their study, intense red emission of Eu3C along with oxygen interstitials (Oi) related broad orange band centered at 590 nm was observed at RT upon excitation above ZnO bandgap energy at 325 nm (Fig. 5.29a). Such intense red Eu3C emission revealed the existence of efficient ZnO!Eu3C ET in Eu3Cdoped ZnO nanosheet-based microspheres. Moreover, the shape in the UV range of excitation spectra (Fig. 5.29b) matched well that of undoped ZnO NPs, which further confirmed the ZnO!Eu3C ET. Unfortunately, when doped with other Ln3C ions such as Tb3C, no similar ZnO to Ln3C ET was observed, which might be caused by the quenching effect of defect-related emission and the unmatched energy levels relative to the valence (VB) and conduction band (CB) of ZnO [103].
In stark contrast, typical emission of Tb3C ions could be detected in colloidal ZnO NPs when excited at 325 and 488 nm [102]. By using colloidal synthetic procedures, Tb3C ions were successfully introduced into ZnO NPs that emitted the characteristic green PL of intra-4f 8 transitions of Tb3C ions. As shown in Fig. 5.30, the 7-K emission spectrum under the 325-nm excitation exhibited the near band edge emission at 3.0–3.4 eV and the broad oxygen vacancy-related emission band at 2.45 eV. More interestingly, intense emission lines of Tb3C ions centered at 1.99, 2.12, 2.28, and 2.53 eV were also observed, which could be ascribed to the 5D4! 7F3, 5D4! 7F4, 5D4! 7F5, and 5D4! 7F6 transitions of Tb3C, respectively. These emission lines of Tb3C ions upon indirect excitation suggested that the Tb3C ions could be sensitized by the ZnO host, which might be of particular interest for potential applications in fabrication the light-emitting devices.
Apart from the typical red and green emissions of Eu3C and Tb3C, intense emissions spanning a wider spectral region can be realized by varying the category of dopants via the sensitization of various semiconductor NPs [23, 106, 111]. Figure 5.31 shows the RT excitation and emission spectra of Nd3C and Sm3C ions embedded in TiO2 NPs by using a facile sol–gel solvothermal method [23]. Intense NIR PL of Nd3C was observed upon excitation above the TiO2 bandgap at 345 nm. These typical emission lines of Nd3C centered at 915, 1,094, and 1,384 nm were explicitly assigned to the transitions from 4F3/2 to 4I9/2, 4I11/2, and 4I13/2, respectively (Fig. 5.31b). Meanwhile, sharp emission lines from Sm3C in the region of 560–750 nm were also obtained when excited using the same excitation light, and thus producing overall orange-to-red emissions that are visible to the naked
118 5 Optical Spectroscopy of Lanthanide-Doped Nanoparticles
eye (Fig. 5.31d). The emission lines centered at 584.1, 612.8, 664.1, and 727.0 nm were owing to the de-excitation from 4G5/2 to its lower multiplets of 6H5/2, 6H7/2, 6H9/2, and 6H11/2 of Sm3C, respectively (Fig. 5.31c). Taken together, these results strongly imply that the Nd3C and Sm3C emissions can be achieved via an efficient nonradiative ET process from TiO2 to the dopants, which was further evidenced by the presence of the intense bandgap absorption peak of anatase TiO2 in the excitation spectra of TiO2:Nd3C and TiO2:Sm3C NPs (Fig. 5.31a). Moreover, it should be noted that the excitation lines arising from 4f –4f transitions of Nd3C (or Sm3C) itself in the RT excitation spectrum were hardly detectable, revealing the fact that the sensitized emission was a much more efficient pathway than the direct excitations of Nd3C and Sm3C ions.
Despite the fact that much significant progress has been made in Ln3C ion-doped semiconductor NPs, thorough and comprehensive understanding of the mechanism for ET from the host to Ln3C is still a great challenge. It has been reported that various types of defect states in semiconductor NPs such as TiO2 and ZnO played a crucial role in the ET between semiconductors and the doped Ln3C ions. However, solid evidence to reveal the mechanism of the ET process from the defect energy levels of the host to dopants has not yet been clarified so far. Time-resolved spectroscopy and single-particle (single-molecule) fluorescence spectroscopy may be very helpful to investigate the PL behaviors of Ln3C ions in nanomaterials and the mechanism of host-to-Ln3C ET.

sections.heading: 6.1 Heterogeneous Assay
sections.text:
Highly sensitive detection and accurate analysis of diverse biomolecules particularly cancerous biomarkers in human fluid samples are critical for early cancer theranostics and consequently increase patient survival. To achieve this goal, some efficient bioassay methods such as heterogeneous sandwich-type photoluminescence (PL) assays and homogeneous FRET assay techniques have been developed based on lanthanide-doped luminescent nano-bioprobes in the past decade [1, 2]. According to their signal detection formats, the presently well developed bioassays based on Ln3C-doped luminescent nano-bioprobes can be divided into two broad categories: heterogeneous and homogeneous bioassays [3]. In this chapter, we will provide a comprehensive survey on the most recent advances in the development of lanthanide-doped luminescent nano-bioprobes and their in vitro homogeneous and heterogeneous detection of biomolecules and tumor markers.
Heterogeneous assays take advantage of the specific recognition and high binding affinity between target analytes and capture molecules anchored on a solid substrate to realize the detection of trace amount of analyte [4]. As depicted in Fig. 6.1, in a
X. Chen et al., Lanthanide-Doped Luminescent Nanomaterials: From Fundamentals to Bioapplications, Nanomedicine and Nanotoxicology, DOI 10.1007/978-3-642-40364-4__6, © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2014
125
126 6 In Vitro Luminescent Biodetection Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nanoprobes
typical procedure for heterogeneous sandwich assays, the capture molecules are first immobilized on a solid substrate like 96-well microplate via incubation and then conjugated with the analyte solution followed by a thorough washing step to avoid negative effect of other biological species in the sample. Subsequently, a solution containing NP-labeled capture molecules is added in order to mark the analyte. As such, the analyte is captured between the capture molecule immobilized on the solid phase and the NP-labeled capture molecule. After washing off excess unbound NPlabeled capture molecules thoroughly, the microplate is finally subjected to a PL measurement. As a result, the concentration of analyte can be quantified by directly measuring the optical signal of the NP label. For comparison, in a heterogeneous competitive assay, a solution containing NP-labeled analyte instead of NP-labeled capture molecule is added in the second step in order to compete with the free analyte to bind to the capture molecule anchored on the substrate; therefore, the optical signal varies inversely with the concentration of the free analyte (Fig. 6.1b). Note that the optical signal detected in sandwich-type assay is directly proportional to the concentration of analyte (Fig. 6.1a).

sections.heading: 6.1.1 Downshifting Luminescence-Based Heterogeneous Assay
sections.text:
One of the earliest examples of the competitive heterogeneous assay based on Ln3C-doped downshifting (DS) luminescent NPs was demonstrated by Kennedy
6.1 Heterogeneous Assay 127
and co-workers [5], where commercial cubic Eu2O3 powder was employed as a luminescent probe to detect the herbicide atrazine with an LOD 0.5 ng/mL, which is comparable to that ( 0.1 ng/mL) in a conventional enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) system [6]. However, poor dispersibility, broad size distribution, large particle size, and relatively weak PL of Eu2O3 are unfavorable for their use in practical bioassays. In their further study, they demonstrated the successful application of the poly(L-lysine)-encapsulated Gd2O3:Eu NPs as reporters in a competitive fluorescence microarray immunoassay to detect phenoxybenzoic acid (PBA, a generic biomarker of human exposure to pyrethroid insecticides), with a non-optimized limit of detection (LOD) of 1.4 g/L [7]. Furthermore, Yan and co-workers utilized a sandwich immunoassay strategy to detect the analyte of rabbit immunoglobulin G (IgG) by using the biotinylated YVO4:Eu NPs as bioprobes [8]. In their study, goat anti-rabbit IgG, rabbit IgG, and biotinylated goat anti-rabbit IgG were utilized as the capture antibody, analyte, and detection antibody, respectively. The concentration of rabbit IgG was able to be quantified by measuring the optical signal of YVO4:Eu NPs bound to the 96-well plate upon UV excitation at 272 nm, and the LOD was estimated to be 0.01 g/mL for rabbit IgG, which competes quite favorably with commercial biological agents for quantitative assays.
It should be noted that all the bioassays mentioned above were carried out by using a UV excitation light source; the unwanted interference of scattered lights and autofluorescence from cells and tissues is unavoidable in practical applications. To minimize such negative effect associated with UV excitation, the TR photoluminescence (TRPL) detection technique has recently been introduced into heterogeneous DS bioassays. This TRPL technique is based on the fact that the PL lifetime of Ln3C is typically in the order of a few to tens of milliseconds, much longer than that of scattered lights and autofluorescence from biological samples, which is generally in the nanosecond range. As a result, the TRPL signal in bioassays can be measured free of the interference of short-lived background noise by setting appropriate delay time and gate time, which thereby offers remarkably higher detection sensitivity together with better signal-to-noise (S/N) ratio, as compared to the conventional steady-state detection technique.
The validity of such TRPL detection has been verified by our recent work, in which water-soluble and carboxyl group functionalized Ln3C-doped GdF3 NPs were prepared via a facile one-step solvothermal route, and then served as the first TRPL nano-bioprobes to detect trace amount of avidin [9]. As shown in Fig. 6.2a, the steady-state PL spectrum for the mixture of GdF3:Dy and rhodamine B isothiocyanate (RhBITC) was dominated by the emission of RBITC that was intentionally introduced as an artificial source of short-lived background fluorescence. Emission bands from Dy3C were hardly observed due to the interference of the emission band from RBITC and scattered lights. In sharp contrast, only intense emission lines originating from Dy3C were detected in the TR spectrum when the delay time and gate time were set as 200 s and 1 ms, respectively. Meanwhile, in an avidin–biotin model system, the TRPL intensity of Ln3C was observed to exhibit nearly linear dependence in the concentration range of 1–100 ng/mL of avidin (Fig. 6.2b), and the LOD was determined to be 5 ng/mL (74 pM).
128 6 In Vitro Luminescent Biodetection Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nanoprobes
Subsequently, this novel TRPL bioassay method was refined and extended to Ln3C-doped other luminescent nanoprobes in our laboratory. For example, a strategy based on sodium co-doping was proposed to fabricate highly emissive and ultrasmall (sub-10 nm) CaF2:Ln3C NPs, which were then explored as sensitive TRPL probes for the detection of avidin (Fig. 6.3a) [10]. As shown in Fig. 6.3b, the observed TRPL signal was gradually enhanced as the amount of avidin was increased. By contrast, in nonbinding control experiments where non-biotinylated NPs (or bovine serum albumin (BSA)) were used in place of the biotinylated NPs (or avidin) under otherwise identical conditions, the TRPL signal was hardly detectable. The calibration curve for the TRPL detection of avidin exhibited a nearly linear dependence in the range of 0.3–10 nM and tended to saturate when the concentration exceeded 10 nM (Fig. 6.3c). The LOD was determined to be approximately 48 pM. These results show unambiguously that the long-lived luminescence of Ln3C coupled with the TR detection technique is particularly effective in removing undesired short-lived background fluorescence.

sections.heading: 6.1.2 Upconversion-Based Heterogeneous Assay
sections.text:
In addition to the TRPL biodetection based on Ln3C-doped DS NPs, UCNPs have shown great promise in various heterogeneous bioassays, which provide another effective strategy to completely eliminate the interference of background noise, because UCNPs are excited by using an NIR diode laser (980 nm) to achieve visible emissions, and, thus, no autofluorescence is produced from biological cells and tissues [11, 12]. Zijlmans and co-workers demonstrated the first bioassay application based on UC phosphors for the detection of prostate-specific antigens in human prostate tissue in 1999 [13]. Since then, considerable efforts have been devoted
6.1 Heterogeneous Assay 129
to the use of UCNPs as sensitive bioprobes for diverse heterogeneous bioassays. For instance, Tanke and co-workers provided the first experimental proof on the prospect and advantages of using UC phosphors in heterogeneous bioassays [14]. In their study, an LOD of 1 ng/ L probe DNA was achieved by using 400-nm Y2O2S:Yb/Er UC particles, which was a fourfold increase in sensitivity relative to that by using conventional cyanine 5 labels. Meanwhile, Hampl et al. reported an LOD of 10 pg human chorionic gonadotropin in a 100-mL sample by using submicron-sized Y2O2S:Yb/Er particles in lateral flow immunochromatographic assays [15]. Niedbala and co-workers developed a lateral flow-based strip assay for simultaneous detection of amphetamine, methamphetamine, phencyclidine, and opiates in saliva by employing multicolor NaYF4:Yb/Er UCNPs [16]. Inspired by these, Li and co-workers proposed a sandwich-hybridization assay for ultrasensitive detection of DNA using sub-50-nm NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs [17]. When combined with magnetic technique for facile separation, this method resulted in an LOD of 10 nM without polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplification.
More recently, a novel heterogeneous UC bioassay approach has been developed in our group, which makes use of the surface-functionalized Ln3C-doped fluoride NPs as bioprobes to detect trace amount of analyte in solutions, ranging from
130 6 In Vitro Luminescent Biodetection Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nanoprobes
the commonly used model biomolecule like avidin to important tumor biomarkers like urokinase plasminogen activator receptor (uPAR), carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and ’-fetoprotein (AFP) (Fig. 6.4). The UC PL signal was collected by using a modified multimode microplate reader (Synergy 4, BioTek) with an external 980-nm diode laser as excitation light source in our laboratory. As schematically illustrated in Fig. 6.4, the concentration of analyte biomolecules can be quantified by measuring the optical signals of UC nanoprobes bound to a 96-well microplate upon NIR excitation. For example, for the detection of avidin, we observed that the UC luminescent intensity of Ln3C-doped fluoride NPs displayed a linear relationship with the quantity of avidin with the LOD of 90 pM. Similar results were also obtained for the UC detection of uPAR, CEA, and AFP with their LODs ranging from 40 to 100 pM, which are still under way for improved detection limits in order to fulfill the requirements in standard clinic applications. Nowadays, an ultrasensitive detection or monitoring of new broad-spectrum tumor biomarkers like uPAR is currently urgently desired for disease diagnosis. Hence, new assay kits based on Ln3C-doped UC nano-bioprobes are expected to play a key role in the early diagnosis and therapy of human cancers.

sections.heading: 6.2 Homogeneous FRET Assay
sections.text:
Even though highly sensitive biodetection can be achieved via the heterogeneous assays aforementioned, one should keep in mind that the heterogeneous bioassay is labor-intensive and time-consuming due to the tedious separation and washing steps before signal measurement, which is inconvenient for fast biodetection particularly in clinical applications. Unlike heterogeneous assay, homogeneous FRET assay primarily makes use of the distance-dependent energy transfer between an excited
6.2 Homogeneous FRET Assay 131
donor and a nearby acceptor molecule via long-range dipole–dipole interactions to detect the various biomolecules dissolved in the solution and thus can be performed easily in one step free of the tedious separation and washing steps typically required in heterogeneous bioassay.
To achieve improved FRET efficiency, the donor and acceptor pair used in the FRET bioassay process should be taken into account carefully. Ln3C-doped luminescent NPs, characterized by long-lived luminescence lifetime and large apparent Stokes or anti-Stokes shift, are regarded as ideal energy donors in FRET bioassay. Especially, the long-lived luminescence of Ln3C provide a means to effectively inhibit short-lived background noise (in nanosecond range) from biological samples in a detection technique known as TRPL, thereby yielding a higher detection sensitivity and enhanced S/N as compared to conventional FRET bioassay [18, 19]. Moreover, such unwanted background noise in bioassays can also be easily overcome by using the unique anti-Stokes luminescence of Ln3C denoted as UC, which is usually achieved upon a 980-nm laser excitation. Consequently, a number of homogeneous bioassay methods based on Ln3C-doped luminescent NPs such as TR-FRET and UC-FRET have recently emerged in order to develop the most convenient bioassay method for fast detection in some practical applications [4, 20– 29], as briefly exemplified in the following.

sections.heading: 6.2.1 Conventional FRET Assay
sections.text: FRET is recognized as a sensitive and reliable analytical technique and thus has been widely used in bioassays. Conventional FRET assay generally takes advantage of the distance-dependent energy transfer between an excited donor and a nearby acceptor molecule via long-range dipole–dipole interactions to detect the analyte biomolecules. In this process, irradiation of the donor by an excitation light source triggers an energy transfer to the acceptor provided that they are within a given proximity to each other and spectrally overlapped between the absorption of acceptor and the emission of donor, and the acceptor in turn emits light at its given wavelength [18]. For example, by using glucose-modified LaF3:Ce/Tb NPs as donor and 3-aminophenyl boronic acid-modified RhBITC as acceptor, Li and coworkers recently developed a conventional FRET pair for glucose determination. Under the non-optimized conditions, the glucose in the concentration ranging from 0.5 to 25.0 mM in aqueous solutions was determined by employing the fluorescence response signal in the FRET system as an effective indicator [19].

sections.heading: 6.2.2 Time-Resolved FRET Assay
sections.text:
TR-FRET bioassay based on Ln3C-doped luminescent NPs is an effective approach to eliminate the interference from short-lived autofluorescence and scattered light
of cells and tissues [20–22], as previously proposed for molecular probes such as Ln3C chelates. In a TR-FRET analysis, the energy transfer from the donor such as Ln3C-doped nanoprobes will apparently lengthen the PL lifetime of the acceptor such as organic dyes that are intrinsically short-lived. The principle of a TR-FRET assay is analogous to that of conventional FRET aforementioned except that the fluorescence response signal in TR-FRET is collected after a suitable delay time, typically 50–100 s after excitation by a flash lamp in a microplate reader (Fig. 6.5). Because of their long PL lifetimes and high quantum yields easily achieved in various host materials, thus far, trivalent terbium (Tb3C) and europium (Eu3C) are among the most common Ln3C ions used in TR-FRET assays. However, we would like to emphasize that most of the previous TR-FRET bioassays were reported with the restricted use of molecular probes like lanthanide chelates.
To overcome the disadvantages associated with molecular probes, we developed the first TR-FRET biosensor based on amine-functionalized cubic NaYF4:Ce/Tb NPs that were prepared via a modified one-step solvothermal route [20]. By employing biotinylated NPs as donor and fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) as acceptor, we demonstrated its application as a sensitive TR-FRET biosensor to detect trace amount of biomolecules such as avidin (Fig. 6.6a). The energy transfer between donor and acceptor was clearly observed through specific interaction between avidin and biotin, after the incubation of biotinylated NPs with FITClabeled avidin in solutions for 30 min. As shown in Fig. 6.6b, the TR-FRET signal represented by the emission band of FITC centered at 520 nm (referred to as FITC520) was gradually enhanced at the expense of PL emission band centered at 489 nm from 5D4! 7F6 of Tb3C (referred to as Tb489) as the concentration of avidin increased, indicative of the occurrence of FRET. The TR-FRET process was further confirmed by the PL lifetime shortening of the donor along with the PL lifetime lengthening of the acceptor. By contrast, such TR-FRET signal was hardly detected in the control experiments under otherwise identical conditions by using
6.2 Homogeneous FRET Assay 133
non-biotinylated NPs as bioprobes. Based on the integrated PL intensity ratio of acceptor to donor, the calibration curve was obtained and the LOD of avidin was determined to be 4.8 nM (Fig. 6.6c).
Subsequently, this novel TR-FRET bioassay method was refined and extended to Ln3C-doped other luminescent nanoprobes in our laboratory. For example, by employing polyethylenimine (PEI) as capping ligand through a facile onestep solvothermal route, we synthesized amine-functionalized and biocompatible KGdF4:Ln3C NPs [22]. The resultant NPs could be easily conjugated to biomolecules through amino groups on the surface of NPs and then served as a magnetic/optical multimodal bioprobe in TR-FRET assay to quantitatively detect avidin protein with an LOD down to 5.5 nM. Very recently, toward the TR-FRET assays of tumor markers, we developed a unique strategy to fabricate monodisperse sub-10-nm CaF2:Ln3C core-only and core-shell NPs with tunable shell thickness through sodium co-doping, which significantly improved the crystallization and the DS/UC properties of the nanoprobes [10]. The long-lived luminescence of Ln3C
134 6 In Vitro Luminescent Biodetection Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nanoprobes
and the small size of the nanoprobes led to record-low detection limit of 164 pm for avidin in homogeneous TR-FRET bioassays (Fig. 6.7a–c, see also Table 6.1). For the first time, we employed these nanoprobes as sensitive TR-FRET probes for the detection of the tumor marker-soluble uPAR (suPAR) with a detection limit down to 328 pM (Fig. 6.7d and e), which is comparable to the uPAR level in the serum of
6.2 Homogeneous FRET Assay 135
cancer patients. We also demonstrate the successful use of CaF2:Ln3C NPs in uPARtargeted cancer cell imaging and thus reveal the great potentials of these ultrasmall CaF2:Ln3C nanoprobes in cancer diagnosis.
Specifically, as compared to the fluoride-based luminescent NPs, Ln3C-doped inorganic oxide NPs are expected to exhibit better photostability and chemical and thermal stability because of their more rigid crystalline environment and higher lattice-binding energy, which makes them highly promising as a new and huge family of luminescent bioprobes for TR-FRET bioassay. However, currently it is notoriously difficult to prepare water-soluble and biocompatible Ln3C-doped inorganic oxide NPs that are both bright and very small. To strive for this purpose, a new inorganic oxide bioprobe based on sub-5-nm amine-functionalized tetragonal ZrO2:Ln3C NPs was very recently developed in our lab through a facile solvothermal method followed by ligand exchange procedure [21]. By utilizing the host-sensitized long-lived luminescence of Ln3C, we showed the application of biotinylated ZrO2 NPs as a highly sensitive TR-FRET bioprobe to detect avidin in solutions (Fig. 6.8a and b). The LOD of 3.0 nM for avidin was comparable to those based on conventional FRET or UC-FRET assays that utilized quantum dots (QDs) or NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs as bioprobes to detect biomolecules such as avidin, DNA, IgG, and glucose with an LOD of 0.5–10 nM. The improvement in LOD was mainly attributed to the much smaller size ( 5 nm) of ZrO2 NPs that is more advantageous in distance-dependent FRET biodetection than the larger NPs. Furthermore, these ultrasmall ZrO2:Ln3C NPs also exhibited remarkable specific recognition capability for cancer cells overexpressed with uPAR, after conjugation with a tumor-targeting peptide like amino-terminal fragment (ATF) of urokinase plasminogen activator (uPA), which is crucial for further material applications in targeted bioimaging and cancer detection.

sections.heading: 6.2.3 Upconversion FRET Assay
sections.text:
The concept of UC-FRET (or UC-LRET) bioassay using UC phosphors as donors was first proposed and experimentally corroborated by Kuningas and co-workers
136 6 In Vitro Luminescent Biodetection Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nanoprobes
[33], who successfully demonstrated the sensitive detection of biotin by utilizing streptavidin-conjugated UC phosphors as donor and biotinylated phycobiliprotein (bio-BPE) as acceptor. As a new type of luminescent bioprobes, the main advantage of UCNPs is that the interference of background noise arising from biological substances can be thoroughly circumvented in a biodetection process, since the UC phosphors are excited in the NIR region to achieve visible emissions. For this reason, various types of UCNPs have recently been synthesized and then used as a background-free label for various biological applications like UC-FRET bioassay and UC bioimaging [12, 34–38].
Specifically, Rantanen and co-workers successfully realized the simultaneous detection of multiple analytes without any interference from autofluorescence by making use of the multipeak emission profiles of UC particle donors (Fig. 6.9) [23]. In an LRET-based dual-parametric sandwich assay, two probe oligonucleotides (P1 and P2) with sequences complementary to a target sequence of “-actin or HLA-B27
6.2 Homogeneous FRET Assay 137
were selectively conjugated to Alexa Fluor 546 (AF546) and Alexa Fluor 700 (AF700) dyes. The dye-labeled oligonucleotides and the target oligonucleotide were then mixed with oligonucleotides (C1 or C2) labeled with UCNPs. Upon formation of the sandwich complex through DNA hybridization, the donor emissions at 540 and 653 nm were quenched by AF546 and AF700, respectively. By measuring the intensities of probe-specific emissions at 600 and 740 nm, two different target oligonucleotide sequences can be detected simultaneously and quantified with an LOD of 0.35 nM.
In another pioneering study, Li and co-workers developed a sensitive DNA sensor with streptavidin functionalized NaYF4:Yb/Er UCNPs as energy donor and reporter DNA-TAMRA as energy acceptor to detect trace amounts of target DNA with an non-optimized detection ranging from 10 to 60 nM, on the basis of the highly specific interaction between streptavidin and the capture between two short oligonucleotides (capture and reporter DNA) and a longer one (target DNA) [32]. Likewise, Zhang and co-workers also showed that the oligonucleotide-modified UCNPs can be used as a sensitive biosensor to detect target DNA with an LOD down to 1.3 nM [39].
Besides organic dyes, metallic NPs such as gold NPs have also been frequently employed as energy acceptors or quenchers in UC-FRET bioassay [31]. The combination of the large extinction coefficient of gold NPs and the intense UC luminescence of NPs is anticipated to offer improved sensitivity and lower background in FRET measurement. For example, Wang and co-workers reported a highly sensitive UC-FRET biosensor for the detection of avidin with sub-50-nm NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs as energy donor and gold NPs as energy acceptor, where an LOD as low as 0.5 nM for avidin was achieved under non-optimized experimental conditions [28]. Meanwhile, Xu and co-workers also developed a sandwich UC-FRET system
138 6 In Vitro Luminescent Biodetection Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nanoprobes
comprising of human IgG labeled with NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs as donor and rabbit antigoat IgG labeled with gold NPs as acceptor, yielding a very low LOD of 0.88 g/mL for goat antihuman IgG [31].
In addition to the bioassay of biomolecules, the detection of heavy transition metal ions (such as Cr3C [40], Pb2C [41], Cu2C [42], Zn2C [43], and Hg2C [44]) has drawn extensive attention because of its potential environmental and biological applications [45]. A great deal of effort has been invested in developing fluorescent chemodosimeters based on specific chemical reactions [46]. When comparing with the conventional fluorescence method, the use of UC PL as the detection signal exhibits no autofluorescence from biosamples and greater penetration depth and has become an interesting strategy for biodetection and bioimaging. For instance, Hg2C is one of the most hazardous and ubiquitous pollutants [46]. Liu and coworkers demonstrated a highly selective water-soluble nanoprobe for UCL sensing and bioimaging of Hg2C ions based on dye-assembled nanophosphors [44]. The chromophoric ruthenium complex N719, a Hg2C-selective dye assembled on the surface of UCNPs, was used as energy acceptor (Fig. 6.10a). Addition of Hg2C
6.2 Homogeneous FRET Assay 139
ions resulted in the decreasing spectral overlap between the visible UC emission of UCNPs and absorption of adduct N719-Hg2C; thereby, FRET from UCNPs to N719-Hg2C was reduced, corresponding to an increasing green UC emission. This dye-assembled UCNPs system can detect Hg2C in aqueous solution with high sensitivity (detection limit of 1.95 ppb), a rapid response time (<10 s), and high selectivity (Fig. 6.10b–c). The detection limit of Hg2C was only 1/10 of that of pure complex N719 in chromophoric sensing Hg2C and was lower than the maximum level (2 ppb) of Hg2C in drinking water set by the US Environmental Protection Agency. Importantly, the nanoprobe was shown to be capable of monitoring changes in the distribution of Hg2C in living cells by UCL bioimaging.
More recently, Deng and co-workers proposed a novel method for rapid detection of glutathione in aqueous solutions and living cells [47]. As demonstrated in Fig. 6.11, their method was established based on the observation that the UC luminescence of hexagonal NaYF4:Yb/Tm core-shell UCNPs was quenched by the manganese dioxide (MnO2) nanosheets formed on UCNP surfaces and such MnO2-induced UC quenching effect would be inhibited when a small amount of glutathione (GSH) was added to the particle solutions. Meanwhile, Liu et al. demonstrated the use of the chromophoric iridium (III) complex-coated NaYF4:Yb/Er/Tm NPs as a ratiometric UCL probe for highly selective detection of cyanide anion in aqueous solution with an LOD of 0.18 M, through the inhibition of the energy transfer from the UCNPs to the chromophoric complex [48].
In light of their unique electronic and thermal properties, graphene, graphene oxide (GO), and carbon NPs (CNPs) are also among the most commonly used energy quenchers in UC-FRET biodetection [26, 27, 49]. Recently, Zhang and
140 6 In Vitro Luminescent Biodetection Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nanoprobes
co-workers constructed a novel biosensor for glucose determination based on FRET from UCNPs to GO, which was capable of homogeneously detecting glucose in human serum samples without any background interference (Fig. 6.12a) [27]. Subsequently, they also developed another type of homogeneous biosensor for matrix metalloproteinase-2 (MMP-2, a very important biomarker in blood) determination by employing CNPs as energy acceptors [26]. A polypeptide chain, containing a specific MMP-2 substrate domain and  -electron-rich region, was designed and coupled with PEI-modified NaYF4:Yb/Er UCNPs to serve as energy donors. Upon NIR excitation, the UC-FRET process was initiated by virtue of the     stacking interaction between the probe peptide and CNPs (Fig. 6.12b), thereby leading to the quenching of emissions from UC donors. By contrast, such UC-FRET process was inhibited due to the cleavage of the substrate peptide between UCNPs and CNPs induced by the addition of MMP-2 in solution. As a result, the UC emissions of the donors were recovered and thus provided a rather straightforward approach to quantify MMP-2 in solution with an LOD as low as 10 pg/mL.

sections.heading: 7.1 Downshifting Luminescence-Based Imaging
sections.text:
DS luminescence (DSL) exhibits many prominent optical features such as high quantum yield, narrow bandwidth, long-lived emission, and large apparent Stokes shifts [1]. So far, most studies of the DSL-related bioimaging are based on Eu3C, Tb3C, and Dy3C that can produce strong and practically useful DSL [2–4]. Recently, Ln3C-doped inorganic NPs have been proposed as an ideal candidate for optical imaging, because the rigid crystal host matrices not only provide a steady microenvironment for the Ln3C emitters but also reduce the risk of toxic ion leaching in vivo.
As a typical example of DSL imaging, we recently developed an inorganic oxide bioprobe based on tetragonal ZrO2:Tb3C NPs ( 5.0 nm) synthesized via a facile solvothermal method (Fig. 7.1) [5]. After bioconjugation with amino-terminal fragment (ATF) of urokinase plasminogen activator (uPA), the oxide NPs exhibited specific recognition of cancer cells overexpressed with uPA receptor (uPAR) (Fig. 7.1a). Intense Tb3C green signal was observed from ATF-coupled NPs bound to the membrane of cancer cells (H1299) upon 488-nm laser excitation (Fig. 7.1b).

146 7 Bioimaging Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nanoprobes
For comparison, the Tb3C green signal was hardly observed on the surface of human embryo lung fibroblasts (HELF) cells with uPAR low expressed under identical imaging conditions, due to the lack of specific recognition between the ATF-coupled NPs and HELF cells (Fig. 7.1c). However, it is worthy of mentioning that the main drawback for such DSL bioimaging is that their efficient absorption usually occurs in the ultraviolet (UV) or visible region, which might cause the autofluorescence from cells and tissues and thus result in poor signal-to-noise (S/N) ratio. To avoid such disadvantage, some new techniques including time-resolved luminescence imaging and persistent luminescence imaging have emerged.
7.1 Downshifting Luminescence-Based Imaging 147

sections.heading: 7.1.1 Time-Resolved Luminescence Imaging
sections.text: Since the DSL is usually featured with long photoluminescence (PL) lifetime even up to tens of milliseconds, by utilizing the time-resolved (TR) technique, the interference of scattered lights and other short-lived autofluorescence from cells and tissues can be eliminated, thus offering a remarkably high sensitivity as compared to the conventional fluorescence imaging [1, 6–9]. In 1990, Beverloo and co-workers first demonstrated the TR PL imaging based on Ln3C-doped inorganic luminescent labels [10]. In their study, Y2O2S:Eu3C particles conjugated with proteins such as avidin or immunoglobulins can bind to latex beads with defined surface antigens. The TR microscopy imaging of the conjugates was evaluated with an epi-fluorescence microscope equipped with a xenon flash lamp and a chopper with velocity to generate a 250 s delay. Alexandrou and co-workers acquired TR images of NaC channels on cell membranes, which was a breakthrough in the development of Ln3C-doped TR bioprobes for bioimaging [11]. In their study, YVO4:Eu3C NPs functionalized with guanidinium groups can specifically target NaC channels (Fig. 7.2a). These NPs were individually detectable in live cardiac myocytes, revealing a heterogeneous distribution of NaC channels (Fig. 7.2b). In another work, they coupled YVO4:Eu3C NPs to bungarotoxin proteins and measured the protein– NP coupling ratio at the single particle level based on TR imaging technique [12].

sections.heading: 7.1.2 Persistent Luminescence Imaging
sections.text:
An obstacle for in vivo DSL bioimaging is that the UV or visible excitation light has rather low organism penetrability. Furthermore, UV irradiation might result
148 7 Bioimaging Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nanoprobes
in significant cellular damage. To solve these problems, persistent luminescent (afterglow) bioprobes have been proposed. Persistent luminescence is an optical phenomenon where the excitation light is stored by the material within a few minutes followed by slowly releasing upon thermal activation to emitting centers, resulting in light emission that can last for hours [13, 14]. This afterglow property is of particular interest for in vivo bioimaging because it allows complete avoidance of the cellular damage and autofluorescence signal upon excitation with UV or visible light.
Scherman and co-workers first demonstrated proof-of-concept in vivo imaging of live animals by employing persistent luminescent NPs (PLNPs) (Fig. 7.3) [16]. In their study, Ca0.2Zn0.9Mg0.9Si2O6:Eu2C/Dy3C/Mn2C NPs synthesized by solid-state reaction exhibited superior persistent red luminescence. In these PLNPs, Dy3C ions were introduced as trapped centers, and Mn2C ions acted as the emitting centers receiving energy from the recombination of electron-hole pair. The excitation energy accepted by Dy3C can thermally transfer to Mn2C for several hours. For in vivo imaging, the PLNPs were excited before injection to a mouse, and the persistent luminescence can be followed for more than 1 h (Fig. 7.3a). It was observed that subcutaneous injections with a dose as low as 20 ng produced a
7.2 Upconversion Luminescence Imaging 149
detectable signal with S/N superior to 5 (Fig. 7.3b). Similarly, after intramuscular injections with a high dose of 200 g, the signal was clearly detectable in the tibial cranial muscle (Fig. 7.3c). Besides, some new lanthanide-doped PLNPs such as Ca2Si5N8:Eu2C/Tm3C [13, 14], Ca1.86Mg0.14ZnSi2O7:Eu2C/Dy3C [17], SrMgSi2O6:Eu2C/Dy3C [18], and CaMgSi2O6:Mn2C/Eu2C/Pr3C [19] with excellent persistent luminescence were recently developed for in vivo bioimaging. However, reports on the clinic applications of such kind of persistent luminescent bioprobes are still rare so far, probably because the PLNPs are usually synthesized at high temperature, and it is extremely difficult to synthesize small-sized PLNPs with good biocompatibility [18].

sections.heading: 7.2 Upconversion Luminescence Imaging
sections.text:
In comparison with DSL materials, UC luminescence (UCL) materials by using near-infrared (NIR) light as the excitation source have many advantages for bioimaging, such as absence of autofluorescence, low phototoxicity, and improved tissue penetration depth [20–22]. Due to these attractive merits, Ln3C-doped UCNPs have been developed as a new class of luminescent optical labels. Nowadays, Er3C, Tm3C, and Ho3C ions are frequently chosen as dopants in UC bioprobes to achieve desirable UCL for bioimaging [23, 24].
In 1999, Zijlmans and co-workers reported the first UC bioimaging based on submicron-sized Y2O2S:Yb/Tm particles (0.2–0.4 m) [25]. In their pioneering work, Y2O2S:Yb/Tm particles were labeled with antibodies in order to bind specifically to antigens on intact cells or in tissue sections. Upon excitation at 980 nm, these particles exhibited strong emission in the visible region (blue, green, and red), which can be visualized and recorded by an epi-fluorescence microscope. Their study indicated that labeling by UC particles resulted in superior S/N owing to the absence of autofluorescence. More importantly, the UCL was not susceptible to photobleaching, which thus facilitated long-time PL microscopy. After that, the idea of UCL bioimaging was realized by employing some other oxysulfides or oxides nanomaterials (e.g., Y2O3:Yb/Er [24] and Gd2O3:Yb/Er [26]).
For the selection of nanomaterials in practical bioimaging, small size, bright luminescence, and biological safety are the necessary requirements [27–30]. In contrast to the oxysulfide or oxide host materials, fluorides are considered as better host materials for the doping of Ln3C to achieve intense UC emissions, owning to their low phonon energies and the resulting minimization of the quenching of the excited state of Ln3C ions [31–34]. With the development of facile synthetic strategies, many high-quality Ln3C-doped fluoride NPs with controlled crystalline phases, shapes, and sizes have emerged [35–40]. Among them, NaYF4 and NaGdF4 have been well established as the most efficient UC host materials, thus have been widely used for in vitro cellular and in vivo animal imaging [41–47]. Because of their high UC efficiency that offered excellent S/N, these UCNPs even allowed reliable single-molecule imaging. Recently, Wu and co-workers demonstrated that
150 7 Bioimaging Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nanoprobes
individual NaYF4:Yb/Er NP can emit non-blinking and photostable UCL for singlemolecule imaging upon excitation from only a 980-nm continuous-wave (CW) laser source (Fig. 7.4), in contrast to other multiphoton imaging techniques that require high-power pulsed femtosecond laser excitation [27].

sections.heading: 7.2.1 Near-Infrared-to-Near-Infrared Luminescence Imaging
sections.text: Although the NIR excitation light for UCL materials has strong penetration ability, the UV/visible UC emissions are still easy to be absorbed by biological samples, which definitely limit their further applications in the observation of deep biological tissues. For small-animal in vivo imaging, highly sensitive NIR–NIR systems have attracted increasing attention, because both the excitation and emission lights are located in the “optical transmission window” of tissues (700–1,000 nm) [39]. For this purpose, Tm3C ions are frequently chosen as dopants since they can exhibit strong NIR emission between 750 and 850 nm due to the transition from 3H4! 3H6 under CW laser excitation at 980 nm. So far, in vivo whole-body imaging of small animals has been successfully realized based on Tm3C-doped NaYF4 [46], NaGdF4 [48, 49], NaLuF4 [50], and NaYbF4 [21, 51] NPs. For instance, Li and co-workers conducted whole-body PL imaging of mouse, by employing sub-10-nm citric acid-capped NaLuF4:Gd/Yb/Tm NPs [49]. The UC quantum yield (800 nm) for these NPs was measured to be 0.47˙ 0.06 %, and the S/N of the mouse injected subcutaneously with citric acid-modified NaLuF4:Gd/Yb/Tm NPs ( 7.8 nm) was 12 times that of citric acid-modified “-NaYF4:Yb/Tm NPs ( 20 nm) (Fig. 7.5a, b). Their results indicated that by utilizing these NaLuF4:Gd/Yb/Tm NPs, high contrast UCL imaging of whole-body mouse with a penetration depth of 2 cm and an excellent detection limit of 50 cells can be achieved (Fig. 7.5c, d).

sections.heading: 7.2.2 Single-Band Luminescence Imaging
sections.text:
To meet the growing demand for efficient optical bioimaging, much effort has been devoted to the developing of new UC optical nanomaterials. Recently, several UCNPs featuring single-band UC emission with high chromatic purity have been used in UCL bioimaging. Zhao and co-workers synthesized NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs that emitted single-band red UC light through doping of 30 mol% Mn2C ions, because of the efficient energy transfer between Er3C and Mn2C ions [52]. After coating with polyethylene glycol (PEG)-conjugated phospholipid, these NPs were demonstrated for the use of in vivo imaging of deep tissue. Another intriguing example was reported by Liu and co-workers, who prepared KMnF3 NPs doped with Yb/Er, Yb/Ho, or Yb/Tm that exhibited single-band red, red, or NIR emissions, respectively [33]. The absence of short-wavelength emission in the visible spectral region in these Ln3C-doped NPs provided a platform for deep-penetration UC imaging (Fig. 7.6a–c). To exemplify the advantage of single-band UCL, they
7.2 Upconversion Luminescence Imaging 151
152 7 Bioimaging Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nanoprobes
injected polymer-modified KMnF3:Yb/Er and NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs into pork muscle tissue at varied depths, which were then imaged by a modified Maestro in vivo imaging system. The UC red emission from KMnF3:Yb/Er NPs can be visualized even at a depth of 10 mm beneath the tissue surface (Fig. 7.6d), whereas the multipeak emission from NaYF4:Yb/Er can only be detected at about 5 mm under identical experimental setup (Fig. 7.6e). More importantly, the UC emission color of KMnF3:Yb/Er NPs did not change with the imaging depth (Fig. 7.6f). On the contrary, owing to the much rapid attenuation of UC green emission relative to UC red emission in tissue, the UC emission color of NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs changed significantly with the depth (Fig. 7.6e and g).
7.3 Magnetic Resonance Imaging 153

sections.heading: 7.3 Magnetic Resonance Imaging
sections.text:
MR imaging (MRI) is a powerful noninvasive medical technique widely used in current clinical diagnosis and therapy. One of the notable advantages of MRI over luminescence imaging is the ability to acquire three-dimensional tomographic information about whole tissue samples and living bodies with high spatial resolution [53]. The MR images are generated from the interaction of protons with
154 7 Bioimaging Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nanoprobes
the surrounding molecules of tissues in a magnetic field when triggered with a radio frequency pulse [53, 54]. In the external magnetic field, protons will align in one direction. These aligned protons are perturbed upon application of the radio frequency pulse. Subsequently, the protons relax to the lower energy level, emitting radio waves which can be recorded by a scanner to produce images of the subject. Small local differences in the environment of water in different tissues will result in different relaxation rates, providing contrast between tissues in MR images [55]. The obtained contrast depends on the longitudinal relaxation time (T1) and the transversal relaxation time (T2), so the parameters of the scanner can be adjusted to get the T1- or T2-weighted MR images.
To shorten the relaxation time and provide better MR images, contrast agents (such as paramagnetic, superparamagnetic, or ferromagnetic materials) are used since they can increase the relaxation rates of water in tissues [53]. It should be noted that all contrast agents shorten both T1 and T2. Some contrast agents will obviously change the spin–lattice relaxation of the protons of the samples and nearby water. They are thus positive (T1) contrast agents, which brightens the imaging where the contrast agents are (Fig. 7.7). By contrast, some contrast agents will mainly affect the spin–spin relaxation and darken the image; thus, they are negative (T2) contrast agents (Fig. 7.7). The ability of contrast agents to reduce T1 or T2 is described by the longitudinal (r1) or transverse (r2) relaxivity, respectively. The higher the r1 or r2 value, the stronger the reduction in T1 or T2, and the better MR images the contrast agents produce. In addition, the ratio of r2/r1 is a defining parameter indicating whether the contrast agent can be employed as a positive or negative agent. Ideal T1 contrast agents should have high r1 values and low r2/r1 ratios to maximize the T1 contrast effect [53].
Nowadays, some organic compounds like gadolinium diethylenetriaminepentaacetate (Gd-DTPA) have been extensively used as MR contrast agents because
7.3 Magnetic Resonance Imaging 155
of the strong paramagnetism of Gd3C [57]. Compared with molecule agents, the magnetic properties of the inorganic NPs agents can be tailored by the size, shape, and composition. Besides, inorganic nanoparticle agents have a long circulation time in the body [58]. These properties make inorganic NPs very attractive as contrast agents in MRI [59]. The inorganic NPs are usually used in MRI as two main forms. The nanoparticle itself can be MRI active, such as iron oxides, gadolinium fluoride, manganese oxide, or other core materials (Table 7.1). Alternatively, a non-MRI-active nanoparticle can be coated with an MRI-active material like Gdchelates [69], or these non-MRI-active nanoparticle can be embedded into a carrier matrix that contains (super)paramagnetic agents [58]. In addition, it is facile to combine inorganic NPs of T1 and T2 contrast agent to obtain T1/T2 dual contrast agents (Fig. 7.8), which have recently attracted considerable interest because they can give highly accurate diagnostic information by the beneficial contrast effects in both T1 imaging with high tissue resolution and T2 imaging with high feasibility on detection of a lesion [55]. For instance, Cheon and co-workers synthesized MnFe2O4@SiO2@Gd2O(CO3)2 NPs, in which the T1 contrast material (Gd2O(CO3)2) and the T2 contrast material (MnFe2O4) were separated by a SiO2 layer (Fig. 7.8a–b) [56]. In their work, the degree of T1 and T2 couplings can be modulated by adjusting the thickness of the SiO2 layer (4, 8, 12, 16, and 20 nm), which made it possible to create new contrast agents with tunable and maximized T1 or T2 signals (Fig. 7.8c). However, the large hydrodynamic sizes may result in short circulating times and poor colloidal stability under physiological conditions. Later, Gao and co-workers synthesized monodispersed Gd2O3-embedded iron oxide (GdIO) NPs (14 nm in diameter) that can act as a T1/T2 mutually enhanced dualmodal contrast agent for MR imaging of liver and hepatic tumor detection with great accuracy in mice [55]. Embedding Gd2O3 into superparamagnetic iron oxide NPs may lead to enhanced local magnetic field strengths by each other under an external magnetic field, resulting in the synergistic enhancement of r1 and r2 relaxivity.

sections.heading: 7.3.1 T1-Weighted Magnetic Resonance Imaging
sections.text:
Positive contrast agents, which are commonly made up of paramagnetic materials, are frequently used for T1-weighted MR imaging in clinic diagnosis. These positive contrast agents are mainly based on metal ions with large numbers of unpaired electrons, such as Mn2C (5 unpaired electrons) and Gd3C (7 unpaired electrons) [70]. Compared to negative contrast agents used in T2-weighted MR imaging, positive contrast agents for T1-weighted MR imaging have several critical advantages such
7.3 Magnetic Resonance Imaging 157
as high signal enhancing effect and magnetic homogeneity without perturbation of the magnetic field, which has led to the development and use of various types of Gd3C-chelates as T1 contrast agents [71]. However, the disadvantages of using Gd3C-chelates, such as possible toxicity from free Gd3C ions and limited amounts of paramagnetic ions are unsuitable for targeted imaging [72]. Although ultrasmall ( 3 nm in diameter) iron oxide NPs have been used as T1 contrast agents [73], the Gd3C-based inorganic NPs are still the prevailing T1 contrast agents in current clinical applications [57]. As indicated in Table 7.1, many Gd3C-based inorganic NPs such as NaGdF4, KGdF4, GdF3, Gd2O3, and GdVO4 were reported to exhibit excellent r1 relaxivity which were suitable for T1-weighted MR imaging. Among these Gd3C-based inorganic NPs, Gd2O3 NPs have been most often investigated. In 2007, the use of Gd2O3 in T1-weighted image of a nude mouse was explored by Roux and co-workers [74]. Another outstanding demonstration was reported by Lee and co-workers, who prepared Gd2O3 NPs with particle diameters of 1 nm [61]. Due to the huge surface-to-volume ratio of the ultrasmall NPs, a large r1 of water proton of 9.9 mM 1 s 1 was measured. As a result, high contrast in vivo T1 MR images of the brain tumor of a rat were observed after these Gd2O3 NPs were injected intravenously.
Besides Gd2O3 NPs, Gd3C-based fluorides such as GdF3 and NaGdF4 attract more and more attention in these years, due to their low phonon energies which are favorable to produce efficient luminescence when doped with Ln3C ions [1, 8]. Van Veggel and co-workers reported the controlled synthesis of NaGdF4 of four different sizes ( 2.5, 4, 6.5, 8.0 nm) [60]. The ionic relaxivity (unit Gd3C concentration) values increased from 3.0 to 7.2 mM 1 s 1 with decreasing particle size, and the relaxivity of the 2.5-nm particle was almost twice that of clinically used Gd-DTPA relaxivity. The rate of increase in ionic relaxivity with decreasing particle size was similar to the rate of increase in the NP surface-to-volume ratio, giving direct indication that the surface Gd3C ions were the major contributors to the relaxivity enhancement. Most recently, with such different sized NaGdF4 NPs, Gao and coworkers reported the in vivo MR imaging of intraperitoneal tumor xenografts [75]. Water-soluble NaGdF4 NPs (5 and 20 nm) coated by PEG were functioned with antiEGFR monoclonal antibody (mAb) to specifically target cancer cells. In comparison with Gd-DTPA, both NaGdF4-5 and NaGdF4-20 gave rise to enhanced cell viability when the concentration of Gd3C was below 5 mM. Their result indicated that both the NaGdF4-PEG-mAb probes with different sizes presented better tumor-targeting ability than Gd-DTPA (Fig. 7.9a). T1 values of the tumor site started to decrease shortly after the injection of NaGdF4-PEG-mAb probes, reaching a minimum at 4 h postinjection by decreasing of T1 of 50 % for NaGdF4-5-mAb and 30 % for NaGdF4-20-mAb (Fig. 7.9b). Since the NaGdF4 NPs without functionalization with mAb cannot specifically target to cancer cells, the resulting decrease of T1 was much lower (<15 %).
