sections.heading: 7.3.2 T2-Weighted Magnetic Resonance Imaging
sections.text:
The representative T2 MRI contrast agent is superparamagnetic iron oxide nanoparticles (SPIO) [76]. In the 1990s, SPIO were reported to enter the clinic for use in MRI as contrast agents [77]. Since then, there has been an explosion of interest in inorganic nanomaterials. Besides iron oxides, alloyed NPs are typical examples with efficient T2 contrast effects. Various bimetallic ferrite NPs have been tested as T2 contrast media. Some examples include FeCo [78], FePt [79], CoFe2O4 [80], MnFeO4 [81], MnFe2O4 [82], and NiFe2O4 [83].
As for the lanthanide-related T2 MRI contrast agent, Dy3C ion has recently been proposed as an efficient T2 contrast agent because of its high magnetic moment (10.6 B) and short electronic relaxation time (0.5 ps). Until now, only a handful of Dy3Cbased chelates (e.g., Dy3C-DTPA [84, 85]) and NPs (e.g., Dy2O3 [68, 86], NaDyF4 [67, 87]) have been studied as T2 contrast agents. One of the major limitations of the present clinically used organic contrast agents is their decreased efficiency at higher magnetic fields [67, 88]. To indicate the advantage of inorganic nanoparticle-based contrast agents, van Veggel and co-workers measured the relaxivity of Dy3C (at 3 and 9.4 T) in NaDyF4 NPs with controlled size of 5.4, 9.8, and 20.3 nm (Fig. 7.10a)
7.3 Magnetic Resonance Imaging 159
[67]. As the size increased, the value of r2 grew from 50 to 6,479 mM 1 s 1, and the contrast of the image went from gray to dark (Fig. 7.10b). The r2/r1 ratio of NaDyF4 NPs was about 2 and 10 times higher than that of commercial contrast
160 7 Bioimaging Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nanoprobes
agent (Resovist) at 3 and 9.4 T, respectively (Fig. 7.10c). This extremely high r2/r1 of the NaDyF4 NPs clearly suggests their great potential as T2 contrast agent at ultrahigh fields (Fig. 7.10d).

sections.heading: 8.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Recent advances in nanotechnology and nanomaterials have contributed to the development of functionalized nanoparticles (NPs) as bioprobes in various biomedical applications [1]. Although single modality NPs with optical or magnetic characteristics have been widely used in biosensing and bioimaging, they are not perfect and insufficient to obtain all the necessary information of the biological samples [2, 3]. Thus, to meet the demands of up-to-date biomedical technology, the development of next-generation bioprobes is essential.
Multimodal biolabeling, which combines two or more functionalities, is emerging as a new frontier in biology and medicine [4]. Particularly, trivalent lanthanide ion (Ln3C)-doped inorganic NPs have been considered as a promising candidate for multimodal bioapplications, owing to their unique electronic structures and unusual optical and magnetic properties [5]. These Ln3C-doped NPs can be employed as
X. Chen et al., Lanthanide-Doped Luminescent Nanomaterials: From Fundamentals to Bioapplications, Nanomedicine and Nanotoxicology, DOI 10.1007/978-3-642-40364-4__8, © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2014
165
166 8 Multimodal Biosensing Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nano-bioprobes
excellent luminescent probes in view of their superior optical features such as narrow emission bandwidths, large Stokes shift, and long luminescence lifetime [6]. However, photoluminescence (PL) biolabeling has the shortcoming of low penetration depth at the wavelengths of both the excitation and emission lights. By contrast, the technique of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) possesses high penetration depth and thus a high spatial resolution, since the biological tissues are essentially transparent to magnetic fields [7]. It is expected that Ln3C-doped optical/magnetic multimodal probes can be guided by external magnetic field to the site of interest, whereas the PL from Ln3C ions can be used for real-time tracking. These Ln3C-doped optical/magnetic multimodal bioprobes, which bring together the advantages of high sensitivity from PL detection, excellent spatial resolution from MRI, and magnetically guided delivery, may have great potentials for versatile applications in bioimaging, MRI, bio-separation, targeted anticancer drug delivery, clinical therapeutics, and diagnostics (the so-called theranostics) [8–10].
Although the last decade has witnessed the rapid development of pursuing luminescent and magnetic nanomaterials [11, 12], it still remains a challenge to synthesize optical/magnetic multimodal bioprobes. So far, many strategies that integrate multiple nano-components into a single particle have emerged. A common strategy is to construct a core–shell structure that consists of luminescent and magnetic materials. However, these hybrid composites (i.e., Fe3O4@NaLuF4:Yb/Er [13], Fe3O4@LaF3:Yb/Er [14]) often confront the difficulties in combining individual optical or magnetic functions while preserving the original particle sizes. To solve this problem, some single-phase nanomaterials such as Gd3C-based NPs (i.e., KGdF4:Tm/Yb [15], NaGdF4:Er/Yb [16]) have recently been proposed as a new class of multimodal bioprobes, since Gd3C is not only a paramagnetic relaxation agent due to its seven unpaired electrons of the half-filled 4f shell but also an efficient sensitizer that can transfer the excitation energy to activate the neighboring Ln3C emitters [17, 18].
The primary applications of Ln3C-doped optical/magnetic multimodal probes in biomedical fields can be roughly divided into biosensing and disease theranostics (Fig. 8.1) [19]. On one hand, optical detection and imaging with high sensitivity have been regarded as one of the most valuable sensing modality, and MRI with insufficient sensitivity is complemented by its high spatial resolution. Once the optical and magnetic functional units are integrated into one system, the optical/magnetic multimodal nanoprobes can provide more effective and accurate information about anatomical structure and physiological function of the biological samples. In addition, the convenience of site-specific guiding under external magnetic field by using optical/magnetic multimodal probes favors some special biodetection or bioimaging [20, 21]. On the other hand, optical/magnetic multimodal Ln3C-doped NPs have demonstrated great potentials in therapeutics such as targeted drug delivery, photodynamic therapy (PDT), and photothermal ablation (PTA) [22, 23]. In this chapter, we introduce the controlled synthesis of lanthanide-doped inorganic multimodal bioprobes including core–shell-structured and single-phase nanoparticles and demonstrate different design strategies for
achieving dual-modal functionalization of nanoprobes. In particular, we highlight the most recent advances in biodetection, bioimaging, and targeted drug delivery and therapy based on these lanthanide-doped multimodal nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 8.2 Design Strategies
sections.text:
In the past decades, the vast majority of multifunctional luminescent materials have been developed based on organic dyes [24], lanthanide chelates [25], and QDs [26–28]. These materials often suffer from a variety of drawbacks, for example, short luminescence lifetime, poor photostability, and potential long-term toxicity. As an alternative to conventional luminescent probes, Ln3C-doped NPs have many advantages such as good biocompatibility, high chemical stability, and photostability [6]. Ln3C-doped NPs are composed of a stable inorganic host and Ln3C dopants embedded in the host lattice.
To date, many host materials such as fluoride [29–32], oxide [33, 34], phosphate [35], and oxysulfide [36] NPs have been synthesized for the doping of Ln3C emitters with tunable emissions for different biosensing purposes. Since the emissions of Ln3C occur within the host crystal, the optical properties of Ln3C ions show little sensitivity to outer chemical environments (i.e., buffer chemistry and assay temperature), which is highly desirable for sensitive fluorescent detection and imaging [37]. Besides, magnetic NPs have also been widely used in current clinical diagnosis and therapy. For example, paramagnetic NPs (Gd2O3, MnO) and superparamagnetic NPs (Fe3O4, MnFe2O4, FeCo alloys) have garnered significant attention owing to their clinical applications as MRI contrast agents [4], and magnetic iron oxide-based NPs were used for magnetic-field-assisted manipulation and bio-separation [23]. To combine the optical and magnetic functional units into one system, many synthetic
168 8 Multimodal Biosensing Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nano-bioprobes
strategies have been reported. Generally, the optical/magnetic multimodal NPs can be classified into two categories based on their structures: core–shell NPs and singlephase NPs, as highlighted in the following.

sections.heading: 8.2.1 Core–Shell Nanoparticles
sections.text:
Core–shell structure is a straightforward route for the preparation of multifunctional NPs that can integrate and maintain the properties of original individual layer. Therefore, great efforts have been dedicated to the synthesis of this kind of nanomaterials with magnetic core and luminescent shell, or with luminescent core and magnetic shell [14]. Most of the core–shell-structured NPs were prepared through conventional layer-by-layer coating, in which surface modification with polymer is usually needed to facilitate the growth of heterogeneous shell materials on the original cores (Fig. 8.2a) [19]. The method has several advantages including the possibility of tuning the coating thickness and corresponding optical or magnetic properties [38]. For the core–shell-structured multimodal NPs, iron oxides such as Fe3O4 are usually employed as the magnetic units, while Ln3C-doped NPs are served as fluorescent units, for instance, NaYF4:Yb/Tm@FexOy [39], Fe3O4@NaLuF4:Yb,Er/Tm [13], Fe3O4@NaYF4:Yb/Er [40], and Fe3O4@LaF3:Yb/Er [14] NPs. The T2 (spin– spin relaxation time) magnetic resonance properties result from the superparamagnetic iron oxide (Fe3O4), and the excellent upconversion (UC) emissions arise from Ln3C-doped fluorides. Besides superparamagnetic iron oxides, paramagnetic materials such as Gd3C-based inorganic materials with superior T1 (spin–lattice relaxation time) magnetic resonance properties can also be employed as magnetic units. In particular, van Veggel and co-workers proposed a universal strategy based on cation exchange reaction to prepare core–shell fluoride NPs (GdF3@LnF3 or GdF3@LnF3) [41, 42]. Recently, by refining this synthetic route, they have synthesized NaYF4:Yb/Tm@NaGdF4 NPs through cation exchange of NaYF4:Yb/Tm NPs with Gd3C ions [43]. In their studies, the intensity of UC emission from the core–shell NPs is remarkably enhanced relative to the initial NaYF4:Yb/Tm core counterparts. More importantly, the thickness of NaGdF4 shell can be easily tuned by varying the amount of Gd3C salt in the cation exchange process.
Another common approach to the synthesis of core–shell NPs is to encapsulate magnetic or fluorescent NPs into mesoporous silica shell, which is usually formed by the hydrolysis of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) (Fig. 8.2b) [19]. The silica shell is not only chemically stable and biocompatible but also allows easy functionalization of NPs with protein or antibody [44, 45]. Lin and co-workers recently reported an interesting work, where Fe3O4@nSiO2@mSiO2@NaYF4:Yb,Er/Tm nanocomposites that exhibited high magnetization (38.0 emu/g) and bright UC emission under 980-nm laser excitation [46] were synthesized. The mesoporous silica shell, which protected the fluorescence from NaYF4:Yb,Er/Tm being quenched by inner magnetite core, was beneficial to the loading of drug. This multifunctional system
can be potentially used as a targeted drug delivery system under external magnetic field, and the drug release amount can be monitored by the change of the UC emission intensity.
In addition, because the physical contact between magnetic ions and water is the major contribution to the change in the spin–lattice relaxation time T1 [47], the magnetic ions available for water access are thus limited by doping into the multimodal NPs, where only a portion of the surface of NPs is occupied by magnetic ions. As such, an effective way to maximizing the magnetic resonance properties is surface modification with magnetic ions (Fig. 8.2c) [19]. To this regard, Li and coworkers synthesized Gd3C complex-modified NaLuF4:Yb/Tm UC nanophosphors by using the Gd3C complex (Gd–DTPA) as the surface ligand [44]. Recently, they developed a novel method of rare-earth cation-assisted ligand assembly to synthesize Gd3C-modified NaYF4:Yb/Er UCNPs [9]. In their study, NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs were first synthesized via a modified cothermolysis process in oleylamine. After that, Gd3C ions were introduced on the surface of NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs by cation-assisted ligand assembly. It should be noted that the Gd3C ions increased the positive charge on the surface of NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs, so that the functional molecules (i.e., folic acid, oleic acid, and aminocaproic acid) can be attached.

sections.heading: 8.2.2 Single-Phase Nanoparticles
sections.text:
Although the above methods for synthesizing core–shell NPs can integrate individual nanocomponent into one NP, the produced hybrid composites either tend to agglomerate or have a larger particle size. What’s more, the preparation of these materials is usually complicated and time-consuming. To solve this problem, many new methods have been proposed, among which one effective way is to prepare single-phase NPs by co-doping magnetic ions and Ln3C ions into inorganic NPs to
170 8 Multimodal Biosensing Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nano-bioprobes
endow them with both luminescent and magnetic properties [48]. In stark contrast to the core–shell NPs, single-phase multimodal NPs can be synthesized via facile one-step routes such as solvothermal or coprecipitation methods.
Doping techniques are widely applied in materials science that involves the incorporation of appropriate atoms or ions into the host lattice to yield multimodal materials, for instance, SrF2:Yb/Er/Gd [8], NaYF4:Yb/Er/Gd [49], and NaLuF4:Gd/Yb/Tm [50]. Recently, Prasad and co-workers synthesized NaYF4 NPs co-doped with Gd3C and Er3C/Yb3C/Eu3C ions via thermal decomposition of corresponding Ln3C trifluoroacetate precursors under nitrogen atmosphere [51]. Intense DS and UC emissions were generated from Ln3C ions (Eu3C, Er3C/Yb3C), and Gd3C ions can provide high contrast MRI modality. Furthermore, after conjugation with tumor-specific antibodies, these NaYF4 NPs were demonstrated to be used for targeted imaging of living cancer cells in vitro. Note that doping will also influence the growth process to control over the crystallographic phase and size of the resulting NPs [8, 52]. Hao and co-workers reported the synthesis of NaLuF4:Gd/Yb/Tm NPs with controllable size and phase by doping different contents of Gd3C ions (Fig. 8.3) [50]. The addition of Gd3C ions promoted the phase transformation from cubic to hexagonal and reduced the particle size from large micro-tubes to small cubes (Fig. 8.3a, b). Meanwhile, the UC luminescence intensity of NaLuF4:Gd/Yb/Tm increased with the Gd3C content, which was ascribed to the formation of more hexagonal phase induced by doping Gd3C. However, the UC emission intensity decreased evidently with further increasing Gd3C content, which was mainly attributed to a significant reduction in size of NaLuF4 NPs from microscale to nanoscale (Fig. 8.3c). Besides the variation of UC emission, the magnetization of these NaLuF4:Gd/Yb/Tm NPs also changed with the doping of Gd3C ions (Fig. 8.3d). The magnetization of the NaLuF4 NPs can be modified from 0.34 to 0.88 emu/g at 20 kOe with increasing the Gd3C content from 10 to 45 %.
Among all the single-phase NPs, some host materials containing metal ions with unpaired electrons, like Gd3C, Mn2C, and Fe3C, are reported to be excellent candidate for the doping of Ln3C ions to produce optical/magnetic multimodal bioprobes. In particular, Gd-based NPs (GdF3, NaGdF4, Gd2O3, GdPO4, GdVO4, etc.) were demonstrated to be used as host materials for UC and DC luminescence and as efficient MRI contrast agent [53–56]. Recently, we synthesized Ln3C-doped KGdF4 NPs via a facile one-step solvothermal route by employing polyethylenimine (PEI) as the surfactant and capping ligand (Fig. 8.4a, b) [18]. In the as-prepared KGdF4:Ln3C NPs, intense long-lived multicolor emissions under single-wavelength (273 nm) excitation were achieved through the energy transfer process from Gd3C to different Ln3C dopants (Eu3C, Tb3C, or Dy3C) (Fig. 8.4c). Furthermore, the KGdF4 NPs can be used as robust MRI contrast agents (Fig. 8.4d). By using the similar synthetic route, we have also prepared carboxyl group-enriched GdF3:Ln3C NPs with poly(acrylic acid) (PAA) as the surfactant and capping ligand [17]. Besides Gd-based NPs, host materials containing Mn2C (e.g., KMnF3 and NaMnF3) [57] or Dy3C (e.g., NaDyF4) [58] were also documented with both intense PL emissions and bright T1 MRI contrast properties.
8.3 Biosensing 171

sections.heading: 8.3 Biosensing
sections.text:
It is anticipated that the combination of the excellent optical and magnetic properties in one nanocomposite would open up new avenues in the fields of both nanotechnology and biomedicine, enabling the advent of some unique multimodal sensing techniques. According to different combinations of optical and magnetic functionalities, the presently established biosensing based on Ln3C-doped optical/magnetic multimodal probes can be generally classified into four major categories, namely, integration of PL detection and MRI, magnetic-separation-assisted PL detection, magnetic-field-guided targeted optical imaging, and optical/MR bimodal imaging, which will be briefly overviewed in the following.
172 8 Multimodal Biosensing Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nano-bioprobes

sections.heading: 8.3.1 Integration of Photoluminescence Detection and Magnetic Resonance Imaging
sections.text:
Fluorescent labeling and MRI are both widely used in clinical practice. As discussed above, TR detection by employing the long-lived PL of Ln3C (such as Tb3C and Eu3C) will offer signals with remarkably high S/N ratio. The validity of integration of TR PL detection and MRI was verified by our recent work (Fig. 8.5) [17], in
which carboxyl group functionalized Ln3C-doped GdF3 NPs were prepared via a facile one-step solvothermal route (Fig. 8.5a, b) and then served as the first sensitive TRPL bioprobes to detect trace amount of avidin with a detection limit of 5 ng/mL or 74 pM (Fig. 8.5c, d) and as robust positive contrast agents for T1 MRI (Fig. 8.5f). By tuning the combinations of Ln3C dopants and their concentrations, multicolor emissions spanning a wide spectral region were achieved in GdF3 NPs under single-wavelength excitation (Fig. 8.5e), which makes them highly suitable as multimodal bioprobes. More recently, we also developed a new bioprobe based on amine-functionalized KGdF4:Ln3C NPs, which were employed as a sensitive TR fluorescence resonance energy transfer (TR-FRET) biosensor to detect avidin with a detection limit down to 5.5 nM, and as a promising T1-weighted MRI contrast agent due to the large longitudinal relaxivity of Gd3C (5.86 S 1 mM 1 per Gd ion and 3.99 105 S 1 mM 1 per nanocrystal) [18].
174 8 Multimodal Biosensing Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nano-bioprobes

sections.heading: 8.3.2 Magnetic-Separation-Assisted Photoluminescence Detection
sections.text:
Despite the remarkable applicability of Ln3C-doped NPs in biodetection, their current use is still greatly limited by the background noise resulted from biological samples. Thus, to meet the demands of modern biotechnology, magnetic-separationassisted PL detection has been proposed, which can be used to isolate the bioprobes from biomolecules and other biological entities that contribute to background noise [59]. This is a major advantage over conventional single-modal optical detection. One of the earliest reports for magnetic-separation-assisted PL detection based on Ln3C-doped multimodal probes was demonstrated by Li and co-workers in the detection of DNA (Fig. 8.6) [59]. In their study, a three-component sandwich assay was used: Fe3O4 NPs were modified with capture DNA, which can be conjugated to probe DNA-modified NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs through the hybridization of the target DNA. The Fe3O4@NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs were then separated from the unconjugated NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs with the assistance of magnetic field. Finally, the UC luminescence (UCL) signals were detected upon excitation with a commercially available 980-nm laser. Their result indicated that the concentration of target DNA in the range of 7.8–78.0 nM was linear very well to the UCL intensity.
8.3 Biosensing 175

sections.heading: 8.3.3 Magnetic-Field-Guided Targeted Optical Imaging
sections.text:
In addition to biodetection, another important application based on Ln3C-doped NPs is bioimaging. Since the magnetic materials can be guided in the presence of an external magnetic field, the optical/magnetic multimodal bioprobes can easily be manipulated by the magnetic field. As such, the multimodal NPs can be guided to the site of interest, whereas the luminescence from doped Ln3C ions can be used for real-time imaging [60].
Inspired by this concept, Liu and co-workers realized the in vivo multimodal labeling, tracking, and manipulation of mouse mesenchymal stem cells (mMSCs) by employing Au-coated NaYF4:Yb/Er@Fe3O4 multifunctional NPs (MFNPs) as probes [61]. Stronger UCL intensity was detected on the site injected with more MFNP-labeled mMSCs (Fig. 8.7a, b). As few as 10 MFNP-labeled mMSCs transplanted into the mouse can be detected on site 1, indicative of high sensitivity of MFNP-based in vivo stem cell tracking. Furthermore, the magnetic-field-induced stem cell translocation in vivo was also investigated. As shown in Fig. 8.7c–e, the MFNP-labeled mMSCs intraperitoneally injected in the middle of the abdomen can be guided to wound where a magnet was attached. Bright UCL signals were observed 6 h later from the site with the magnet attached, suggesting that the cells labeled with magnetic NPs can be manipulated by applying a magnetic field. Similarly, obvious darkening effect was also observed by T2-weighted MR imaging in the wound site nearby the magnet (Fig. 8.7f). Besides, strong UCL signals from MFNP-labeled mMSCs were observed in the confocal images of the wound slices, while negligible UCL signals were detected on the other side of wound without magnet attached (Fig. 8.7g). All these results revealed the excellent magnetic-fieldguided targeting effect of tracking and controlling of the MFNP-labeled mMSCs in vivo.

sections.heading: 8.3.4 Multimodal Imaging
sections.text:
Because different imaging methods have different spatial resolutions, imaging depths, and areas of application, multimodal imaging, which can fuse together the useful information from several imaging techniques by inheriting the advantages of individual imaging modalities, will result in a comprehensive imaging regime. Integrating fluorescence imaging and MRI contrast enhancement into a single NP is a common strategy of the multimodal imaging [14, 51, 56, 62, 63]. Currently several groups realized optical and MR dual-modal imaging by employing Ln3Cdoped NPs, exemplified by Fe3O4@LaF3:Yb/Er [14], NaYF4:Yb/Er/Gd [49, 51], and Gd2O3:Yb/Er [33], to name a few. In addition to optical and MR dual-modal imaging, more imaging modalities were combined into the identical nanoprobe for visualization of the same target at different levels from the cellular scale to the whole body. Specifically, Li and co-workers successfully demonstrated MR/UCL/positron
176 8 Multimodal Biosensing Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nano-bioprobes
8.3 Biosensing 177
emission tomography (PET) trimodal imaging based on Gd3C-capped, 18F -labeled NaYF4:Yb/Er NPs, where radioactive 18F ions were introduced on the UCNPs through interaction with the Ln3C ions (Fig. 8.8) [9]. The doping of Yb3C, Er3C, and
178 8 Multimodal Biosensing Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nano-bioprobes
Gd3C ions endowed NaYF4 NPs with bright UC emissions (Fig. 8.8a–c) and high T1 enhancement (Fig. 8.8d, e), respectively. Intense radioactivity signals were observed exclusively in the liver and spleen (Fig. 8.8f), which confirmed that multimodal NPs had been taken up by these two organs. The results were consistent with those from UCL and MR imagings and further confirmed by the biodistribution of these multimodal NPs (Fig. 8.8g). Likewise, in their subsequent study, Li and co-workers further demonstrated UCL/MRI/X-ray computed tomography (CT) trimodal imaging by employing Gd3C/Yb3C/Er3C (or Tm3C)-co-doped NaLuF4 NPs [64].

sections.heading: 8.4 Theranostics
sections.text: With the rapid development in the field of oncology as well as in other branches of biomedical nanotechnology, the design and fabrication of multimodal NPs that would simultaneously perform drug delivery, targeted diagnosis, and therapy have evoked intensive attention in recent years [65]. Particularly, multimodal NPs with unique structure and desirable optical/magnetic properties seem to be an ideal system for biomedical applications in targeted drug delivery and optical/magnetic disease theranostics.

sections.heading: 8.4.1 Targeted Drug Delivery
sections.text:
Rapid advances in the synthesis of multimodal Ln3C-doped NPs have led to the development of new analytical tools for various bioapplications. There is an increasing demand for new materials and methodologies to bridge the gap between biomaterials and clinic theranostics. In the field of disease diagnosis and therapy, one of the most essential challenges is enhancing the target specificity of therapeutic agents. To accomplish this goal, tremendous effort has been devoted to the development of various targeted drug delivery systems. For example, drug vehicles based on Ln3C-doped multimodal NPs were developed for the delivery of drug molecules to the target cells by surface modification with specific biological molecules or under an external magnetic field [66]. Among multimodal NPs, biocompatible silica-coated core–shell nanomaterials with mesoporous structure have been commonly selected as ideal carriers for drug delivery, due to their high specific surface and cavity volumes, as reported by Lin and co-workers who synthesized NaYF4:Yb/Er@mSiO2 NPs for the loading of anticancer drug within the porous silica shell [67]. Furthermore, they synthesized NaYF4:Yb/Er@mSiO2 nanofibers, which can also be used for drug delivery and cell imaging [68].
8.4 Theranostics 179
For conventional targeted drug delivery system based on inorganic NPs, surface modification with specific biomolecules (e.g., nuclear localizing signal peptide [69, 70] and folic acid [71–73]) is generally required in order to label the NPs with target cells or biological tissues. For example, by conjugating NaYF4:Yb/Er@NaGdF4 NPs with nuclear localizing signal peptide (TAT), Shi and co-workers realized the loading of anticancer drug doxorubicin (DOX) in NPs and simultaneously monitoring the cellular uptake of these multimodal NPs by means of MR/UC bimodal imaging (Fig. 8.9a) [69]. Note that the DOX-loaded NaYF4:Yb/Er@NaGdF4 NPs can easily migrate into the cell nuclei of human HeLa cells because the TAT protein bound to NPs was effective in nuclear translocation of recombinant fusion proteins (Fig. 8.9b). In their conceptual experiment, a concentration of DOX in the cancer cell nuclei and an enhanced activity in killing the cancer cells were observed in only 24-h incubation.
In comparison with conventional surface modification method for targeted drug delivery, magnetic-field-assisted drug delivery is a more convenient and attractive strategy. In this regard, Zhang and co-workers proposed a yolk–shell nanorattles consisting of NaYF4:Yb/Er shells and Fe3O4 cores (MUC-F-NR) for targeted chemotherapy (Fig. 8.10) [74]. In their study, the anticancer drug DOX was loaded into the free volume of the nanorattle (Fig. 8.10a), which was subsequently utilized as in vivo antitumor agents under external magnetic field (Fig. 8.10b). The active accumulation of DOX-loaded MUC-F-NR on the tumor under external magnetic field can be observed from UC emissions, in stark contrast to the passive accumulation of DOX-loaded MUC-F-NR without magnetic field (Fig. 8.10c). Similar UC luminescence from in vivo and ex vivo imaging of tumor demonstrated that scattering and absorbance from the surrounding tissue of the tumor had little impact on the UCL imaging (Fig. 8.10d). More importantly, in the presence of magnetic field for marine hepatocarcinoma (H22) tumor-bearing mice, DOXloaded MUC-F-NR showed excellent in vivo therapeutic efficacy for liver cancer (Fig. 8.10e).

sections.heading: 8.4.2 Optical/Magnetic Disease Theranostics
sections.text:
The optical and magnetic properties of multimodal NPs provide unparalleled opportunity for simultaneous diagnosis and therapy of diseases. For example, MRI has been considered as an important clinical diagnostic tool for providing unsurpassed three-dimensional soft tissue information in detail. Phototherapy like PTA or PDT is a form of medical treatment in which light is used to treat diseases including a variety of cancers [22, 23].
Particularly, PDT is an emerging therapeutic technique for a variety of diseases, due to its low cost, high efficiency, and minimal extra trauma [75, 76]. In PDT treatment, photosensitizer molecules are excited by light with appropriate
180 8 Multimodal Biosensing Based on Lanthanide-Doped Nano-bioprobes
wavelength, producing cytotoxic reactive oxygen species and singlet oxygen (1O2) to destroy nearby cancer cells [77]. Conventional photosensitizers used in PDT are mostly activated by ultraviolet (UV) and/or visible light with low penetration ability, which limits their application for treating tumors under the skin or inside the body. Because of the energy transfer from UCNPs to photosensitizer, the
8.4 Theranostics 181
use of UCNPs in PDT can afford deeper penetration than that of visible lightexcited PDT agent [78]. Moreover, instead of irradiating the photosensitizers in the UV-visible range, UCNPs are usually excited with deep-penetrating NIR light, and the upconverted visible light in turn excites the organic photosensitizer, which then produces lethal singlet oxygen (Fig. 8.11) [79]. Furthermore, by using optical/magnetic multimodal NPs, the therapy process can be monitored by both PL and MR imaging. To this regard, several photosensitizer-conjugated multimodal UCNPs like NaYF4:Yb/Er@NaGdF4 [7] and NaYF4:Er/Yb/Gd@SiO2 [80] were developed for NIR-excited PDT of tumors. In the PDT treatment, the accumulation of NPs within cancer cells is an important factor to realize highly effective therapy. Very recently, Liu and co-workers developed a pH-sensitive PDT agent by employing two layers of chlorine e6 (Ce6)-conjugated NaYF4:Yb/Er/Mn NPs (UCNP@2 Ce6) with strong red UC emission at 660 nm to activate the photosensitizer Ce6 [81]. After further coating with charge-reversible polymer containing dimethylmaleic acid (DMMA) groups and poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) chains, UCNP@2 Ce6-DMMA-PEG nanocomposites was obtained (Fig. 8.12a). The surface of nanocomposites can be converted to be positively charged, which was beneficial to their binding to negatively charged membranes of cancer cells. Because the tumor extracellular environment was acidic (pH 6.5–6.8), significantly enhanced cell internalization of NPs in cancer cells and thus the increasing PDT efficacy can be achieved. One day after the injection with UCNP@2 Ce6-DMMA-PEG NPs, only a slight decline of the MR and UCL intensity was observed (Fig. 8.12b and d), while sharply decreased intensity was found for the mice injected with pHinsensitive UCNP@2 Ce6-SA-PEG counterparts (Fig. 8.12c and e). Their results indicated that UCNP@2 Ce6-DMMA-PEG could serve as promising smart pHresponsive PDT agents in cancer theranostics.

metadata.abstractText: Lanthanide (Ln) ions are long known as the lighting elements. Their intricate optical properties originate primarily from the unique features of their electronic [Xe]4f N configurations (ND 0–14), which have very localized states and can be conventionally described within the framework of crystal-field theory. On placing an Ln ion in a dielectric crystal, the energy levels split under the influence of the electric field produced by the crystalline environment. In this chapter, a general introduction to free Ln ions is addressed, which includes the energy-level structures, selection rules of electronic transitions, site symmetry, as well as crystal-field theory for free Ln ions. 1.1 Free Lanthanide Ions In general, the term lanthanides (Ln) refers to a series of consecutive chemical elements in the periodic table from lanthanum to lutetium (atomic numbers ZD 57– 71), while the rare earths (RE) are commonly used for the lanthanides coupled with the elements scandium (ZD 21) and yttrium (ZD 39). Except scandium and yttrium, they have very similar electronic configurations for trivalent ions ([Xe]4f N), namely, all the trivalent Ln3C ions have unfilled electron shell structure 4f N (ND 1–14) (Table 1.1). Note that the most commonly studied valence state of the Ln or RE ions is the trivalent one in this book, when the terms Ln and RE are used; henceforth, we shall always mean the trivalent state, that is, Ln3C or RE3C, unless otherwise specified. As shown in Table 1.1, the partially occupied 4f N electrons for these trivalent Ln3C ions are not in the outer shell and are efficiently shielded by the filled 5s and 5p electron shells, the ligand and/or crystal-field (CF) environment thereby has only a weak influence on the electronic cloud of Ln ions even in solid materials. Although weak, this weak influence can be treated as a perturbation known as the CF interaction, which is mainly responsible for the fine spectral structure of Ln3C ions [1, 2]. For the electronic [Xe]4f N configurations of Ln3C ions, they indeed generate X. Due to the shielding of the filled 5s25p6 subshells, the electronic transitions between these 4f N states (levels) are very sharp and have features resembling those of free ion. In particular, they do not vary much with the chemical environments in which the Ln3C ions are inserted. This diagram has been frequently referred in the literature and can give us a general idea of the energy-level positions for all Ln3C ions and help us in the analysis of unknown spectra in diverse nanomaterials, to determine their exact energy-level positions. 4 1 A General Introduction to Lanthanide Ions 1.2 Energy-Level Structures of Free Lanthanide Ions A major outcome from the electronic spectra of Ln3C ions is the assignment of the 4f N energy levels, which is of particularly useful for their applications in diverse fields such as lasers and phosphors. For multi-electron free (gaseous) Ln3C ions, the energy levels of each electronic configuration will be split into a series of energy levels, owing to the interaction between the electron orbital magnetic moment and the spin magnetic moment. These states can be described under the Russell–Saunders coupling scheme by the multiplet 2SC1LJ that is composed of (2SC 1)(2LC 1) states, where S and L denote the total electron spin and orbital angular momenta, respectively [3]. The values of LD 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 are used to be designated by the letters S, P, D, F, G, H, I, K, L in spectroscopy. Due to the coupling of the orbital angular momentum and the spin angular momentum in quantum mechanics, these multiplets 2SC1L are usually composed of total 2J C1 possible microstates, where J is the total (i.e., vector sum of S and L) angular momenta. When it comes to the coupling scheme of the orbital angular momentum and the spin angular momentum, hitherto, there are four models of coupling in the atomic spectroscopy theory, that is, LS coupling (Russell–Saunders coupling), jj coupling, pair coupling (Racah coupling), and intermediate coupling [3]. Among these four coupling schemes, LS coupling is the most commonly used coupling scheme for Ln3C ions, in view of their much stronger electrostatic interaction between different 4f electrons relative to their spin–orbit interaction. In this model, the spin momenta si and orbital momenta li of all the electrons are first coupled by exchange interaction to form a total spin and orbital angular momenta S and L, respectively, and then the total spin angular momentum S couples with the total orbital angular momentum L into the total angular momentum J. According to this coupling scheme, the possible microstates can be designated by 2SC1LJ . For example, for 4f 1 configuration of Ce3C, there are two multiplets, that is, F5/2 and F7/2, where SD 1/2, LD 3, and JD 5/2 or 7/2. For 4f 3 configuration of Nd3C, there exist a series of states having quantum numbers SD 3/2, LD 6, and JD 9/2, 11/2, 13/2, and 15/2, which correspond to the multiplets of I9/2, I11/2, I13/2, and I15/2, respectively. For 4f N configurations of other Ln3C ions, the allowed spectroscopic multiplets or terms were collected and listed in Table 1.3. In Table 1.3, the 2SC1Ln means that the terms of L appear n times and the J values corresponding to the different possible states (or energy levels) are not shown, which can be easily obtained from L and S as follows: JDL S, L SC 1, : : : , LC S 1, LC S. When the number of 4f electrons is large, it should be noted that three quantum numbers LSJ are inadequate to classify different states completely. The states with the same LSJ number can appear up to ten times as exemplified by GJ multiplets of Gd3C (Table 1.3). In order to completely classify the states in a 4f N configuration, an additional quantum number ¤, called the seniority number, is needed for distinguishing the states that have the same L and S quantum numbers. As a matter of fact, two or more quantum numbers are required in order to completely define the states in a 4f N configuration. The other classification number is UD (u1u2), for characterizing the irreducible representations of the group G2. Details in classification of the 4f N states were given in the books by Judd and Wybourne [1, 9]. Besides, it is worthy of pointing out that some qualitative rules are very helpful to understand the energy-level structures of Ln3C ions in Fig. 1.1 [3]. One of the wellknown qualitative rules is Hund’s rule, which has the following guidelines: (1) the terms (or states) with the largest S values have the lowest energy values among all the terms of an electron configuration. Among these terms, those with the highest L values have the lowest energy values; (2) for the terms in configuration with a number of electrons equal or exceeding that of the half-filled shell, the larger the J value, the lower the energy. On the other hand, if the number of electrons lower than that of half-filled shell, then the smaller the J values, the lower the energy. On the basis of the above qualitative rule, one can readily determine which multiplet is the ground state of a 4f N configuration of Ln3C ions. Taking trivalent Nd3C ions, for example, we know that the 4f 3 electron configuration of Nd3C belongs to the case of an electron number lower than that of a half-filled shell. The total spin angular momentum S for these three electrons is 3/2 in maximum, and the maximum orbital angular momentum L is 6. According to second guideline of Hund’s rule, the energy of state with JD 6 3/2D 9/2 will be the lowest one. Therefore, the ground states of Nd3C should be I9/2. By contrast, the trivalent Er3C ions have 4f 11 electron configuration and have the same terms and states as those for the 4f 3 configuration. However, its electron number exceeds that of the halffilled shell and so the larger the J, the lower the energy. Then its ground state should be I15/2 (JD 6C 3/2). From the 4f N energy-level diagrams of trivalent Ln3C ions (Fig. 1.1), it can be seen that Hund’s rule is really available. If one considers the Gd3C ion as a center, the multiplets of any Ln3C ions in the left positions can be 6 1 A General Introduction to Lanthanide Ions found in those of Ln3C ions in the corresponding right positions. Nevertheless, for the same term, the lower multiplets in the left will be the higher multiplets in the right. Furthermore, it should also be noted that the energy separations between different terms and different multiples in the same term are larger for Ln3C ions in the right of Gd3C ion. This phenomenon is induced by the fact that the Coulomb interaction between electrons and the spin–orbital interaction are stronger for the right part of rare earth ions due to radius reduction of lanthanide contraction and the fact that the spin–orbital coupling is proportional to Z4. 1.3 Crystal-Field Theory and Site Symmetry 1.3.1 Crystal-Field Theory The multi-electron systems for Ln3C ions are complicate systems in quantum mechanics, and, thus, it is impossible to solve its energy-level structure strictly and analytically. Fortunately, just like many other problems in quantum mechanics, the problem can be simplified by neglecting some less important interactions in a good enough approximation. Among these, the central field approximation is one of the most important. The atoms can be treated as N electrons, with mass me and charge e, moving around a nucleus with infinite mass and charge of Z. The 4f electrons have very localized states that are conventionally described within the framework of CF theory [1].
